1 1. 11 OS §§ 9-114, 34-101 et seq.
2.16.010: CREATED; CONTROL AND SUPERVISION:
There is created within the government of the city a department to be known as
the police department, and offices shall be furnished by the city. The
department shall be under the control and supervision of the chief of police,
which office and position is created. (Ord. 368, 1974)
2.16.020: DEPARTMENT PROPERTY; GENERAL POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF CHIEF OF POLICE:
The department shall have possession and control of all records, books, papers,
offices, equipment, automobiles, and all other property now or hereafter held
for or by the police department. The chief of police shall have and possess
such other, further and additional power and authority as may be granted in
this chapter or as may otherwise be provided by law. (Ord. 368(1), 1974)
2.16.030: CHIEF OFFICER:
The mayor shall be the chief officer of the department and the chief of police
shall execute the lawful orders of the mayor and shall be responsible to him
for the operation and administration of the department. (Ord. 368(2), 1974)
2.16.040: CONTROL OF DEPARTMENT:
The police department shall be under the control of an executive officer to be
known as the chief of police, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the city council. (Ord. 368 §1(a), 1974)
2.16.050: POLICE CHIEF QUALIFICATIONS:
The appointment to the position of chief of police shall be based on
qualifications of at least five (5) years of command experience; and, further,
on the previous record as a member of a police department or law enforcement
body or agency, length of service and efficiency of the services performed.
(Ord. 455 §1, 1977)
2.16.060: BOND; POLICE CHIEF AND CERTAIN EMPLOYEES:
The chief of police, after his appointment and before entering upon the
discharge of his duties, shall execute a bond to the city, which bond shall be
furnished by a surety company authorized to do business in the state. Such bond
shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of duty as is now required by
other public officials and shall be the sum of not less than ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00). He shall take and subscribe to the oath of office
required by the constitution. The chief of police may require any assistant or
other employee of the police department to furnish bond in like manner in the
amount not to exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), where such assistant or
employee has charge of any public funds or property belonging to the city. The
premium on bonds required by this chapter shall be paid from the funds
hereinafter appropriated for the support and maintenance of the police
department. (Ord. 368 §1(c), 1974)
2.16.070: ORGANIZATION OF DEPARTMENT:
The chief of police shall organize the department in such a manner as may deem
necessarily proper to conduct the work of the department, including the
modifying of the basic code of conduct as the need does arise. (Ord. 384 §1,
1975: Ord. 368 §2, 1974)
2.16.080: APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS, INVESTIGATORS AND EMPLOYEES:
The chief of police, subject to the merit system rules and conditions set forth
in this chapter, shall appoint such subordinates, officers, investigators, and
other employees as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this
chapter, not exceeding the number established by the council. (Ord. 368 §3,
1974)
2.16.090: SELECTION OF COMMAND OFFICERS:
The chief of police shall appoint subordinate command officers, such as
assistant chief, majors, captains, lieutenants and sergeants. (Ord. 1005 §1,
2005: Ord. 603 §1, 1985: Ord. 368 §4(a), 1974)
2.16.100: PROBATIONARY PERIOD:
Probationary officers, when first appointed, shall be required to serve a
probationary period of one year. During such probationary period, their
services may be terminated at any time and for any reason in the discretion of
the chief of police. Retention in the service after the expiration of the
probationary period of one year shall entitle such officer to be classified as
a permanent employee and he shall be so except as set out in charter or
ordinance. (Ord. 516 §1, 1981)
2.16.110: QUALIFICATIONS FOR OFFICERS:
No person shall be appointed as policeman in the city unless at the time of his
or her appointment he or she is in good physical condition and of good moral
character, not less than twenty one (21) years of age and possesses a high
school education or the equivalent evidenced by a GED test. (Ord. 384 §2, 1975:
Ord. 368 §4(c), 1974)
2.16.120: TRAINING FOR DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
The chief of police is authorized to send members of the police department to
such schools as Oklahoma University, Oklahoma State University, the National
Police Academy conducted by the federal bureau of investigation and to other
schools of similar training which would be conducive to improving the
efficiency of the police department. (Ord. 368 §4(d), 1974)
2.16.130: TRAVELING EXPENSES; FURNISH MOTOR VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT:
In addition to the salaries or wages of the chief of police or other employees
of the police department when deemed necessary in connection with the discharge
of their duties respectively assigned or delegated to them, the chief of police
or other employees shall be allowed and paid their actual necessary traveling
expenses incurred in the discharge of their respective duties while outside the
city. Such shall be paid from the same fund and in the same manner as other
salaries after the filing of proper claims as approved by the city council. The
chief of police shall be and he is authorized and empowered to furnish motor
vehicles and other equipment for use while on such assigned or delegated
duties. (Ord. 368 §5, 1974)
2.16.135: CUSTODY AND POSSESSION OF CERTAIN DUTY EQUIPMENT AT RETIREMENT:
A.   An officer or employee of the police department shall be entitled to
receive, upon retirement by reason of length of service, the continued custody
and possession of the collar brass and badge carried by such officer or
employee immediately prior to retirement with said items being declared surplus
and nonusable by the city council.
B.   An officer or employee of the police department may be entitled to
receive, upon retirement by reason of disability, the continued custody and
possession of the collar brass and badge carried by such officer or employee
immediately prior to retirement upon written approval of the chief of police
with said items being declared surplus and nonusable by the city council.
C.   Custody and possession of the collar brass and badge of an officer or
employee of the police department killed in the line of duty may be awarded to
the spouse or next of kin by the chief of police with said items being declared
surplus and nonusable by the city council.
D.   In the event that the police department issues new badges, the chief of
police may allow officers or employees of the police department and officials
or employees of the city to possess old badges, for display purposes only, in
accordance with title 11, section 11-116 of the Oklahoma state statutes with
said items being declared surplus and nonusable by the city council. Such
officers, officials or employees shall pay the costs of having said badges
mounted for display.
E.   An officer or employee of the police department shall be entitled to
receive, upon retirement in good standing after twenty (20) or more years of
full time service to the city of Warr Acres police department as a certified
law enforcement officer the continued custody and possession of his/her duty
weapon carried by such officer or employee immediately prior to retirement upon
written approval of the chief of police with said items being declared surplus
and nonusable by the city council. (Ord. 1106, 2011)
2.16.140: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY:
The chief of police is vested with the power and is charged with the duty of
observing, administering and enforcing the provisions of this chapter and all
other ordinances or laws of the city, the enforcement and administration of
which is now or hereafter vested in the police department. (Ord. 368 §6(a),
1974)
2.16.150: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The chief of police is authorized to adopt and enforce such rules and
regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter and
any other laws the enforcement of and administration of which are vested in the
police department. (Ord. 368 §6(b), 1974)
2.16.160: POLICE CHIEF REPRESENTATIVE:
The chief of police may in his discretion appoint any employee of the police
department as his representative to affix his signature to administrative
letters, notices and orders to enforce the provisions of the law, and authorize
such employee to affix the facsimile signature of the chief of police adopted
by him as a facsimile signature, provided however, it is unlawful and shall
constitute the crime of forgery to affix or endorse the facsimile signature of
the chief of police, as provided in this section, to any instrument, voucher,
check, claim or draft for the payment of money due and owing to the city. (Ord.
368 §6(c), 1974)
2.16.180: POLICE OFFICER POWERS:
A.   The chief of police and all other salaried, commissioned officers or
reserve officers of the police department shall have the power:
   1.   Of peace officers for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this
chapter and all others the enforcement of which is vested in the police
department;
   2.   The salaried officers of the police department shall have the powers
now or hereafter vested by law in peace officers except the serving of civil
process. The salaried, commissioned officers shall have the authority to arrest
without writ, rule, order or process any person in the city detected by them in
the act of violating any law of the city or the state;
   3.   To assist in the location of stolen property, including livestock and
poultry or the carcasses thereof, and to make necessary inspection of any
vehicle or contents thereof in connection therewith notwithstanding the
provisions of law. The powers and duties conferred in this section shall in no
way be a limitation on the powers and duties of sheriffs or other peace
officers of the state;
   4.   At all times to direct all traffic in conformance with law and, in the
event of a fire or other emergency, or to expedite traffic, or to ensure
safety, to direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the
provisions of law. Any policeman shall have authority, and it shall be his
duty, to require satisfactory proof of identification of any person suspected
of violation of any law or to require satisfactory proof of ownership of any
motor vehicle suspected of being used in any crime in the city or the state;
   5.   When on duty, upon reasonable belief that any vehicle is being operated
in violation of any provision of the ordinances of the city or the state, to
require the driver to stop and exhibit his driver's license, and to take such
action as is required by the ordinances and the policies of the police
department;
   6.   To inspect any vehicle of a type required to be registered in the state
in any public garage or repair shop in the city or any used or new car lot in
this city, for the purpose of locating stolen vehicles or hit and run vehicles
or those vehicles used in the commission of crime;
   7.   To serve all warrants relating to the enforcement of the laws and
ordinances of the city relating to the operation of vehicles or the use of
streets, and the compliance of the ordinances of the city or warrants given to
the police by state, county, or federal authority;
   8.   To investigate all accidents occurring upon the public streets and
property in the city, and upon private property when requested to do so, and to
secure the testimony of witnesses or of persons involved;
   9.   To investigate all thefts, burglaries, suicides and attempted suicides
or any crime committed within the city limits.
B.   The chief of police shall require that the officers of the police
department patrol the streets of the city and cooperate with sheriffs and
police officers of other departments in enforcing the laws of the state and the
United States.
C.   All members of the police department enforcement division when on duty
shall be dressed in distinctive uniform and display a badge of office, except
those assigned to special duty by the chief of police.
D.   The chief of police shall issue to each officer mentioned in subsection C
of this section a badge of authority with the seal of the state in the center
thereof with the words "Warr Acres Police" on the face thereof. Neither the
chief of police or any other person shall issue any such badge to any person
who is not a duly appointed and acting member of the police department or
reserve police.
E.   The chief of police shall require that the contents of this chapter are
available to each member of such police department and shall require that such
policemen follow such guide and such orders or code of conduct that is now or
hereafter may be adopted.
F.   No city official or any other person shall have the power, right, or
authority to command, order, or direct any policeman to perform any duty or
service contrary to the provisions of this chapter or the basic code of conduct
of the police department. (Ord. 368 §6(e), 1974)
2.16.190: DUTIES OF THE POLICE DEPARTMENT; MUTUAL AID ASSISTANCE:
It shall be the duty of the police chief and all police officers to enforce all
ordinances and applicable laws throughout the city, under the direction of the
mayor or his designee. The mayor or his designee and chief of police or his
designee are hereby authorized to respond to mutual aid calls under emergency
conditions on behalf of other law enforcement agencies including
municipalities, counties, the state of Oklahoma, or a federal law enforcement
agency, upon request of said agency and under such regulations and conditions
as may be established by the mayor or his designee. (Ord. 790 §1, 1996)
CHAPTER 2.20
CITY HALL OPERATIONS
(Rep. by Ord. 1038 §1, 2007)
CHAPTER 2.24

2.24.010: ORGANIZATION AND OPERATION:
This chapter shall govern the organization and operation of the municipal
criminal court of the city, as put into operation by a resolution duly passed
on January 7, 1969, and filed in accordance with law, as authorized by title
11, Oklahoma Statutes, section 958.1 and 958.2. To the extent of conflict
between any provisions of this chapter and the provisions of any other
ordinance of this city, the provisions of this chapter shall control. The court
shall be operative on and after January 13, 1969. (Ord. 285 §1, 1969)
2.24.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires a different meaning, the
following words are defined as follows:
ATTORNEY FOR THIS MUNICIPALITY: The city attorney.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The peace officer in charge of the police force of the
municipality.
CLERK: The clerk of this municipality, including any deputy or member of the
office staff of the clerk while performing duties of the clerk's office.
COURT: The municipal criminal court of the city.
GOVERNING BODY: The city council.
JUDGE: The judge of the municipal criminal court aforesaid, including any
acting judge or alternate judge thereof as provided for by the statutes of this
state and this chapter.
THIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT: The district court judicial district of the state
wherein the government of this municipality is situated. (Ord. 285 §2, 1969)
2.24.030: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION:
The court shall exercise original jurisdiction to hear, and determine all
prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance of this municipality is
charged, including any such prosecutions transferred to the court in accordance
with applicable law. (Ord. 285 §3, 1969)
2.24.040: JUDGE; ALTERNATE JUDGES:
A.   There shall be a judge of the court. The judge must be duly licensed to
practice law in the state. He may engage in the practice of law in other
courts, but he shall not accept employment inconsistent with his duties as
judge, or arising out of facts which give rise to or are connected with cases
within the jurisdiction of the court, pending therein or which might become the
subject of proceedings therein. He need not reside within the municipality.
B.   There shall be appointed for the judge a first alternate judge and a
second alternate judge, possessed of the same term and made in the same manner
as the judge. Either a first alternate or a second alternate judge shall sit as
acting judge of the court in any case if the judge is absent from court, unable
to act as judge, or disqualified from acting as judge in the case. (Ord. 285
§4, 1969)
2.24.050: TERMS OF JUDGES; ACTING JUDGES:
The official term of the judge shall be two (2) years, expiring on June 30 in
each even numbered year. The first alternate judge and the second alternate
judge shall serve a like term. The judge and alternate judge, unless sooner
removed for proper cause, shall serve until his successor is appointed and
qualified. If, at any time, there is no judge or alternate judge, duly
appointed and qualified, available to sit as judge, the mayor shall appoint
some person possessing the qualifications required by this chapter as judge,
who shall preside as acting judge over the court in the disposition of pending
matters until such time as a judge or alternate judge is available. (Ord. 285
§1, 1970: Ord. 285 §5, 1969)
2.24.060: APPOINTMENT OF JUDGES:
The judge and alternate judges shall be appointed by the mayor, with the
consent of the governing body, provided that the judge of the municipal court
existing in this municipality at the effective date of the ordinance codified
in this chapter shall act as judge of the court provided in this chapter until
a judge is appointed and qualified under the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 285
§6, 1969)
2.24.070: SALARY OF JUDGE:
The judge of the municipal court shall receive a salary in an amount to be
fixed by the city council monthly, paid in the same manner as the salaries of
other officials of this municipality. (Ord. 285 §7, 1969)
2.24.080: REMOVAL PROCEDURE OF JUDGES:
The judge or alternate judges of the municipal criminal court shall be subject
to removal from office, by the governing body, for the causes prescribed by the
constitution and laws of this state for the removal of public officers.
Proceedings for removal shall be instituted by the filing of a verified written
petition, setting forth facts sufficient to constitute one or more legal
grounds for removal. Petitions may be signed and filed by the mayor or twenty
five (25) or more qualified electors of this municipality; in the latter event,
verification may be executed by one or more of the petitioners. The governing
body shall set a date for hearing the matter, and shall cause notice thereof,
together with a copy of the petition, to be served personally upon the judge at
least ten (10) days before the hearing. At the hearing, the judge shall be
entitled to representation by counsel, to present testimony and to cross
examine the witnesses against him, and to have all evidence against him
presented in open hearing. So far as they can be made applicable, the
provisions of the Oklahoma administrative procedure act governing individual
proceedings 1  shall govern removal proceedings hereunder. Judgment of removal
shall be entered only upon individual votes, by a majority of all members of
the governing body, in favor or such removal. (Ord. 285 §8, 1969)
 
Notes
1 1. OS title 75, §§ 309–317.
2.24.090: VACANCY; SUCCESSOR JUDGES:
A.   A vacancy in the office of judge shall occur if the incumbent:
   1.   Dies;
   2.   Resigns;
   3.   Ceases to possess the qualifications for the office; or
   4.   Is removed, and the removal proceedings have been affirmed finally in
judicial proceedings or are no longer subject to judicial review.
B.   Upon the occurrence of a vacancy in the office of judge, the mayor shall
appoint a successor to complete the unexpired term, upon the same procedure as
an original appointment is made. (Ord. 285 §9, 1969)
2.24.100: CHANGE OF VENUE PROHIBITED:
In prosecutions before the court, no change of venue shall be allowed; but the
judge may certify his disqualification or he may be disqualified from sitting
under the terms, conditions and procedure provided by law for courts of record.
If a judge is disqualified, the matter shall be heard by an alternate or acting
judge. (Ord. 285 §10, 1969)
2.24.110: PRINCIPAL OFFICER OF THE COURT:
All writs or processes, which may be issued by the judge or the clerk of the
court, shall be directed, in his official title, to the chief of police of this
municipality, who shall be the principal officer of the court. He shall execute
all such writs or processes, provided, that such duties of service may also be
performed by any member of the police force of the city. (Ord. 526 §1, 1982)
2.24.120: CLERK OF THE COURT:
The clerk, or a deputy designated by him, shall be the clerk of the court. He
shall assist the judge in recording the proceedings of the court and in
preparing writs, processes and other papers. He shall administer oaths required
in proceedings before the court. He shall enter all pleadings, processes, and
proceedings in the dockets of the court. He shall perform such other clerical
duties relating to the proceedings of the court as the judge shall direct. He
shall receive and receipt for forfeitures, fees, deposits, and sums of money
payable to the court. He shall pay to the treasurer of this municipality, on
the first and fifteenth day of each month, all money so received by him, except
such special deposits or fees as shall be received to be disbursed by him for
special purposes. All money paid to the treasurer shall be placed in the
general fund of the municipality or in such other fund as the governing body
may direct, and it shall be used in the operation of the municipal government
in accordance with budgetary arrangements governing the fund in which it is
placed. (Ord. 285 §12, 1969)
2.24.130: PROSECUTING OFFICER:
The attorney for this municipality shall be the prosecuting officer of the
court. He shall prosecute all alleged violations of the ordinances of the city.
He shall be authorized, in his discretion, to prosecute and resist appeals,
proceedings in error and to review from this court to any other courts of the
state, and to represent this municipality in all proceedings arising out of
matters in this court. (Ord. 285 §13, 1969)
2.24.140: BOND; CLERK OF THE COURT:
The clerk of the court shall give bond, in the form provided by title 11 of the
Oklahoma Statutes, 1968 supplement, section 958.18, in a sum to be set by the
governing body and the bond shall be submitted to the governing body for
approval. (Ord. 285 §14, 1969)
2.24.150: CONDUCT OF THE BUSINESS OF THE COURT:
The judge may prescribe rules, consistent with the laws of the state and with
the ordinances of this municipality, for the proper conduct of the business of
the court. (Ord. 285 §15, 1969)
2.24.160: ENFORCEMENT OF COURT ORDERS, RULES AND JUDGMENTS:
Obedience to the orders, rules and judgments made by the judge or by the court
may be enforced by the judge, who may fine or imprison for contempt committed
as to him while holding court, or committed against process issued by him, in
the same manner and to the same extent as the district courts of this state.
(Ord. 285 §16, 1969)
2.24.170: WRITTEN COMPLAINT:
A.   All prosecution for violations of the ordinances of the municipality shall
be styled "The City of Warr Acres, Oklahoma vs. (naming defendant or
defendants)". Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, prosecutions shall
be initiated by the filing of a written complaint which shall be subscribed by
the person making the complaint and verified before a judge, court clerk, a
deputy court clerk or a police officer.
B.   No arrest warrant for a defendant or defendants charged in the complaint
filed shall be issued until the complaint has been approved by the city
attorney or the judge of the municipal court; or in the alternative, until a
hearing shall be had before the judge who shall issue the warrant for arrest
upon the finding of probable cause that an offense has been committed and that
the person or persons charged committed the offense. (Ord. 526 §2, 1982)
2.24.180: CITATIONS, ARRESTS, BAIL:
A.   If a police officer, or other person charged with the enforcement of the
ordinances of the city, including the building inspector, observes facts which
he believes constitute violation of an ordinance of this municipality, traffic
or nontraffic, committed by a resident thereof, in lieu of arresting such
person and requiring bail as provided in subsection B of this section, he may
take his name and address and other pertinent and necessary information and may
issue to him, in writing and in the form prescribed by the police department or
other department of the city, a citation embracing the required information,
and further stating the offense alleged to have occurred and notifying him to
answer to the charge in the court at a time as specified in the citation. The
officer, upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violator, endorsed
by such person signing the citation, to answer as specified, shall release the
person from custody. If the person to whom the citation is issued fails to
answer as prescribed in the citation, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest
and his appearance compelled.
B.   Whenever a resident of this municipality is arrested for the violation of
any ordinance and is not released by being allowed to sign a citation as
hereinabove provided, he shall be admitted to bail or released on his own
recognizance.
C.   Whenever a nonresident of this municipality is arrested for a violation,
other than traffic violation by a law enforcement officer, the defendant shall
be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment.
D.   If the alleged traffic violation is committed by a nonresident of this
municipality, the police officer shall take him into custody under arrest. The
arrested person either shall be taken before the judge for further proceedings
according to law or may be released upon the compliance with any of the
following bonding procedures:
   1.   Posting a cash bail in an amount and in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter; or
   2.   Depositing with the arresting officer an approved guaranteed arrest
bond certificate; or
   3.   Depositing with the arresting officer such person's valid license to
operate a motor vehicle in exchange for a receipt therefor issued by the
arresting officer. Such receipt shall be recognized as a temporary operator's
license and shall authorize the holder thereof to operate a motor vehicle until
the date of his hearing, but not to exceed twenty (20) days. The arresting
officer shall without undue delay deliver the license into the custody of the
court clerk.
Upon providing such required bail, the issuance of a citation, and upon giving
his written promise to appear on the date certain, as provided in subsection A
of this section, the arrested person shall be released from custody.
E.   In the event the offense charged is one which the maximum penalty is more
than thirty five dollars ($35.00) or for which the person arrested is entitled
to a jury trial, such arrested person shall not be permitted bail by posting a
valid driver's license but shall be required to post bail bond as provided in
section
2.24.200 of this chapter. (Ord. 641 §1, 1986)
2.24.181: FAILURE TO APPEAR:
The arresting officer shall indicate on the citation the date of trial, and the
defendant must appear in person or by counsel at the stated time and place. If
the defendant fails to appear in court in person or by counsel to answer the
charge against him, or fails to arrange for a future appearance, the cash bail,
if cash bail has been deposited by the defendant, shall be forfeited. If a
guaranteed arrest bond certificate has been deposited, the bond shall be
forfeited and proceedings to collect the sum involved shall be commenced by the
city attorney. If a license to operate a motor vehicle has been deposited, the
court clerk shall immediately forward to the department of public safety the
driver's license attached to an official notification form furnished by the
department of public safety, advising that the defendant failed to appear and
requesting suspension of the defendant's driver's license pursuant to state
law. If bail has been forfeited, the court may, upon motion of the city
attorney or upon its own motion, issue a bench warrant. (Ord. 480 §2, 1978)
2.24.190: TRAFFIC CITATIONS:
Persons who are cited for violation of one of the traffic regulatory ordinances
of this municipality may elect to pay a fine in the minor violations bureau of
the city in lieu of appearance before the municipal criminal court and such
payment shall constitute a final determination of the cause against the
defendant. The governing body of this municipality shall by resolution
prescribe a schedule of fines to be paid as set out in this section. (Ord. 285
§19, 1969)
2.24.200: RELEASE ON BAIL:
Upon arrest, or upon appearance without arrest in response to citation or
summons, or at any other time before trial, before or after arraignment, the
defendant shall be eligible to be released upon giving bail for his appearance
in an amount and upon conditions fixed by the judge, who shall prescribe
appropriate rules of court for the receipt of bail. In case of arrests made at
night or under other conditions of emergency or when the judge is not
available, the rules shall authorize the chief of police, or his designated
representative, to accept a temporary cash bond, not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than the maximum monetary penalty provided by ordinance for
such offense charged. (Ord. 285 §20, 1969)
2.24.210: ARRAIGNMENT:
Upon making an appearance before the court, the defendant shall be arraigned.
The judge, the attorney of the municipality, or the court clerk, shall read the
complaint to the defendant, inform the person of their legal rights, including
the right of trial by jury, if available, and of the consequences of
conviction, and ask the defendant whether they plead guilty or not guilty. Upon
entering a plea, the judge, the attorney of the municipality, or the court
clerk, shall take the following action:
A.   If the defendant pleads guilty, the court may proceed to judgment and
sentence or may continue the matter for subsequent disposition.
B.   If the plea is not guilty, then the court may proceed to try the case, if
the officer is present for trial, and the defendant is prepared, or may set it
for hearing at a later date if the officer is not present or the defendant is
not prepared for trial.
C.   In the event that the defendant pleads not guilty, the court shall impose
a bond in the maximum amount of the fine that the court may impose. (Ord. 919
§1, 2000)
2.24.220: MISDEMEANOR TRIAL PROCEDURE:
In all trials, as to matters not covered in this chapter, or by the statutes
relating to municipal criminal courts, or by rules duly promulgated by the
supreme court of Oklahoma, the procedures applicable in trials of misdemeanors
in the district courts shall apply to the extent. Provided, the municipal
judges may take judicial notice of all state statutes and the ordinances of the
city of Warr Acres. (Ord. 526 §4, 1982)
2.24.230: DEFENDANT TO BE PRESENT:
Unless excused by the court, the defendant must be present in person at the
trial of his cause or at any other hearing or proceeding as the court may
direct. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.240: FAILURE TO APPEAR ACCORDING TO TERMS OF BOND:
A.   If without sufficient excuse, a defendant fails to appear according to the
terms or conditions of his bond, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or
judgment, or upon any other occasion when his presence in court or before the
judge may be lawfully required, the judge may direct that fact to be entered
upon the court minutes, thereby declaring the bond to be forfeited. Court costs
shall be collectible from the proceeds of the bond.
B.   At the discretion of the judge, he may direct that such forfeiture be
certified to the district court of Oklahoma County to be entered on the
judgment docket as provided in title 11, section 27-118 of the Oklahoma
Statutes.
C.   Such failure to appear shall constitute grounds for the court to exercise
its powers of contempt where no cash bond is available to satisfy any judgment
of the court. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.250: JURY TRIALS:
In all prosecutions in the municipal court for any offense punishable by a fine
of more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), excluding court costs, or by
imprisonment, or by both such fine and imprisonment, a jury trial shall be had
unless waived by both the defendant and the city of Warr Acres. In prosecutions
for all other offenses, or the cause wherein a jury trial is waived, the trial
of the cause shall be to the court. All jury trials shall be set at the time of
arraignment. (Ord. 1020 §1, 2006: Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.260: WAIVER OF JURY TRIAL:
The jury trial waiver as provided herein shall be in writing and may be signed
at any time before trial. It shall become a part of the record and shall be
substantially as follows:
   CITY OF WARR ACRES, OKLAHOMA
   vs.      Case #      
   (name of defendant or defendants)
   WAIVER OF JURY TRIAL
I,                          , hereby acknowledge that I am the defendant in the
above styled action; that the potential penalty upon conviction for the offense
charged is a fine in excess of Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment,
or both, and I understand that I am thereby entitled to a jury trial in this
matter.
After being fully advised of the nature of the charges, the potential penalty
and my rights, I hereby voluntarily waive my rights to trial by jury reserving
all other rights to which I am entitled.
               
      DEFENDANT
The City of Warr Acres hereby waives its right to trial by jury in this cause.
               
      FOR THE CITY OF WARR ACRES
The city attorney, municipal court clerk or the municipal judge may, in their
discretion, waive a jury trial on behalf of the city. Provided, if a jury trial
is waived by the defendant at any time after jurors are requested by the judge,
any cost accrued shall be assessed against the defendant. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.270: SELECTION AND REQUEST FOR JURORS:
A.   The municipal judge shall by court rule provide for jury terms and the
scheduling of cases for jury trial.
B.   Whenever a calendar has been made up for the trial of cases by jury, the
judge of the municipal court shall timely request, in writing, the chief judge
of Oklahoma County to cause the names of a stated number of jurors, deemed
sufficient to dispose of the cases on the calendar, to be drawn from the jury
in accordance with the governing statutes of the state, and to be certified by
the clerk of the district court to the judge of the municipal court.
C.   If after statutory exceptions are allowed, the listed number is found to
be insufficient, the judge of the municipal court shall make additional
requests for qualified jurors in the same manner as herein provided.
D.   Requests for exemption or release from jury duty shall be directed to the
municipal judge and may only be granted by the judge. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.280: SUMMONS OF JURORS:
A.   Upon receipt of the jury list, the clerk of the court shall cause a
summons substantially in the following form to be issued and served upon each
person on the certified list:
   SUMMONS
      CITY OF WARR ACRES   )
         )
      STATE OF OKLAHOMA   )
      TO: (name and address of juror)
You are hereby summoned to appear in the Municipal Court of the City of Warr
Acres to be held at 5930 NW 49th Street, Warr Acres, Oklahoma on the        day
of                 , 200, at the hour of                     , to serve as a
juror in said court, and to continue in such service until discharged by the
Court. Failure to appear is a violation of the municipal ordinances punishable
by a fine not to exceed Thirty-Five Dollars ($35.00) for each day of non-
appearance.
HEREOF fail not under penalty of the law.
ISSUED under authority of said court this          day of               , 200.
                                                
         MUNICIPAL JUDGE
SERVED this          day of                 , 200  , by                        
     
B.   Service of such summons shall be as the judge may prescribe by rule or
direct by order, either in person upon the juror by the chief of police, or by
any member of the police force of the city, or by the clerk of the court
through registered or certified mail directed to the juror at the address as
shown on the jury list with a request for a personally signed returned receipt.
In any proceeding wherein service of summons by mail is an issue, evidence of
mailing of the summons and official postal return shall be prima facie evidence
that the summons was received by the juror and therefore properly served. (Ord.
965 §1, 2002)
2.24.290: DUTIES OF JURORS:
After jurors are sworn they must sit together and hear the proofs and oral
arguments of the parties, which must be delivered in public and in the presence
of the defendant. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.300: DUTIES OF THE JUDGE:
In all actions tried before a jury, the judge shall determine all questions of
law including introduction of evidence. He shall also instruct the jury as to
the law. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.310: VERDICT OF JURY:
A verdict of the jury may be rendered by the concurring vote of five (5) of the
six (6) jurors. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.320: VERDICT REQUIREMENTS:
The verdict of the jury, in all cases must be general. When the jury has
arrived at its verdict, it shall deliver the verdict publicly to the court. The
judge must enter the verdict in the docket or cause it to be so entered. (Ord.
965 §1, 2002)
2.24.330: DISCHARGE OF JURY:
Once impaneled and sworn, the jury must not be discharged until a verdict is
rendered, unless the judge, for good cause, discharges it sooner, in which
event the court may proceed again to trial and so on until a verdict is
rendered. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.340: COMPENSATION OF JURORS:
Jurors shall receive for their services the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per
day plus mileage at the rate of twenty cents ($0.20) per mile for necessary
mileage as determined by the most direct route from their residence. Claims for
their expenses shall show the method of computation of the expenses and shall
be verified as other claims against the city. Such claims may be paid out of
the general funds of the city. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.350: WITNESS FEES AND MILEAGE:
Witnesses required to testify on behalf of the city may be compensated, if
requested in writing in advance of the trial, in the sum of ten dollars
($10.00) for attendance and mileage, as for jurors. Claims shall be submitted
for payment as claims for jurors; provided, this section shall not apply to any
police officer or peace officer. (Ord. 965 §1, 2002)
2.24.360: COURT COSTS:
When a person enters a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, pays a fine, or is
convicted of a violation of any ordinance of the city, the court clerk shall
assess costs of prosecution to the defendant in a sum not to exceed thirty
dollars ($30.00) plus the fees and mileage of witnesses. Such costs shall be in
addition to any fine or other penalty which may be imposed. (Ord. 1075 §1,
2009)
2.24.370: ACQUITTAL:
If judgment of acquittal is rendered and the defendant is not to be detained
for any other legal cause, he shall be discharged at once. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.380: JUDGMENT:
A.   If, after conviction, judgment of imprisonment is entered, a copy thereof,
certified by the clerk, shall be delivered to the chief of police or other
appropriate sheriff or police officer. Such copy shall be sufficient warrant
for execution of the judgment.
B.   If a defendant, who is financially able, refuses or neglects to pay a fine
or costs or both, payment may be enforced by imprisonment until the same is
satisfied at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per day. If the defendant is
without means to pay the fine or costs, the judge may direct the total amount
to be entered on the court minutes and thereafter certified to the district
court to be entered on the judgment docket as herein authorized.
C.   All prisoners confined to jail on conviction or on plea of guilty may be
compelled, if their health permits, to work on the public streets, avenues,
alleys, parks, buildings or other public premises or property. For each day of
such work, the prisoner shall be credited five dollars ($5.00) toward any fine
or costs or witness or juror fees or mileage until same are satisfied.
D.   The chief of police, subject to the direction of the mayor, shall direct
where the work shall be performed. The head of the department in charge of the
place where the work is to be performed, himself or by some person designated
by him, shall oversee the work. If a guard is necessary, the chief of police
shall make provision therefor. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.390: SUSPENSION OF JUDGMENT:
Whenever any person shall be convicted, or upon a plea of guilty and sentence,
the judge may suspend the sentence imposed, or any part thereof, upon such
terms as the court shall direct, and subject to the provisions imposed by
section 27-123 of title 11, Oklahoma Statutes. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.400: SUPERVISION OF JUVENILES:
The judge, in addition to other duties, shall provide for the supervision of
all juveniles who are placed on probation or under suspended sentences which
the court shall pronounce. (Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.410: DEFERRAL OF SENTENCE:
Upon entering judgment against the defendant, the court may defer sentencing,
upon such terms or conditions as the judge may specify, for a period not to
exceed six (6) months. Upon such deferral, an administration fee not to exceed
one hundred dollars ($100.00) may be imposed as costs in addition to the court
costs. (Ord. 686 §2, 1989: Ord. 526 §5, 1982)
2.24.420: APPEALS:
Appeals from the municipal court shall be had in accordance with the procedure
established by state law therefor, and the municipal judge shall take care that
upon the filing of a proper appeal all necessary documents shall be timely
forwarded to the clerk of the district court of Oklahoma County. (Ord. 526 §5,
1982)
CHAPTER 2.25
JUVENILE OFFENDERS
SECTION:
2.25.010: Jurisdiction
2.25.020: Custody And Detention
2.25.030: Penalties
2.25.040: Confidentiality Of Records
2.25.050: Funds From Fines
2.25.060: Failure Of Parent/Guardian/Custodian Of Juvenile To Appear
2.25.070: Juvenile Proceedings; Privacy
2.25.080: Citation Issued To Juveniles
2.25.090: Traffic Offenses
2.25.010: JURISDICTION:
The municipal court of the city of Warr Acres may elect to exercise original
jurisdiction to hear and determine certain offenses committed by those persons
under the age of eighteen (18) years and penalize those juveniles found guilty,
all as authorized by 10 Oklahoma Statutes, section 7303-1.1. (Ord. 938 §1,
2001)
2.25.020: CUSTODY AND DETENTION:
A child under the age of eighteen (18) years who is taken into custody for the
alleged violation of a municipal ordinance relating to the following offenses:
a) vandalism; b) larceny; c) trespassing; d) assault; e) battery; f) assault
and battery; g) truancy; h) curfew violations; i) possession of nonintoxication
beverage; j) possession of alcoholic beverages; k) disorderly conduct; l)
public intoxication; m) possession of firearms; n) possession of tobacco
products; o) possession of marijuana; p) possession of drug paraphernalia, and
any other ordinances as provided in 10 Oklahoma Statutes section 7303-1.2 as
amended; may be temporarily detained by the city in a certified municipal
juvenile facility under the following conditions:
A.   The municipality shall immediately take all reasonable steps to attempt to
locate the child's parent, legal guardian, legal custodian, or attorney, and
determine if said parent, legal guardian, legal custodian, or attorney is
willing to appear at the municipal juvenile facility and assume personal
custody of the child upon the child's release from such facility.
B.   The child shall be released to the personal custody of his or her parent,
legal guardian, legal custodian, or attorney as soon as practicable, and upon
the written promise of such parent, legal guardian, legal custodian, or
attorney to return the child to municipal court to answer the municipal charges
on the date and at the time set by the municipal court.
C.   The child shall be detained in the municipal juvenile facility for no
longer than twenty four (24) hours; provided, if no parent, legal guardian,
legal custodian, or attorney appears at the municipal juvenile facility and
assumes personal custody of the child within said twenty four (24) hour period,
then custody or release of the child shall be determined pursuant to the
provisions of 10 Oklahoma Statutes, section 7303-1.1.
D.   The child shall not be held in any jail, adult lockup, or adult detention
facility unless total separation exists between juveniles and adult spatial
areas.
E.   The child shall be provided with adequate fresh drinking water.
F.   The child shall be provided with adequate food not less than three (3)
times in a twenty four (24) hour period.
G.   The child shall be provided with adequate bathroom facilities and bedding.
H.   The child shall be provided with any necessary medical care and treatment.
(Ord. 959 §1, 2002: Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.030: PENALTIES:
Pursuant to the interlocal cooperation agreement between the city and the
district court, as authorized by 10 Oklahoma Statutes, section 7303-1.1 a child
under eighteen (18) years of age may be charged, prosecuted, and if convicted,
fined for violation of a municipal ordinance relating to one or more of the
offenses listed in section
2.25.020 of this chapter; provided that the maximum fine which may be imposed
shall not exceed the maximum fine authorized by law. When assessing punishment,
the court also may require appropriate community service work, not to exceed
ninety (90) hours, in lieu of a fine if the product of multiplying the number
of hours of community service work by the prevailing minimum wage does not
result in a number which exceeds the maximum fine authorized by law, or
restitution, or both community service work and restitution. In addition, the
court may require the child to receive counseling or other community based
services, as necessary. If a child is prosecuted for an offense in the
municipal court, the child shall not be prosecuted for the offense in the
district court. The municipal court may also impose costs as authorized by law.
(Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.040: CONFIDENTIALITY OF RECORDS:
All municipal arrest records, prosecution records, court records, and court
proceedings for cases involving children under eighteen (18) years of age
charged with violating municipal ordinances relating to one or more of the
offenses listed in section
2.25.020 of this chapter shall be kept confidential and shall not be open to
public inspection except by order of the municipal court or as otherwise
provided by 10 Oklahoma Statutes sections 620.6, 7005-1.1 to 7005-1.5, 7307-1.6
and 7307-1.7. (Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.050: FUNDS FROM FINES:
Funds generated from fines paid pursuant to prosecutions under this chapter
shall be earmarked and used by the city only for the following purposes:
A.   To fund local programs which address problems of juvenile crime;
B.   To fund the costs of prosecutions authorized by this chapter;
C.   To fund the costs of detention authorized pursuant to this chapter; and
D.   To fund administrative costs related to local programs that address
problems of juvenile crime or related to the prosecution, detention, or
punishment authorized pursuant to this chapter.
Such earmarked funds shall not be used by the city for any purpose other than
purposes set forth in subsections A through D of this section. (Ord. 938 §1,
2001)
2.25.060: FAILURE OF PARENT/GUARDIAN/CUSTODIAN OF JUVENILE TO APPEAR:
It shall be an offense for the parent, legal custodian or legal guardian of a
child to fail to return a child to municipal court to answer the municipal
charges on the date and time set by the municipal court where such parent,
legal custodian, or legal guardian executes a written promise to return the
child to municipal court.
It shall be a defense to a prosecution under this section where the parent,
legal custodian, or guardian appears at the appointed court date and provides
evidence that he or she made a good faith effort to secure the juvenile's
appearance in court. (Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.070: JUVENILE PROCEEDINGS; PRIVACY:
All cases under this chapter involving juveniles shall be heard separately from
cases involving adults. The hearings shall be private, but persons having a
direct interest in the case may be admitted. Any victim, relative or legal
guardian of a victim of a juvenile criminal act shall be deemed to have a
direct interest in the case. (Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.080: CITATION ISSUED TO JUVENILES:
If a municipal citation is issued to a juvenile under this chapter, the
municipal court hearing date shall be indicated on the citation, and
notification of the citation shall be mailed by the municipal court to the
parents, guardian, legal custodian or responsible adult relative of the
juvenile. (Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
2.25.090: TRAFFIC OFFENSES:
The municipal court of the city shall retain and exercise original jurisdiction
over juveniles charged with violations of the traffic ordinance of the city,
and sections
2.25.010 through
2.25.080 of this chapter shall not apply to prosecution of juveniles for
traffic violations. (Ord. 938 §1, 2001)
CHAPTER 2.26
TRUANCY
SECTION:
2.26.010: Child To Attend School
2.26.015: Prohibited
2.26.020: Penalty
2.26.010: CHILD TO ATTEND SCHOOL:
It shall be unlawful for a parent, guardian, or other person having custody of
a child who is over the age of six (6) years and under the age of eighteen (18)
years to neglect or refuse to cause or compel such child to attend and comply
with the rules of some public, private, or other school unless other means of
education are provided for the full term the schools of the district are in
session, or the child is excused as provided in title 70 Oklahoma Statutes,
section 10-105 et seq. (Ord. 959 §1, 2002)
2.26.015: PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any child who is over the age of sixteen (16) years
and under the age of eighteen (18) years and who has not finished four (4)
years of high school work to neglect or refuse to attend and comply with the
rules of some public, private, or other school, or receive an education by
other means for the full term the schools of the district are in session unless
the child is excused from attendance by the provision of 70 Oklahoma Statutes,
section 10-105 et seq. (Ord. 959 §1, 2002)
2.26.020: PENALTY:
The penalty upon a plea of guilty, nolo contendere, or a finding of guilt shall
be a fine of no more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus court costs. (Ord.
959 §1, 2002)
CHAPTER 2.28
POLICE PENSION AND RETIREMENT FUND 1
SECTION:
2.28.010: Definitions
2.28.020: Board Of Trustees Created
2.28.030: Membership
2.28.040: Officers
2.28.050: Meetings
2.28.060: Quorum
2.28.070: Powers
2.28.080: Payroll Deduction
2.28.090: Deposit Into The System
2.28.100: State Statutes
 
Notes
1 1. 11 OS ch. 13A.
2.28.010: DEFINITIONS:
FUND: The Oklahoma police pension and retirement fund.
LOCAL BOARD: The city of Warr Acres police pension and retirement board.
MEMBER: All eligible officers of the city of Warr Acres.
OFFICER: Any duly appointed and sworn full time officer of the regular police
department of the city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, whose duties are to preserve
the public peace, protect life and property, prevent crime, serve warrants,
enforce all laws and municipal ordinances of this city and who is authorized to
bear arms in the execution of such duties.
STATE BOARD: The Oklahoma police pension and retirement board.
SYSTEM: The Oklahoma police pension and retirement board. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.020: BOARD OF TRUSTEES CREATED:
There is hereby created a local board of trustees which shall have the
operation and management of the police pension and retirement system of the
city, which board of trustees shall consist of the city clerk-treasurer and
three (3) members of the police department of the city, which is designated and
known as the local board of trustees of the city police pension and retirement
system. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.030: MEMBERSHIP:
Within thirty (30) days after the passage of the ordinance codified in this
chapter, the members participating in the system either active or retired from
the police department of the city shall elect by ballot three (3) participating
officers of such police department, one of whom shall serve for the term of one
year, one of whom shall serve for the term of two (2) years, and one for the
term of three (3) years; thereafter members participating in the system either
active on or retired from the police department shall, every year, elect by
ballot one of its members to serve for the term of three (3) years upon the
local board, provided, if the positions of clerk and treasurer are held by one
person, that person shall be allowed only one local board position and one vote
on any matter before the local board. If a vacancy occurs on the local board,
the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the
office was previously filled. The ballots shall be placed in a ballot box to be
provided by the city and so conducted that each elector's ballot shall be
secret as in the election for city offices. The city clerk shall conduct the
election by seeing that each and every person so voting is a member
participating in the system, and shall canvass all ballots so voted and shall
certify the results thereof to the mayor. The person receiving the highest
number of votes shall be elected. Each member of the local board of trustees so
elected shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office, take and
subscribe an oath of office according to law. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.040: OFFICERS:
On the second Monday of the month, after the election of the local board of
trustees, the local board shall meet at a place designated by the city clerk
and shall choose and elect a chairman and a secretary from the members of the
local board who shall serve for a term of one year or until their successors
are elected. The city clerk shall act as the treasurer of the board of trustees
and serve the local board as provided in this chapter. One year from the date
of the first organizational meeting, and each year thereafter, the local board
shall elect a chairman and secretary from its members. In the event any
chairman or secretary ceases to be a member of the local board the local board
shall elect from its members a chairman or secretary to serve the unexpired
term of the respective member whose membership on the local board is
terminated. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.050: MEETINGS:
The local board shall hold monthly meetings on the second Monday of each and
every month of each year and upon call of its chairman at such other times as
the chairman deems necessary. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.060: QUORUM:
A majority of all the members of the local board shall constitute a quorum and
have the power to transact business. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.070: POWERS:
The local board of trustees shall, in addition to other powers granted in this
chapter, have power to:
A.   Compel witnesses to attend and testify before the local board upon all
matters connected with the operations of this chapter and in the same manner as
is, or may be, provided by law, for the taking of testimony before notaries
public, and its chairman or any member of the local board may administer oaths
of such witnesses;
B.   Provide all rules and regulations needful for its guidance and operation
and shall have the power to amend said rules and regulations as the local board
may determine from time to time;
C.   Review applications for the following:
   1.   Membership in the system,
   2.   Refund of accumulated contributions to members terminating employment,
   3.   Retirement benefits,
   4.   Disability benefits and examinations to determine continuation of
disability benefits,
   5.   Shall recommend approval, disapproval or modification of each
application and the secretary shall forward such recommendations to the state
board within ten (10) days following the local board's decision. Consideration
by the local board shall be pursuant to the rules and regulations of the state
board. The state board shall furnish all required forms. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.080: PAYROLL DEDUCTION:
Commencing on January 1, 1983, the city treasurer shall deduct, each pay
period, from the salary or wages of each paid eligible member of the police
department an amount equal to eight percent (8%) of the total base salary or
wages paid to the eligible members of the police department. The amount so
deducted shall be deposited within ten (10) days following the payroll period
on which the contributions are based, by the city treasurer, into the Oklahoma
police pension and retirement system, state of Oklahoma. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.090: DEPOSIT INTO THE SYSTEM:
Commencing on January 1, 1983, the city treasurer shall deposit, within ten
(10) days following the payroll period on which the contributions are based,
from the general fund of the city into the Oklahoma police pension and
retirement system, state of Oklahoma, an amount which shall be equal to eight
percent (8%) of the total base salaries or wages paid to eligible members of
the police department; and commencing on January 1, 1984, the city treasurer
shall deposit, within ten (10) days following the payroll period on which the
city's contributions are based, from the general fund of the city into the
Oklahoma police pension and retirement system, state of Oklahoma, an amount
which shall be equal to ten percent (10%) of the total base salaries or wages
paid to eligible members of the police department. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
2.28.100: STATE STATUTES:
Provisions of title 11, section 50 of the Oklahoma state statutes, as amended
from time to time, not specified in the chapter are hereby incorporated by
reference. (Ord. 584 §1, 1984)
CHAPTER 2.32
FIREFIGHTERS' RELIEF AND PENSION FUND 1

2.32.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the words set out in this section shall have
the following meanings:
FUND: The Oklahoma firefighters' pension and retirement fund.
LOCAL BOARD: The city firefighters' pension and retirement board.
MEMBER: All eligible firefighters of the city.
STATE BOARD: The Oklahoma firefighters' pension and retirement board, state of
Oklahoma.
SYSTEM: The Oklahoma firefighters' pension and retirement system. (Ord. 590 §1,
1984)
2.32.020: BOARD OF TRUSTEES CREATED:
There is created a local board of trustees which shall have the operation and
management of the firemen's pension and retirement system of the city, which
board of trustees shall consist of the mayor, the city clerk-treasurer and
three (3) members of the fire department of the city, which is designated and
known as the local board of trustees of the city of Warr Acres firefighters'
pension and retirement system. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.030: MEMBERSHIP:
The fire department of the city shall elect, by ballot, three (3) members of
such fire department, one of whom shall serve for the term of one year, one of
whom shall serve for the term of two (2) years, and one for the term of three
(3) years; thereafter such fire department shall, every year, elect by ballot
one of its members to serve for the term of three (3) years upon the local
board; provided, if the positions of clerk and treasurer are held by one
person, that person shall be allowed only one local board position and one vote
on any matter before the local board. If a vacancy occurs on the local board,
the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the
office was previously filled. The ballots shall be placed in a ballot box to be
provided by the city and so conducted that each elector's ballot shall be
secret as in the election for city offices. The city clerk shall conduct the
election by seeing that each and every person so voting is a member
participating in the system, and shall canvass all ballots so voted and shall
certify the results thereof to the mayor. The person receiving the highest
number of votes shall be elected. Each member of the local board of trustees so
elected shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office, take and
subscribe an oath of office according to law. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.040: OFFICERS:
The mayor shall be an ex officio member and chairman of the local board, the
city clerk-treasurer shall be ex officio secretary-treasurer of the local
board. The mayor shall have a casting vote with the members only when necessary
to avoid a tie vote among them. On the second Monday of the month, after the
election of the local board of trustees, the local board shall meet at a place
designated by the city clerk and shall choose and elect a vice chairman from
the members of the local board who serve for a term of one year or until their
successors are elected and promulgate such other rules and offices as may be
necessary to ensure the orderly conduct of business. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.050: MEETINGS:
The local board shall hold monthly meetings on the first Monday of each and
every month of each year and upon call of its chairman at such other times as
the chairman deems necessary. The local board shall keep a record of its
proceedings, which record shall be public record. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.060: QUORUM:
A majority of all the regular voting members of the local board shall
constitute a quorum and have the power to transact business. (Ord. 590 §1,
1984)
2.32.070: POWERS:
The local board of trustees shall, in addition to other powers granted in this
chapter, have power to:
A.   Compel witnesses to attend and testify before the local board upon all
matters connected with the operations of this chapter and in the same manner as
is, or may be, provided by law, for the taking of testimony before notaries
public, and its chairman or any member of the local board may administer oaths
of such witnesses;
B.   Provide all rules and regulations needful for its guidance and operation
and shall have the power to amend said rules and regulations as the local board
may determine from time to time;
C.   Review applications for the following:
   1.   Membership in the system,
   2.   Refund of accumulated contributions to members terminating employment,
   3.   Retirement benefits,
   4.   Disability benefits and examinations to determine continuation of
disability benefits,
   5.   Shall recommend approval, disapproval or modification of each
application and the secretary shall forward such recommendations to the state
board within ten (10) days following the local board's decision. Consideration
by the local board shall be pursuant to the rules and regulations of the state
board. The state board shall furnish all required forms. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.080: PAYROLL DEDUCTION:
Commencing on January 1, 1983, the city treasurer shall deduct, each pay
period, from the salary or wages of each paid and eligible member of the fire
department an amount equal to eight percent (8%) of the total base salary or
wages paid to the members of the fire department. The amount so deducted shall
be deposited each month by the city treasurer into the Oklahoma firefighters'
pension and retirement fund, state of Oklahoma. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
2.32.090: DEPOSIT INTO THE SYSTEM:
The city treasurer shall deposit monthly from the general fund into the
Oklahoma firefighters' pension and retirement fund an amount equal to a
percentage of the total actual paid gross salaries of the members of the fire
department in accordance with the following schedule:
A.   July 1, 1992 through June 30, 1993: Eleven percent (11%),
B.   July 1, 1993 through June 30, 1994: Eleven and one-half percent (111/2%),
C.   July 1, 1994 through June 30, 1995: Twelve percent (12%),
D.   July 1, 1995 through June 30, 1996: Twelve and one-half percent (121/2%),
and
E.   July 1, 1996 through June 30, 1997: Thirteen percent (13%)
or in such amount as the Oklahoma legislature may direct by amendment to the
laws governing the firefighters' pension and retirement system. (Ord. 734 §1,
1992)
2.32.100: STATE STATUTES:
Provisions of title 11, section 49 of the Oklahoma state statutes, as amended
from time to time, not specified in this chapter, are hereby incorporated by
reference. (Ord. 590 §1, 1984)
