2.36.010: POWER TO HIRE OR REPLACE EMPLOYEES:
The mayor, in coordination with the heads of the departments of the city, is
empowered to hire and/or replace employees of the city, except for all
directors or heads of administrative departments, and all other administrative
officers and employees of the city. (See also charter section 3-1.) (Ord. 685
§1, 1989)
2.36.011: EMPLOYEE HANDBOOK OF PERSONNEL POLICIES AUTHORIZATION:
There is authorized an employee handbook of personnel policies which shall
provide for personnel policies, rules and regulations including employee
benefits applicable to all employees not otherwise represented by a labor
representative or provided by other employment agreements.
The handbook shall be prepared by the mayor and submitted to the council for
approval. Once approved by the council the provisions thereof shall be the
official policies of Warr Acres regulating employee relations between the city
and its covered employees.
The handbook may be updated, modified or changed to meet changing and current
conditions, provided such change or modification shall not become effective
until and after the same has been approved by the council pursuant to a duly
adopted resolution.
All rights, duties, obligations or benefits accrued, established, or vested
prior to the effective date of the employee handbook of personnel policies
shall not be affected by its adoption or approval. (Ord. 720 §1, 1992)
2.36.012: THE EMPLOYEE HANDBOOK OF PERSONNEL POLICIES:
Insert pages 2-1 through 2-33 sections 100 through 600, and appendix A,
complaint form; appendix B, supervisory bypass procedures; appendix C, alcohol
and controlled substance testing policy and procedures; appendix D, nepotism;
appendix E, family and medical leave act (FMLA) policy. (Ord. 927 §1, 2001)
2.36.015: OVERTIME FOR HOLIDAYS:
By amending section 500, subsection 502 overtime, by adding B-4. Any
noncontract employee who is required to work on an authorized holiday will be
paid the eight (8) hours for the authorized holiday, and will be paid for
actual time worked and will be paid a minimum of three (3) hours regardless of
time worked. (Ord. 946 §1, 2001)
2.36.020: SALARY INCREASES:
(Rep. by Ord. 974 §1, 2002)
2.36.025: PAY SCALE AND MERIT SYSTEM FOR EXEMPT AND NONEXEMPT, NONUNIFORM
EMPLOYEES:
The city council shall, from time to time, establish by resolution the rates of
compensation for all city employees not covered by a collective bargaining
agreement. The rates of compensation for employees covered by a collective
bargaining agreement shall be established by the terms of the collective
bargaining agreement and, in the absence of such an agreement, the compensation
shall be established by the council. The rates of compensation for nonexempt
employees who are not covered by the terms of a collective bargaining agreement
shall be established by a pay scale adopted by the council unless otherwise
stated. The rates of compensation for exempt employees shall be established by
the council. The council shall, from time to time, review the pay scale and
make adjustments thereto as it deems appropriate. (Ord. 1130, 2012)
2.36.040: EXEMPT AND NONEXEMPT, NONUNIFORM EMPLOYEES MERIT SYSTEM:
The city council will establish a merit system for employees related to
increases in compensation for employees. Employees who have not yet reached or
exceeded the maximum compensation established for their position shall be
eligible for a merit increase on their anniversary provided they receive a
satisfactory evaluation. Other adjustments to base compensation or additional
compensation may be provided to an employee based on that employee meeting
objective criteria established for and applicable to all employees within a
particular classification. Such criteria may either be in the form of a hiring
incentive or an incentive for an employee to receive certifications not
regularly required or expected for their current position. The criteria will be
established in advance by the council. (Ord. 1130, 2012)
2.36.100: POLICE DEPARTMENT UNIFORMS AND MAINTENANCE ALLOWANCE:
Employees of the police department shall wear uniforms, as may be required and
approved by the police chief, and shall be provided by the city at no cost to
the employee. Uniforms and related items are to be provided based on the needs
of the individual employee for conformance to departmental policy as to form,
function, color, style, quantity and fit as established by the police chief.
Commencing upon the issuance of uniforms, the city will provide the following
employees with a uniform maintenance allowance payable twice a year as set
forth:
A.   The police chief and deputy chief shall receive an annual uniform
allowance payable on the anniversary date of employment not to exceed three
hundred dollars ($300.00). Receipts for approved purchases must be presented
before payment will be made. In addition, the police chief and his deputy shall
receive a uniform allowance of forty dollars ($40.00) per month for which no
receipts shall be required.
B.   In the event an employee is on leave from active duty for one workweek or
more in a one month period, the uniform allowance will be prorated, provided
this subsection shall not apply in instances of vacation or holiday leave of
less than two (2) workweeks. (Ord. 930 §1, 2001: Ord. 869 §1, 1998: Ord. 724
§1, 1992)
2.36.120: FIRE DEPARTMENT UNIFORMS AND MAINTENANCE ALLOWANCE:
All employees of the fire department, except those employees represented by a
bargaining agent, shall be issued uniforms and uniform items governed by a
quartermaster system. The quartermaster system shall be under the direct
control of the fire chief and mayor as to the style, type, and apportionment of
uniforms and uniform items. Employees covered hereby shall receive a uniform
maintenance allowance of thirty five dollars ($35.00) per month payable in the
months of July and January of each fiscal year. No receipts shall be required.
(Ord. 723 §1, 1992: Ord. 685 §1, 1989)
2.36.130: BENEFITS:
Benefits shall not be assignable or transferable and are not subject to
garnishment or levy of any kind. Any attempted transfer or pledge of benefits
shall mean that the city will terminate payment of benefits. (Ord. 685 §1,
1989)
2.36.140: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYEE:
An employee may be terminated as freely as if the employee benefits plan were
not in operation. (Ord. 685 §1, 1989)
2.36.150: SUSPEND OR CHANGE BENEFITS PLAN:
The city reserves the right to suspend or change the benefits plan. The city
will notify employees of any suspension or change as soon as practicable. (Ord.
685 §1, 1989)
2.36.220: EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM; CREATED; ADOPTED:
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the city charter, as amended, and by the
laws of the state, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and
meritorious service on the part of city employees and thereby promote public
efficiency, there is authorized, created, established, approved and adopted,
effective as of November 1, 1973, the funded pension plan designated the
"employee retirement system of Warr Acres, Oklahoma", hereinafter called the
"system", an executed counterpart of which is marked exhibit A, amended by
document 83-1 and document 92-1, and attached to the ordinance codified in this
section and sections
2.36.230 through
2.36.260 of this chapter as a part hereof. (Ord. 735 §1, 1992: Ord. 583 §1,
1984)
2.36.230: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE SYSTEM:
For the purpose of administration of the system adopted in section
2.36.220 of this chapter, there is established a board of trustees, which shall
be the members of the city council as now existing or as from time to time duly
elected or appointed and constituted. The powers and duties of the board of
trustees shall be as set forth in the system instrument attached to the
ordinance codified herein as exhibit A as amended by document 83-1. (Ord. 583
§3, 1984)
2.36.240: FUND FOR THE SYSTEM; POOLING PROCEDURE:
A fund is provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons entitled to
benefits under the system adopted in section 2.36.210 of this chapter. All
contributions to such fund shall be paid over to and received in trust for such
purpose by the city treasurer, who shall be the treasurer of the system. Such
fund shall be pooled for purposes of management and investment with similar
funds of other incorporated cities, towns and municipal trusts in the state as
a part of the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund, in accordance with a duly
executed contract for such purpose, which contract shall be executed by the
city council as soon as feasible. The city treasurer shall hold such
contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay over and transfer
the same to the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund, as duly authorized and
directed by the board of trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal and shall not be
considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is made to the county
excise board. The fund and system shall be valued every other year for
actuarial soundness by a qualified actuarial firm. (Ord. 362 §3, 1973)
2.36.250: APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SYSTEM; TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
The city is authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the establishment,
operation and administration of the system adopted in section
2.36.220 of this chapter and to appropriate and pay the same. In addition, the
city is authorized to appropriate annually such amounts as are required in
addition to employee contributions, to maintain the system and the fund on a
sound actuarial basis in accordance with the respective annual actuarial
valuation. Any appropriation so made to maintain the system and fund shall be
for deferred wages or salaries and for the payment of necessary expenses of
operation and administration, including separate annual appropriations to be
transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund for such
purposes, and shall be paid into the fund when available, through the city
treasurer, to be duly transferred by him to the Oklahoma municipal retirement
fund. (Ord. 362 §4, 1973)
2.36.260: EXECUTION OF SYSTEM INSTRUMENT; POOLING OF FUND:
A.   The mayor and city clerk are each authorized and directed to execute (in
counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original) the system
instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary, advisable and proper
to put the system adopted in section 2.36.220 of this chapter and related trust
into full force and effect, and to make such changes therein as may be
necessary to qualify the same under sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the internal
revenue code of the United States. The counterpart attached to the ordinance
codified herein as exhibit A, as amended by document 83-1, which has been duly
executed as set out in this section simultaneously with the passage of the
ordinance codified in this section and sections
2.36.220 through
2.36.250 of this chapter and made a part thereof, is ratified and confirmed in
all respects.
B.   The city council is authorized and directed to proceed immediately on
behalf of the city to negotiate a contract with other incorporated cities and
towns of the state to pool and combine the fund into the Oklahoma municipal
retirement fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of such other cities and
towns, for purposes of pooled management, and investment. The city council
shall manifest approval of such contract and the execution thereof by the mayor
and city clerk, by a formal resolution. (Ord. 583 §5, 1984: Ord. 362 §5, 1973)
2.36.265: SPECIAL RETIREMENT OPTION:
A participant whose integral age and integral years of credited service total
seventy five (75), or more, may elect to retire, and the early retirement
reduction described in article V, paragraph 5.2 of the plan shall not apply.
The election must be made prior to November 1, 1995, and the employee's
retirement date shall not be later than January 2, 1996. (Ord. 771 §1, 1995)
2.36.270: DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN:
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the state of Oklahoma, and
for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part
of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby
authorized created, established, and approved and adopted, effective as of
January 1, 2010, the amended and restated plan designated "employee retirement
system of the city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, defined contribution plan"
(hereinafter called system), an executed counterpart of which is marked exhibit
A (joinder agreement) and exhibit B (amended and restated plan) and attached to
the ordinance codified in this section and sections
2.36.272 through
2.36.274 of this chapter as a part hereof. (Ord. 1078 §1, 2009)
2.36.271: ADMINISTRATION OF THE PENSION PLAN:
For the purposes of administration, the board of trustees created by section
2.36.230 of this chapter shall exercise the powers and sections as are set out
in exhibit A regulating the defined contribution plan. (Ord. 698 §1, 1990)
2.36.272: FUND FOR THE DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN:
A fund is hereby provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons
entitled to benefits under the system. All contributions to such fund shall be
paid over to and received in trust for such purpose by the city. Such fund
shall be pooled for purposes of management and investment with similar funds of
other incorporated cities, towns, and municipal trusts in the state of Oklahoma
as a part of the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund in accordance with the
trust agreement of the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund, a public trust. The
city shall hold such contributions in the form received, and from time to time
pay over and transfer the same to the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund, as
duly authorized and directed by the board of trustees. The fund shall be
nonfiscal and shall not be considered in computing any levy when the annual
estimate is made to the county excise board. (Ord. 1078 §2, 2009)
2.36.273: APPROPRIATIONS OF THE DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN:
The city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, is hereby authorized to incur the necessary
expenses for the establishment, operation, and administration of the system,
and to appropriate and pay the same. In addition, the city of Warr Acres,
Oklahoma, is hereby authorized to appropriate annually such amounts as are
required in addition to employee contributions to maintain the system and the
fund in accordance with the provisions of the defined contribution plan. Any
appropriation so made to maintain the system and fund shall be for deferred
wages or salaries, and for the payment of necessary expenses of operation and
administration to be transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma municipal
retirement fund for such purposes and shall be paid into the fund when
available, to be duly transferred to the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund.
(Ord. 1078 §3, 2009)
2.36.274: EXECUTION OF THE DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN:
A.   The mayor and city clerk be and they are each hereby authorized and
directed to execute (in counterparts, each of which shall constitute an
original) the system instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary,
advisable, and proper to put said system adopted in section
2.36.220 of this chapter and related trust into full force and effect, and to
make such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the same under
sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the internal revenue code of the United States.
The counterpart attached hereto as exhibit A and exhibit B, which has been duly
executed as aforesaid simultaneously with the passage of the ordinance codified
in this section and sections
2.36.270,
2.36.272 and
2.36.273 of this chapter and made a part hereof, is hereby ratified and
confirmed in all respects.
B.   The city council is hereby authorized and directed to proceed immediately
on behalf of the city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, to pool and combine the fund
into the Oklahoma municipal retirement fund as a part thereof, with similar
funds of such other cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and
investment. (Ord. 1078 §4, 2009)
2.36.276: ASSUMPTION AND RATE TABLES:
The retirement system defined benefit plan of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, is amended
by adopting revised appendix I to its retirement plan containing the actuarial
factors needed to determine actuarially equivalent options under the plan, same
being exhibit B attached to the ordinance codified herein and incorporated
herein by reference. The actuarial assumptions for the retirement plan of Warr
Acres, Oklahoma, effective on July 1, 1991, as follows are approved and shall
be used in computing contribution rates and benefits under the plan:
 
Interest rate           7.5 percent
Disability rate         OASBI incident rate
Mortality table         1983 group annuity
Salary scale            5 percent per year
Disabled mortality rate Social security administration table
 
(Ord. 708 §1, 1991)
CHAPTER 2.37
MAYOR
SECTION:
2.37.010: Salary
2.37.020: Waiver Of Salary
2.37.030: Report Of New And Pending Litigation

2.37.010: SALARY:
The Mayor of the City of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, shall be paid an amended salary
of fifteen thousand eighty dollars ($15,080.00), payable at the rate of one
thousand two hundred fifty six dollars sixty seven cents ($1,256.67) per month.
The salary provided shall be in addition to any allocated expenses authorized
by the Council. (Ord. 1172, 2016)
2.37.020: WAIVER OF SALARY:
The Mayor shall have the option to exercise a waiver of any or all of the
salary provided for in section
2.37.010 of this chapter by executing a written waiver. Upon execution of the
waiver of a salary by the Mayor, the funds allocated for said salary shall be
reallocated to the City's General Fund. (Ord. 611 §1, 1985)
2.37.030: REPORT OF NEW AND PENDING LITIGATION:
The Mayor shall provide the Council a report of all new litigation filed
against the City as it arises. The report shall include: parties to the action;
date filed; nature of the action; nature of remedy or remedies sought;
significant hearing dates; attorney(s) acting on behalf of the City; and
information concerning the results of the litigation completed or settlements
reached, if available and disclosure not prohibited by the terms of the
settlement. (Ord. 784 §1, 1996)
2.37.040: ANNUAL BUDGET:
The Mayor shall furnish the Council with a proposed annual budget, as required
by article 3, section 3-1 of the Charter, which reconciles with the financial
statement and estimate of needs filed annually with the County Excise Board,
pursuant to 68 Oklahoma Statutes section 3002. (Ord. 853-A §1, 1998)
CHAPTER 2.40

2.40.010: PURPOSE; POLICY:
It is declared to be the policy of the city to extend, at the earliest date, to
the employees and officials thereof not excluded by law or this chapter, and
whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the
benefits of the system of federal old age and survivors' insurance, as
authorized by the federal social security act and amendments thereto, including
public law 734 of the 81st congress. In pursuance of said policy, and for that
purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state
or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code §1-2)
2.40.020: EXECUTION OF AGREEMENTS AND AMENDMENTS:
The mayor is authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and
amendments thereto with the state department of public welfare, as agent or
agency, to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided in section
2.40.010 of this chapter. (Prior code §1-3)
2.40.030: WITHHOLDINGS:
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose
provided in section
2.40.010 of this chapter are authorized to be made in the amounts and at such
times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations,
and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by said laws
or regulations. (Prior code §1-4)
2.40.040: EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS:
There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as
may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer
contributions, which shall be paid over to the state or federal agency
designated by said laws or regulations. (Prior code §1-5)
2.40.050: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by
applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code §1-6)
2.40.060: OTHER RETIREMENT SYSTEMS:
There is excluded from this chapter any authority to make any agreement with
respect to any position or any employee or official now covered or authorized
to be covered by any other ordinance creating any retirement system for any
employee or official of the city. (Prior code §1-7)
2.40.070: COMPENSATION ON FEE BASIS:
There is excluded from this chapter any authority to make any agreement with
respect to any position, or any employee or official, compensation for which is
on a fee basis, or any position, or any employee or official not authorized to
be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Prior code §1-
8)
CHAPTER 2.44
LOST OR UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 1
SECTION:
2.44.010: Property Delivered To
2.44.020: Record Of And Disposition Of Property Received
2.44.030: Public Auction
2.44.035: Destruction And Disposal Of Guns
2.44.040: Rightful Owner
 
Notes
1 1. 60 OS ch. 13, § 657.
2.44.010: PROPERTY DELIVERED TO:
When any policeman or officer comes into possession of any property, supposedly
lost, unclaimed or stolen, or takes any property off of or from any criminal or
person believed to be a criminal, he shall forthwith deliver the property to
the chief of police. (Prior code §11-10)
2.44.020: RECORD OF AND DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY RECEIVED:
The chief of police shall maintain a complete record of all such property
received, showing the date it was received, a description of the article, and
the source from which it was received. When any person, to the satisfaction of
the chief of police, presents proof of ownership thereof, and after the
termination of any pending legal proceedings, the chief of police will return
the article to the owner upon the payment of all reasonable and necessary
expenses incurred in its preservation, to be certified by the chief of police,
who shall take a receipt therefor and shall enter into the record the name of
the person to whom it was delivered, the date of such delivery and any funds
received. Any property not claimed within sixty (60) days from the date of the
receipt of same shall be sold or otherwise disposed of as set forth in this
chapter. (Prior code §11-11)
2.44.030: PUBLIC AUCTION:
Any property, other than animals, firearms, intoxicants and weapons of any kind
remaining in possession of the chief of police for sixty (60) days unclaimed,
shall be sold at public auction, and the proceeds thereof shall be paid to the
city treasurer. A minimum of ten (10) days before the sale of the property, the
chief of police shall post notice of sale and auction in four (4) public places
in the city, one of which shall be the police station, showing a description of
the property to be sold, and the date and place of the sale and auction. Upon
the sale of the property, the chief of police shall enter into the records the
name and address of the person purchasing the property, and the amount paid
therefor. (Prior code §11-12)
2.44.035: DESTRUCTION AND DISPOSAL OF GUNS:
A.   When the chief of police determines that guns which have been confiscated
by his department and are no longer needed for evidence in any criminal
complaint, and he is of the opinion that the guns have no commercial value, and
are sometimes known as Saturday night specials, and in addition in his opinion
the guns should be destroyed, he shall take the following action: He shall
prepare a list describing each gun by manufacturer, model and serial number if
known, previous owner, or the person from whom the gun was obtained.
B.   The chief of police shall notify the owner or person from whom the gun was
obtained at their last known address, first class mail, postage prepaid, twenty
(20) days prior to submitting that list to the city council for their
permission to destroy said guns. At the time of submitting the list the chief
of police shall give details as to the proposed supervised destruction.
C.   After supervised destruction of said guns, the chief of police shall
advise the administration in writing as to the date and method of destruction
and disposal of the scrap gun material. (Ord. 1107, 2011)
2.44.040: RIGHTFUL OWNER:
If the rightful owner of the property recovers the same from the purchaser, the
purchaser shall have the money paid therefor returned to him upon presentation
of a claim duly audited and approved by the city council. (Prior code §11-13)
CHAPTER 2.48
CIVIL DEFENSE 1
SECTION:
2.48.010: Title
2.48.020: Definitions
2.48.030: Office Of Civil Defense Established
2.48.040: Office Space And Equipment
2.48.050: Powers And Duties Of The Director
2.48.060: Enemy Caused Emergencies
2.48.070: Natural Emergency
2.48.080: Liability For Death Or Injury
2.48.090: Contributions
2.48.100: Penalty For Violations
 
Notes
1 1.  63 OS §§ 683.1 et seq., 683.11 et seq.
2.48.010: TITLE:
This chapter is to be known as the CIVIL DEFENSE CODE of the city. (Prior code
§1-58)
2.48.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall be construed as follows,
unless a contrary intent appears clear from the context:
CIVIL DEFENSE: The preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency
functions other than functions for which primary responsibility is assigned
elsewhere by federal, state or local law or ordinance, to protect the public
peace, health and safety, and to preserve lives and property in the city during
any emergency resulting from enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, or
from any flood, drought, fire, hurricane, earthquake, storm or other
catastrophe in or near the city and involving imminent or actual peril to life
and property. These functions include administration, organization, planning,
recruiting, training, education, information, welfare service, relief service,
police service, warden service, fire service, rescue service, medical service,
health service, transportation service, communications service, streets and
sewers service, utilities service, general engineering service, plant
protection service, supply service, mutual aid, mobile support, evacuation, and
all other functions necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying
out of the foregoing functions.
ENEMY CAUSED EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by actual or impending
attack, sabotage or other hostile action anywhere within the United States, and
involving imminent peril to lives and property in or near the city. Such
emergency shall be deemed to exist only when the mayor so declares by public
proclamation. Such emergency shall be deemed to continue to exist until the
mayor declares its termination by public proclamation, or until the governing
body declares its termination by resolution.
NATURAL EMERGENCY: Any state of emergency caused by any actual or impending
flood, drought, fire, hurricane, earthquake, storm or other catastrophe in or
near the city, and involving imminent peril to lives and/or property. Such
emergency shall be deemed to exist and to be terminated under the same
conditions as prescribed for an enemy caused emergency. (Prior code §1-59)
2.48.030: OFFICE OF CIVIL DEFENSE ESTABLISHED:
There is established within the executive branch of the city government the
Warr Acres office of civil defense. This office shall consist of:
A.   A civil defense advisory committee, consisting of the mayor as chairman
and of five (5) other members appointed by the mayor and serving at his
pleasure or until the repeal of this chapter. The committee shall elect from
among its members a vice chairman and a secretary. Except as otherwise provided
in this chapter, the committee shall function in an advisory capacity on all
matters pertaining to civil defense. It shall hold regular meetings at least
four (4) times a year, and at other times on the call of the mayor. The
committee shall serve without compensation;
B.   A director of civil defense, who shall be appointed by the mayor and who
shall serve at the mayor's pleasure or until the repeal of this chapter. The
director shall be the executive head of the office of civil defense, and shall
be responsible to the mayor for carrying out the civil defense program of the
city. He shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for actual
expenses in the conduct of his duties. He shall coordinate the activities of
all organizations for civil defense within the city and shall maintain liaison
with and cooperate with civil defense agencies and organizations of other
governmental units both within and without the state and of the federal
government, and shall have such additional authority, duties and
responsibilities as may be authorized under this chapter or amendments hereto;
C.   Such other volunteer civil defense advisory committees as may be created
by the director for the evaluation of technical, professional or other phases
of the work of the office of civil defense and which may provide advisory
assistance on any matters pertaining thereto. (Prior code §1-60)
2.48.040: OFFICE SPACE AND EQUIPMENT:
Appropriate office space, furniture, equipment and supplies as required shall
be provided for the office of civil defense. Expenditures for these purposes,
within the appropriations therefor, shall be made only on the authority of the
mayor and city council. The director shall also, within the appropriations
therefor, establish a primary and one or more secondary control centers, as he
deems necessary, to serve during an enemy caused or a natural emergency. (Prior
code §1-61)
2.48.050: POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR:
The director shall have general direction and control of the office of civil
defense, and shall be responsible for carrying out the provisions of this
chapter. In so doing the director is expressly authorized to:
A.   Utilize the services, skills, and technical knowledge of all city
officials and employees, and to cooperate, insofar as permitted by other
appropriate legislation, with the federal government, the state and its
subdivisions, with other states and their subdivisions, and with private
agencies, in all matters pertaining to civil defense;
B.   Make, amend and rescind the necessary orders, rules and regulations to
carry out the provisions of this chapter within the limits of the authority
conferred upon him in this chapter, with due consideration to be given to the
plans and powers of the federal government, the government of Oklahoma, and
other public and private agencies and organizations empowered to act in either
enemy caused emergencies or natural emergencies, or both;
C.   Prepare comprehensive plans for the civil defense of the city in both
enemy caused and natural emergencies, such plans and programs to be integrated
and coordinated with the plans and programs of the federal government, of the
government of Oklahoma, and of other public and private agencies and
organizations empowered to act in either enemy caused or natural emergencies or
both;
D.   Establish, within the limits of funds available, a public warning system,
composed of sirens, horns, or other acceptable warning devices;
E.   Establish and carry out recruitment and training programs as may be
necessary to develop an adequate, qualified civil defense volunteer corps;
F.   Conduct drills, exercises and similar programs as may be necessary to
develop a well trained, alert, fully prepared civil defense organization;
G.   Make such studies and surveys of the industries, resources and facilities
of this city as he deems necessary to ascertain its capabilities for civil
defense, and plan for the most efficient emergency use therefor;
H.   On behalf of the city, enter into mutual aid arrangements with surrounding
communities, both in the states of Oklahoma and of Texas, subject to the
approval of the city council;
I.   Delegate any administrative authority vested in him under this chapter,
and provide for the subdelegation of any such authority;
J.   Take any other action proper and lawful under his authority to prepare for
either an enemy caused or a natural emergency. (Prior code §1-62)
2.48.060: ENEMY CAUSED EMERGENCIES:
In the event of any actual enemy caused emergency, as proclaimed by the mayor,
the director of civil defense, with the approval of the mayor, may exercise
during such emergency the power to enforce all rules and regulations relating
to civil defense, and acting under the authority of statutes when enacted, or
under the authority of the mayor as an agent of the governor of Oklahoma, may
take control of all means of transportation and communications, all stocks of
fuel, food, clothing, medicine and supplies, and all facilities including
buildings and plants, and exercise all powers necessary to secure the safety
and protection of the civilian population. In exercising such powers, he shall
be guided by regulations and orders issued by the federal government and the
governor of Oklahoma relating to civil defense and shall take no action
contrary to orders which may be issued by the governor under similar emergency
powers. (Prior code §1-63)
2.48.070: NATURAL EMERGENCY:
In the event of any natural emergency as proclaimed by the mayor, the director
of civil defense, with the approval of the mayor and acting under his
instructions, shall coordinate in every way the proper activities of the civil
defense organization. He is specifically charged in such emergency with the
collection, evaluation and dissemination of information to all agencies, both
public and private, participating in the city's civil defense organization or
cooperating in any such emergency. He shall, as director, have the power to
recommend appropriate action, but he shall not otherwise have control over the
participating agencies. He shall also recommend to the mayor the allocation of
any funds received from the federal or state governments or from any other
source to alleviate distress and aid in restoring normal conditions. (Prior
code §1-64)
2.48.080: LIABILITY FOR DEATH OR INJURY:
Neither the city nor any officer or member of the civil defense organization
provided for in this chapter shall be liable for personal injury or property
damage sustained by any person appointed or acting as a volunteer civil defense
worker or member of any agency engaged in civil defense activity prior to or
during either an enemy caused or a natural emergency; or shall the city or any
such officer or member be liable for the death or injury of any persons or
damage to property resulting from such civil defense activity prior to or
during either an enemy caused or a natural emergency. (Prior code §1-65)
2.48.090: CONTRIBUTIONS:
Whenever the federal government or the state, or any person, firm or
corporation offers to the city any services, equipment, supplies, materials or
funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for purposes of civil defense, the mayor
may accept such offer and may authorize the director of civil defense to
receive same subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations,
if any, of the agency making the offer. (Prior code §1-66)
2.48.100: PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter in the city, or who
fails to carry out any of the provisions of this chapter or to comply
therewith, or with any of the orders, rules or regulations made under the
authority of this chapter, shall upon conviction be punished by a fine not
exceeding twenty dollars ($20.00) for each separate offense. (Prior code §1-67)
CHAPTER 2.50
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES CODE
SECTION:
2.50.010: Definitions
2.50.020: Contractor Selection And Obligations
2.50.030: Medical Director
2.50.040: Insurance Requirements
2.50.050: Response Times
2.50.060: Violations
2.50.070: Penalties
2.50.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
ALS FIRST RESPONDER: Any vehicle not normally used for purposes of patient
transport, and which must meet the following requirements: a) be staffed with a
minimum of a paramedic; b) equipped with the required communications, automatic
vehicle locator, and ALS equipment; and c) certain advanced life support
equipment that will meet or exceed State equipment regulations.
AVL: A system utilizing a technology approved by the Coordinator and which
allows real-time monitoring at the locations of all units in service.
ADVANCED LIFE SUPPORT OR ALS: Means the treatment of life- threatening medical
emergencies by authorized emergency medical technician-paramedics under medical
control, pursuant to the laws of the City or State, or the provision of such
treatment by other qualified and licensed medical or nursing personnel.
AMBULANCE: Any vehicle permitted by the department and the City which is
equipped to provide advanced or basic life support, which is designed,
constructed, maintained, equipped, or operated for, and is used for or intended
to be used for the transportation of patients.
ARRIVAL AT INCIDENT LOCATION: Means the time an ALS ambulance crew or ALS first
responder notifies the E-911 Center that the ambulance or ALS first responder
has arrived at the scene of an incident. In situations when the ambulance or
ALS first responder has responded to a location other than the scene (e.g.,
staging areas for hazardous material, violent crimes incidents, or non- secured
scenes), arrival "at the incident location" shall be the time the ambulance or
ALS first responder arrives at the designated staging location. If an ambulance
or ALS first responder unit fails to report that it has arrived at the incident
location prior to the crew departing the unit, the response time clock shall
not be stopped until the time of the next communication between the ambulance
and the E-911 system.
BASIC LIFE SUPPORT OR BLS: Means the treatment of life- threatening medical
emergencies by an emergency medical technician or other qualified and licensed
medical and nursing personnel using such techniques approved by City, pursuant
to the law of the State.
CONTRACTOR: Means the entity which City has contracted with to provide
emergency medical services.
DEPARTMENT: Oklahoma Department of Health, Office of Emergency Medical Services
Division.
EMS: Means emergency medical services.
EMS COORDINATOR: The employee or official designated by City as the EMS
Coordinator.
EMT: Means emergency medical technician.
E-911 SYSTEM: City's Emergency Communications Center(s) which receives all
requests for emergency medical services, fire service, and law enforcement.
EMERGENCY 911 COMMUNICATIONS: The E-911 system which receives all requests for
emergency medical services, fire service, and law enforcement for the City.
EMERGENCY REQUEST: A request for emergency services received at E-911 or a
request for emergency services transferred from the E-911 system to contractor.
EMERGENCY SERVICES: The delivery of emergency medical services, including
without limitation the response to calls for emergency medical assistance, the
rendering of such levels of medical services as are required by applicable law,
including emergency medical treatment rendered by employees of contractor who
are trained as EMT/AEMT's and paramedics and the provision of ambulance
transportation of patients within City.
EMERGENCY TRANSPORT: Is the transport of a patient in an ALS ambulance
resulting from: a) a response to an emergency request, or b) a response to a
non-emergency request which results in a need for emergency services.
LEVEL 0: No ambulances are available within City.
MEDICAL DIRECTOR: Medical director means an individual who has an active,
unencumbered license to engage in the practice of medicine pursuant to title 63
of the Oklahoma Statutes, sections 1-2501 through 1-2516; and, Oklahoma
Administrative Code, chapter 641, Emergency Medical Services.
NON-EMERGENCY TRANSPORTS: Requested medical transports of patient(s), or
unscheduled transports, not meeting the definition of emergency transport of
patient(s).
PARAMEDIC: A person who is certified by the State to perform basic and advanced
life support procedures, pursuant to the provisions of the laws of the State.
PATIENT: An individual who is ill, sick, injured, wounded, or otherwise
incapacitated, and needs, or is at risk of needing, medical attention, or care
on scene and/or during transport to or from a health care facility.
RESPONSE: Means the act of responding to an emergency or a non- emergency
request, which begins with the dispatching of an ambulance and: a) in the case
of a request resulting in a patient being transported, ends with the
ambulance's arrival at the incident location, or b) in the case of a request
which does not result in a patient transported, ends with cancellation of the
ambulance responding to the request.
RESPONSE TIME: That period of time when contractor is notified of a pending
emergency request, until arrival at the incident location.
SERVICE AREA: The City limits of the City of Warr Acres. (Ord. 1177, 2017)
2.50.020: CONTRACTOR SELECTION AND OBLIGATIONS:
City may provide for EMS service within the service area by selecting a
qualified contractor to perform such services. The contractor shall be selected
in accordance with the Charter and ordinances of the City applicable to any
service contract.
A.   Contractor shall:
   1.   Be solely responsible for acquiring and renewing all licenses, permits,
certificates or similar government approvals which are or may be required by
applicable law and department's rules and regulations for conducting services
described herein.
   2.   Accept assignment of Medicare benefits as payment and shall not bill
Medicare beneficiaries for any additional amount except as permitted by the
Medicare Guidelines for the acceptance of assignment.
   3.   Transport patients from all areas of the service area, in accordance
with Medical Control Destination Protocols, to appropriate medical facilities.
   4.   Provide one dedicated, fully staffed and equipped ambulance, twenty
four (24) hours-per-day, 365-days per year in the City limits unless such
ambulances are not available under the terms of this agreement. The ambulance
dedicated to the City will be based in the City limits or on property
immediately bordering the City limits, and will never leave the City to support
another community, except for the City of Bethany, unless resources are
available for such response. Contractor will not reduce ambulance resources to
level zero (0) in City to serve a mutual-aid request response unless under pre-
determined circumstances, or upon approval of City's authorized contract
administrator.
   5.   Staff each ambulance per the State of Oklahoma's rules, regulations,
legislation and laws. Every ambulance which responds to an emergency or non-
emergency request for service shall be staffed and equipped at the paramedic
level of care.
   6.   Provide a standby ALS ambulance for standby upon request of the EMS
Coordinator when: a) there is reason to believe a life threatening public
emergency presently exists in City (to include fire and law enforcement scenes,
when requested), and b) dedicated special events. Contract may request
additional fees related to providing an ambulance stand-by fee for for-profit
events.
   7.   Not deny access to emergency care and transportation to any person
located in the service area, regardless of ability to pay. Payment for services
shall be subject to the following restrictions:
      a.   If a resident of City, who is a payer into City's Ambulance Service
Utility Assessment Program, requires services, contractor shall bill its
charges to all available third-party payers, on behalf of the resident, and
shall limit its collections to those funds received from all available third-
party payers to the extent permitted by all applicable laws, and shall not
balance- bill the patient or other responsible party (except for deductible(s)
and/or co-pays). Provided, however, that the recipient of said services fully
cooperates with EMS by providing required information for use by contractor
and/or its billing agent(s) in a timely manner.
      b.   If a resident of City, who is a payer into the City's Ambulance
Service Utility Assessment Program, requires services but has no insurance,
contractor shall discount its total charges equal to the Center for Medicare
Services (CMS - Medicare) payment allowable (at the time of service),
regardless if the transport is a CMS qualified payer. Provided, however, that
the recipient of said services must fully cooperate with contractor by
providing required information for use by contractor and/or its billing agent
(s) in a timely manner to substantiate the claim of having no insurance.
      c.   If a resident of City requires services but has no insurance,
contractor agrees to discount its total charges equal to the Center for
Medicare Services (CMS - Medicare) payment allowable (at the time of service),
whether the transport is a CMS qualified payer, or not.
   8.   Not offer incentives, by way of additional salaries or wages, or
compensated leave of absence, to employees based upon the number of procedures
performed or based upon mileage for the provision of ambulance transportation.
   9.   Respond to City's inquiries about service and/or complaints within
three (3) business days of notification.
   10.   Enter into a standard HIPAA Business Associate Agreement with City as
the covered entity to provide for the protection of the privacy and security of
health information.
   11.   Submit reports and supporting documentation to City related to
performance of duties governed by this chapter, such reports to be submitted
within twenty (20) business days following the end of each month. The reports
shall detail the preceding month's ambulance calls and their disposition.
   12.   Contractor shall complete and maintain appropriate documentation and
Pre-Hospital Care Reports per State of Oklahoma rules and regulations, and
those regulations of the Federal government.
   13.   Maintain mutual-aid agreements with surrounding, contiguous ambulance
services in accordance with Oklahoma ambulance licensing protocols (310:641-3-
120) to ensure coverage is provided in the event resources exceed that which
contractor is required to provide. Contractor shall, in turn, provide
reciprocal mutual aid service to neighboring communities providing the
capability exists without jeopardizing the requirements of the primary response
area. (Ord. 1177, 2017)
2.50.030: MEDICAL DIRECTOR:
Contractor shall, at all times, ensure that a medical director is retained. The
role of the medical director is as follows:
A.   Oversee contractor's organization in accordance with the State of Oklahoma
Emergency Medical Services Rules and Regulations governing ambulance services.
Provide oversight for contractor, including ultimate responsibility for the
quality of care, treatment, and services provided.
B.   Review contractor's standard of care by incorporating advancements, which
become known and available from time to time, or to correct defects in the
system standard of care discovered as a result of the Quality Improvement
Program. However, no change shall be made in the system standard of care, which
results in a standard that is less than or in contravention of the minimum
standards required by the laws of the State.
C.   Provide medical oversight of contractor's employees including direct and
in-direct medical oversight. The medical director, or designee, shall provide
medical direction in accordance with the State and Federal protocols and
policies and procedures. Other specific oversight responsibilities shall
include, but may not be limited to:
   1.   Monitoring controlled substance usage.
   2.   Monitoring quality assurance reports.
   3.   Conducting case review.
   4.   Determining and implementing clinical performance improvement
initiatives.
   5.   Incident review.
   6.   Complaint review.
   7.   Continuing education.
D.   Review and approve local medical control standards and requirements
(including if necessary, written and practical tests) for EMS personnel
providing care under the medical director's authority in accordance with the
current system standard of care. Personnel subject to such requirement will
include:
   1.   Persons receiving telephone requests for ambulance services first
responders.
   2.   Ambulance personnel.
   3.   Field training personnel.
E.   Administer testing (if necessary) and authorization of EMS system
personnel, and to establish and promulgate written guidelines in connection
therewith.
F.   Develop guidelines for on-line medical control, transport destination
policies and use of air medical services.
G.   Develop standards applicable to on-board equipment used in the delivery of
first response services and contractor's services within the service area.
H.   Report once each year, in writing, to City on the quality of care and
response time performance being provided by all components of contractor's
operation.
I.   Monitor all aspects of system performance including clinical quality of
care and verification of response time performance reported by first responders
and contractor.
J.   Report once each year, in writing, to City on the quality of care and
response time performance being provided by all components of the City's EMS
system.
K.   Monitor all aspects of City's EMS system performance including clinical
quality of care and verification of response time performance reported by first
responders and contractor.
L.   Contractor shall have controlled substance policies and procedures,
consistent with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, and Oklahoma Bureau
of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs requirements, to govern the storage,
inventory, accountability, restocking, and procurement of controlled drugs and
substances permitted and utilized in the provision of ALS by paramedics.
   1.   The medical director shall approve all controlled substance policies
and procedures.
   2.   Any incident of non-compliance with controlled substance policies and
procedures shall be reported immediately to City. (Ord. 1177, 2017)
2.50.040: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
A.   Contractor shall keep in full force and effect a policy or policies of
public liability and property damage insurance, executed by a financially
stable insurance carrier(s) which is licensed or permitted to write insurance
by the Oklahoma Insurance Commission, with coverage provisions insuring the
public from any loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by
reason of the operation of contractor's ambulances, and providing that amount
of recovery shall be in limits of not less than the following sums:
   1.   Automobile liability, combined single limit, in the amount of two
million dollars ($2,000,000.00).
   2.   General liability in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
per occurrence, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) aggregate.
   3.   Medical professional liability claims made in the amount of one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00)
aggregate.
   4.   Worker's compensation in the amount of the statutory limits plus one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) employer's liability, part B workers'
compensation.
   5.   Excess liability coverage in the amount of five million dollars
($5,000,000.00).
Contractor shall have City named as additional insured per the insurance
policy. (Ord. 1177, 2017)
2.50.050: RESPONSE TIMES:
In each thirty (30) day period, (beginning on the first day of each month), not
less than ninety percent (90%) of contractor's responses to emergency requests
shall be performed in less than eleven (11) minutes with an average of ninety
percent (90%) reliability aggregated monthly in the City of Warr Acres.
Contractor will perform all unscheduled non-emergency requests for service
within two (2) hours, with an average of ninety percent (90%) reliability
aggregated monthly. Contractor will respond "emergency status" to all requests
for service presumptively classified or assumed to be an emergency.
A.   To account for unusual factors beyond contractor's control which might
affect the response time, the following requests for ambulance service shall
not be included in the calculation:
   1.   Calls which are canceled prior to arrival if in accordance with
approved medical protocols and based on information received from first
response units on scene or City's 911 Communications Center(s). This includes
calls canceled by the caller prior to arrival.
   2.   Calls during severe weather conditions where response time compliance
is either impossible or could be achieved only at a greater risk to EMS
personnel or the public than would result from a delayed response.
   3.   Requests during a disaster, locally or in a neighboring authority,
which has requested assistance from City.
   4.   Response times outside defined service area.
   5.   Call for service that are deemed excepted for good cause by the City's
EMS Coordinator. Such grounds include, but are not limited to, the transmission
of erroneous, incomplete, or inaccurate information from City's 911 Dispatch
Center(s).
B.   The following response times shall be monitored and accurately recorded so
that continual audit of these times may be performed as a method to assure the
most efficient responses are being performed:
   1.   Time request for EMS response is received at the dispatch center (this
time shall be indicated when sufficient information has been received from the
caller to initiate a response).
   2.   Time ambulance is notified.
   3.   Time ambulance is en route.
   4.   Time ambulance is on the scene.
   5.   Time ambulance is en route to the hospital or is available if not
needed.
   6.   Time ambulance arrives at the hospital.
   7.   Time ambulance is back in service area. (Ord. 1177, 2017)
2.50.060: VIOLATIONS:
A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to commit any of the
following acts:
   1.   To perform or permit anyone to perform duties as an ambulance driver,
attendant (EMT-basic, EMT-D, or paramedic), system status controller, or first
responder without complying with the terms of this chapter, or for any EMT-
paramedic to seek or accept medical direction by radio contact from anyone who
is not a certified "base station physician";
   2.   To use, or cause to be used, an ambulance service other than
contractor, except for those services described in subsection B of this
section;
   3.   For any person, firm or organization to respond to emergency calls
originating within the regulated service area, other than contractor;
   4.   For any person, firm or organization to provide special events
ambulance standby service within the regulated service area, other than
contractor;
   5.   For any person, firm or organization to respond to routine transport
calls originating within the regulated service areas other than contractor;
   6.   To knowingly give false information to induce the dispatch of an
ambulance, or first responder unit.
B.   It shall not be a violation of this chapter, if the vehicle or ambulance
is:
   1.   A privately owned vehicle not used in the business of transporting
patients who are sick, injured, wounded, incapacitated or helpless;
   2.   A vehicle rendering services as an ambulance in the event of a major
catastrophe or emergency when ambulances with certifications based in the
locality of the catastrophe or emergency are incapacitated or insufficient in
number to render the services needed;
   3.   An ambulance owned or operated by, or under contract with, the Federal
or State government;
   4.   An ambulance transporting a patient to a location within the regulated
service area, which transport originated from a point outside the regulated
service area;
   5.   An ambulance responding to a call pursuant to a mutual aid agreement
with contractor;
   6.   A vehicle engaged in a routine transport call to transport a patient
from a hospital, nursing home or freestanding dialysis center (i.e., a dialysis
center not located on hospital grounds) which is located within the regulated
service area to any jurisdiction outside the regulated service area (the
"receiving jurisdiction"), if the receiving jurisdiction allows contractor to
lawfully engage in routine transport calls to transport patients from
hospitals, nursing homes, and freestanding dialysis centers located within that
receiving jurisdiction to destinations within the regulated service area;
   7.   A vehicle engaged in a routine transport call to transport a patient
from a hospital, nursing home, or freestanding dialysis center located within
the regulated service area to any unincorporated area;
   8.   A vehicle engaged in a routine transport call to transport a patient
from a hospital, nursing home, or freestanding dialysis center located in
either the eastern or western division of the regulated service area, to a
destination in the other division of the regulated service area;
   9.   A vehicle engaged in the interstate transport of a patient. (Ord. 1177,
2017)
2.50.070: PENALTIES:
A.   Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be punished by fine and costs not to exceed the sum of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) excluding costs.
B.   Each day that any violation of the provisions of this chapter is committed
or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1177, 2017)

CHAPTER 2.60
PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR
SECTION:
2.60.010: Office Created
2.60.020: Appointment; Removal From Office
2.60.030: Qualifications
2.60.040: General Duties
2.60.050: Acting Director
2.60.010: OFFICE CREATED:
The office of public works director is hereby created and the executive
official in charge shall be known as the public works director. (Ord. 782 §1,
1996)
2.60.020: APPOINTMENT; REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The public works director shall be appointed by the mayor with consent of the
council. This appointment shall continue during good behavior and satisfactory
service. He shall be at will and subject to rules set forth in the employee
handbook of personnel policies. (Ord. 985 §3, 2003: Ord. 782 §2, 1996)
2.60.030: QUALIFICATIONS:
The qualifications for the public works director shall be as established from
time to time by a written job description adopted by the city council. (Ord.
782 §3, 1996)
2.60.040: GENERAL DUTIES:
A.   Duties of the public works director, under the general supervision of the
mayor, shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
   1.   Plan, assign, direct and exercise general supervision over all public
works divisions including, but not limited to, sanitation, sewer, streets,
parks, engineering and city garage;
   2.   Prepare and submit budget for public works divisions;
   3.   Make periodic inspection of city public works department facilities and
operations;
   4.   Review reports of all public works department divisions' activities and
progress for evaluation upon request and determine appropriate actions
required;
   5.   Receive complaints concerning city services from citizens and resolve
problems or forward to appropriate division for handling;
   6.   Prepare special reports as required and serve as advisor to mayor and
council;
   7.   Attend council, planning commission, traffic commission and board of
adjustment meetings;
   8.   Respond to questionnaires, surveys and other requests for information
from public, other government agencies, mayor, council and others;
   9.   Prepare applications for grants and funding for public works related
projects;
   10.   Coordinate engineering planning of city projects with consultants,
other cities, state, county and federal agencies;
   11.   Establish division policies and procedures;
   12.   Perform other duties as assigned or required.
B.   The public works director shall have authority in the following areas:
   1.   No authority on private property;
   2.   No code enforcement authority or traffic control unless directly
related to his area of responsibility. If any traffic control must be used then
the police and fire departments shall be properly advised;
   3.   Areas of authority and responsibility limited to all city streets right
of way to right of way, all public easements, all city property, sewers and
sanitation.
C.   Any ruling that may adversely affect a citizen or business may be appealed
to the city council. (Ord. 782 §4, 1996)
2.60.050: ACTING DIRECTOR:
During temporary absence or disability of the public works director, the person
designated by the public works director or the mayor at the time shall serve as
acting public works director. (Ord. 782 §5, 1996)

CHAPTER 3.04
PURCHASES AND REPAIRS
SECTION:
3.04.010: Approval Of Purchase
3.04.011: Authorized Purchases
3.04.020: Contracts; Sealed Bids
3.04.030: Notice For Bids
3.04.040: Filing Of Bids
3.04.050: Emergencies
3.04.010: APPROVAL OF PURCHASE:
The mayor shall contract for and purchase all supplies, materials and equipment
for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government; provided,
that before any such contract is entered into or such purchase is made
involving the expenditure of more than seven thousand five hundred dollars
($7,500.00), the same shall be approved by the council. Except in cases of
purchases of new or used equipment from or through a governmental agency, or
purchases of uniforms, bulk orders of concrete, asphalt, sand, gasoline or
diesel fuel, or in case of an emergency, all purchases in excess of fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be submitted to competitive bidding under
such terms as the council shall direct. Nothing in this section shall prohibit
the mayor or the council from authorizing leases of equipment as may be
provided by law.
The purchase of supplies, equipment, materials that are similar or
substantially similar to supplies, equipment or materials made available to the
city pursuant to a valid contract competitively bid by the state of Oklahoma,
or by any political subdivision thereof, by any other state (or political
subdivision thereof), or pursuant to a governmental services administration
(GSA) contract shall be deemed to have met the competitive bidding requirements
of this section. (Ord. 1165, 2015)
3.04.011: AUTHORIZED PURCHASES:
Authorized purchases for the maintenance and operation of the various
departments in the budget shall not be infringed, provided each purchase shall
not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Request for purchases outside the
budget authorization must be approved by the council prior to the actual order.
(Ord. 777 §1, 1996: Ord. 752 §1, 1994)
3.04.020: CONTRACTS; SEALED BIDS:
Except in cases of emergency, before entering into any contract or any purchase
which requires and has the approval of the council, lease or rental contracts
with or without option to purchase excluded, the mayor shall give written
notice for sealed bids for the furnishing of such supplies, materials or
equipment. (Ord. 808 §1, 1996: Ord. 786 §1, 1996: prior code §8-2)
3.04.030: NOTICE FOR BIDS:
The notice required by section
3.04.020 of this chapter shall state the time and place for filing the bids,
and shall contain an accurate description of the supplies, materials or
equipment to be purchased, the time and place the bids shall be opened, and
shall state that all bids may be rejected. (Prior code §8-3)
3.04.040: FILING OF BIDS:
The bids shall be in writing, sealed and filed with the city clerk prior to the
time they are to be opened and the bids shall be opened at the time specified
in the notice, at which time any or all bids may be rejected, or the mayor may
readvertise for bids, or after due consideration thereof may award a contract
to, or purchase such supplies, materials or equipment from, the lowest and best
responsible bidder. (Prior code §8-4)
3.04.050: EMERGENCIES:
It is further provided by this chapter that the mayor shall have the authority,
in cases of "emergency" as hereinafter defined, to effect repairs to any and
all city equipment, buildings or property, not to exceed twelve thousand
dollars ($12,000.00). The mayor shall notify the council of such action within
ten (10) days, or submit a full report at the next council meeting, whichever
shall first occur. The notification or report shall include a statement of the
reasons for his actions. Such statement shall be entered into the official
minutes at the next regular council meeting. For purposes of this chapter,
"emergency" is defined as a condition resulting from a sudden, unexpected
happening, or unforeseen occurrence or condition, and/or situation, either as
to its onset or as to its extent, of such severity or magnitude that immediate
response or action is necessary to preserve the health and safety of the public
or environment or to preserve property. It shall also be defined as a condition
or situation which, if allowed to continue, would lead to economic loss to the
city or to further damage of city equipment, buildings or property. (Ord. 994
§1, 2003: Ord. 873 §1, 1998: prior code §8-5)
