6.08.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed herein:
LARGE ANIMALS: Classified as all such animals, wild or domestic, having hoofed
feet, and all large species of wild animals having pawed feet, not customarily
considered suitable household pets.
LICENSE: To have, to obtain and to hold a license issued by the city.
SMALL ANIMALS: Classified as cats, dogs, skunks, opossums, rats, rabbits,
chickens, geese, reptiles, and all other animals, wild or domestic, of a like
nature and description. (Ord. 382 §11, 1975)
6.08.020: ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY:
Pursuant to
chapter 6.04 of this title, creating the animal control department for the city
and the duties and responsibilities imposed thereby, the animal control officer
or his representative for the city is directed and authorized to enforce the
provisions of this chapter, as follows, and all applicable state laws made a
part of this chapter. (Ord. 382 §2, 1975)
6.08.030: LICENSE FOR DOGS AND CATS; PAYMENT REQUIRED:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person within the city to keep, own,
possess, harbor, or allow to remain in or upon the premises under his or her
control any dog or member of the canine family or any cat or member of the
feline family over four (4) months of age without having paid a license fee as
set forth in this chapter.
B.   All required vaccination and city tags will be attached to all dogs and
cats at all times.
C.   Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction in the municipal
court, be subject to a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) plus court
costs. (Ord. 999 §2, 2004: Ord. 692 §1, 1989)
6.08.035: PERSONS AUTHORIZED TO DISPENSE CITY LICENSES:
A city license shall be issued only by the animal control officer or his
designee, the Warr Acres licensed veterinarian or a veterinarian of the owner's
choice, provided such veterinarian is authorized by the city to dispense the
city license. (Ord. 999 §3, 2004)
6.08.040: LICENSE; EXPIRATION; NONTRANSFERABLE:
All licenses shall expire on January 1 of each year, and no license shall be
issued for a period of less than one year. No license shall in any case be
returned or transferred from one person to another person. No free license
shall be granted, nor rebates allowed, for any cause, nor any sum accepted less
than the amount provided in this chapter. (Ord. 382 §3, 1975)
6.08.050: FEES AND CHARGES DESIGNATED:
Fees and charges specifically set forth by this chapter are as follows:
A.   Annual dog or cat license fee, per animal, is five dollars ($5.00) for the
first registration and two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) for each successive and
consecutive annual registration for the same animal. Unless the annual
registration is continuous the charge shall be the same as an initial
registration.
B.   Charges allowed for taking animals into custody for any reason, except
euthanization, are as follows:
 
Type Of Charge                                                 Fee       
Owner releasing an unwanted dog/cat to the animal control     No charge
officer
Pick up; entry or return to pound per animal                  $15.00
Board:                                                         
   Dogs and cats, per day, including day of entry and      7.00
reclamation
   All other animals, per day, including day of entry and  At city's cost
reclamation
Veterinary health check per animal on entry, if required      At city's cost
 
(Ord. 999 §4, 2004: Ord. 836 §1, 1997: Ord. 692 §2, 1989)
6.08.060: RABIES VACCINATION:
No license shall be issued for any dog or cat owned, kept, possessed, harbored
or allowed to remain in and upon the premises of any person under his or her
control unless such dog or cat has first been vaccinated against rabies by a
qualified veterinarian or his designee. As a prerequisite to the issuance of a
dog or cat license, there shall be delivered to the animal control department
or an authorized licensing veterinarian a certificate showing that the animal
has been properly vaccinated against rabies and giving the date and place of
vaccination. Upon presentation of proper evidence and payment of the fee as
provided for in section
6.08.050 of this chapter the animal control department is authorized to issue a
license and metal tag, which tag shall be attached to the collar of the
licensed dog or cat and the removal of the tag shall be an offense and a
violation of this chapter if not immediately replaced with a current issue.
(Ord. 616 §1, 1985)
6.08.070: QUARANTINE AND CONTROL OF RABID ANIMALS:
Pursuant to the authority contained in title 63 of the Oklahoma Statutes
annotated 1971, section 1-508, and the policy adopted by the Oklahoma state
board of health (a copy of which is attached to the ordinance codified herein
and made a part of this chapter), the animal control officer or his
representative is directed and authorized to enforce the aforesaid policy in
conjunction and cooperation with the state board of health, and to do all acts
consistent therewith in the quarantine and control of rabid animals, or animals
suspected of being rabid.
A.   Report Of Animal Bite Required: Any person owning, harboring, or keeping
an animal that bites a person and any person bitten by an animal must report
that occurrence to the animal control officer within twenty four (24) hours.
B.   Notification Of Required Confinement And Observation: Upon receiving a
report that a person has been bitten by an animal, an animal control officer
shall issue a notice to the person owning, keeping or harboring the animal
which states that confinement and observation of the animal are required.
C.   Confinement And Observation Of Animal Required: Upon receiving the notice
required, the person owning, harboring, or keeping the animal which in the
preceding ten (10) days has bitten or is suspected of having bitten any person,
shall have the animal immediately placed in confinement for rabies observation.
D.   Method Of Confinement And Observation: Confinement and observation as
required by state law and this section shall be effected by placing the animal
under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten (10) days
from the date the person was bitten. In the event of the suspect animal's death
or illness, the person so designated as responsible for the animal shall
immediately make arrangements for the removal and shipment of the animal's head
to the laboratory of the state department of health for examination. In no
event shall the suspect animal be removed from the city limits until released
by the animal control officer or his specifically authorized representative.
E.   Seizure And Impoundment By Animal Control Officer: In the event the person
who owns, harbors or keeps the suspected animal cannot, with due diligence, be
located or notified, or, in the event the person who owns, harbors, or keeps
the suspected animal, refuses or fails to place the animal in confinement as
required by this section after notice to do so has been given, an animal
control officer shall seize and impound the animal and place it in confinement
for the required observation period. The animal control officer shall
thereafter notify the owner or keeper of the animal of the seizure, impoundment
and confinement. If, subsequent to the seizure and impoundment of the animal by
the animal control officer, the owner or keeper of the animal cannot be located
or notified and if the animal remains unclaimed at the expiration of the
confinement period, the animal control officer may dispose of the animal
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter concerning the disposition of
unclaimed, impounded animals.
F.   Euthanasia: In special circumstances, the animal control officer or his
representative may order the euthanasia of an animal and may perform or order
the performance of tests for the diagnosis of rabies. Provided, however, that,
prior to disposing of the animal, the division shall attempt to locate and
notify the owner or keeper of the animal. For purposes of this section,
"special circumstances" shall be defined as those situations involving severe
animal bites upon the head, face, neck or upper extremities, or deep
lacerations, or multiple animal bite wounds inflicted by unimmunized animals.
(Ord. 999 §5, 2004: Ord. 386 §7, 1975)
6.08.080: DISPOSITION OF IMPOUNDED DOGS, CATS AND OTHER ANIMALS:
After reasonable efforts have been made to locate and notify the owners of
impounded animals or those persons having control or possession thereof, and
after the expiration of seventy two (72) hours, the animal control officer or
his representative shall be authorized to humanely dispose of the impounded
animals by any of the following measures:
A.   Euthanization in a euthanization chamber as maintained and operated by the
animal control officer or his representative;
B.   Injection of an approved lethal drug; or
C.   Any other humane means which is recommended and approved by the director
of the Oklahoma City Zoo.
D.   In any case, the provisions of the ordinances governing the adoption of
dogs and cats shall be available as an alternative to euthanization. (Ord. 999
§6, 2004: Ord. 458, 1977: Ord. 382 §8, 1975)
6.08.090: ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person or persons to permit their dog or canine, or any
animal or fowl possessed, kept or harbored by such person, to run at large on
the streets, alleys or public places, or over, across or upon the private
property not under the control of the owner within the city, whether or not a
license fee has been paid. Any person who violates this section shall, upon
conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) plus
court costs. (Ord. 746 §1, 1994: Ord. 692 §3, 1989)
6.08.095: CONFINEMENT OF DOGS REQUIRED:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, harbors or possesses any dog
to fail to control such dog as required by the provisions of this section.
B.   Every person who owns, possesses or harbors any dog within the city shall
control the dog while on property owned or controlled by him or her. Control
may be accomplished by confinement by means of a substantial fence or similar
enclosure of sufficient strength and height to prevent the dog from escaping
therefrom, or from extending its head through the enclosure so as to constitute
a threat to any person or animal in the area adjoining the enclosure; or by
keeping the dog inside a house or other building. Dogs not confined in this
manner must be controlled by the owner. Control may be accomplished by means of
strict and immediate obedience by the dog to the owner's commands. Control may
also be accomplished by tether or leash which shall consist of a metal chain or
other material of sufficient strength to prevent the dog from escaping from the
property. If the tether or leash is not under the direct physical control of
the individual who owns, possesses or harbors the dog, then it shall be long
enough to permit the dog to have reasonable exercise, but shall not allow the
dog access to public property or to sidewalks or rights of way or to property
owned or leased by persons other than the owner of the animal. Owners choosing
to exert control by means of strict obedience of the dog to the owner's
commands must be present and in the immediate vicinity of the dog and shall be
deemed to have violated this provision if the dog fails to obey the owner's
command and runs at large on the property in defiance of the owner's commands.
C.   Any person who violates this provision shall, upon conviction, be punished
by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 1129,
2012)
6.08.100: ANIMALS RUNNING AT LARGE; IMPOUNDMENT:
It shall be the duty of the animal control officer or his representative to
take up any dog or animal found running at large and confine it in the city
pound or any other place so designated by the mayor for a period of seventy two
(72) hours, during which time the owner shall be notified or the person having
control or possession may redeem the animal upon payment of all required fees.
The animal control officer or his representative shall issue an official
receipt for the amount paid. (Ord. 999 §7, 2004: Ord. 382 §9, 1975)
6.08.110: IMPOUNDMENT FEES; EUTHANIZATION OR DISPOSAL:
The fees received as provided for in section
6.08.100 of this chapter shall be immediately delivered to the city treasurer
and the amount credited to the general fund of the city. In the event the fees
are assessed as a result of taking up any animal or the failure to procure a
license as required, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer or his
representative to euthanize or dispose of the animal after the expiration of
time as provided in section
6.08.100 of this chapter. If an animal is confined at the city pound or any
other place, the owner shall pay the fee and charges as provided in this
chapter, even though the owner does not repossess the animal. If an animal is
turned over to a licensed veterinarian or animal hospital for any obvious
reason, the owner shall pay all reasonable and necessary fees charged therefor.
(Ord. 382 §9, 1975)
6.08.120: VICIOUS OR NOISY ANIMALS:
A.   It is unlawful for any person knowingly to keep or harbor any dog which
habitually barks, howls or yelps, or any cat which habitually cries or howls to
the great discomfort of the peace and quiet of the neighborhood, or in such
manner as to materially disturb or annoy persons in the neighborhood who are of
ordinary sensibilities. Such dogs and cats are declared to be a public
nuisance.
B.   Whenever any person shall complain to the police department that a dog
which habitually barks, howls or yelps, or a cat which habitually cries or
howls is being kept by any person in the city, the police department shall
notify the owner of such dog or cat that a complaint has been received and that
person should take whatever steps necessary to alleviate the howling, yelping
or crying.
C.   If the warning given to the person alleged to be keeping a cat or dog as
set forth in subsection B of this section is ineffective, then a verified
complaint of one citizen may be presented to the police department, alleging
that a dog which habitually barks, howls or yelps, or a cat which habitually
cries or howls, is being kept by any person within the city. The police
department shall inform the owner of such dog or cat that the petition has been
received and shall cite the owner of the dog or cat for violation of alleged in
the complaint.
D.   If the municipal court finds the party against whom the complaint is filed
guilty of violating the provisions of subsection B of this section, the court
may impose a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense
and a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second and
subsequent offenses, plus court costs.
E.   In the event of more than one conviction involving the same animal, the
court may, in its disposition and in addition to the fines imposed, order the
animal destroyed in the manner provided by law. The destruction order shall not
be effective until the time for appeal of the conviction shall have lapsed.
Upon appeal being perfected in the appropriate appellate court, the destruction
order shall be stayed until the appeal is resolved. (Ord. 1024 §1, 2006: Ord.
976 §1, 2002: Ord. 744 §§2–6, 1993: Ord. 692 §4, 1989)
6.08.121: NUMBER OF DOGS OR CATS PER HOUSEHOLD:
A.   Owning, possessing or harboring more than four (4) dogs or cats, or
combination thereof, in a single household by any person is prohibited.
Exception: This prohibition shall not apply to any duly licensed kennel or
veterinary clinic in the city. Nor shall cats which are duly vaccinated and
licensed as of October 1, 1985, if counting them would exceed the limitation of
licensed pets per household.
B.   Any person found to be in violation of the provisions of this section
shall be guilty of an offense and subject to a fine of twenty five dollars
($25.00) for each day the violation continues as each day's continued violation
of this section shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such.
(Ord. 1127, 2012)
6.08.122: INTERFERENCE WITH ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER:
A.   It shall be an offense for any person to interfere with, hinder, delay or
obstruct in any manner whatsoever any animal control officer in the performance
of his official duties.
B.   Any person found in violation of this section shall, upon conviction in
the municipal court, be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 1000 §2, 2004: Ord. 616 §1, 1985)
6.08.130: DEAD ANIMALS:
The animal control officer and/or his representative is directed and authorized
to remove all dead animals found upon boulevards, streets, alleys and other
city property, and the animal control officer is authorized to enter upon
private property for the removal of the same, upon request of the owner. It
shall be the duty of any person having knowledge of the whereabouts of any dead
animal to notify the animal control department and to give the location where
the dead animal may be found. Every person who strikes any animal with a
vehicle and injures or kills such animal should notify the animal control
department immediately after the occurrence giving time and place of injury or
death, together with a description of the animal, and the name and address of
the person making the report. (Ord. 382 §12, 1975)
6.08.140: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS, HERPTILES AND FOWL:
Proper care of and treatment of all animals, herptiles and fowl shall be
required. It is unlawful for any person to maltreat, neglect, improperly
confine, fail to act or commit any act which results in cruelty to any animal,
herptile or fowl. Any person violating this section shall upon conviction be
fined a sum not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court costs.
(Ord. 692 §5, 1989)
6.08.150: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
Whenever the proper city authority or its authorized agent deems it desirable
to make an inspection of premises in the city, in order to determine the
existence of violations of any provisions of this chapter pertaining to the
health, welfare or safety of the public, the animal control officer or his
representative shall be allowed entrance to the premises for these purposes if
any of the following conditions exist:
A.   Entry is by permission or at the request of the occupant of the premises
or of the person in apparent charge, or
B.   Where an imminent danger to health, welfare or safety exists. (Ord. 382
§14(A), 1975)
6.08.160: SEARCH WARRANT:
If entry is refused or delayed by the occupant or person in apparent charge of
the premises, or if the conditions stated in section
6.08.150 of this chapter do not exist, the animal control officer or his
representative may apply to the proper magistrate for a search warrant to
authorize entry into the designated premises for the purpose of making an
inspection to determine the existence of a violation of any provision of this
chapter pertaining to the health, welfare or safety of the public. (Ord. 382
§14(B), 1975)
6.08.170: PROBABLE CAUSE FOR SEARCH WARRANT:
Probable cause for the purpose of a search warrant issued pursuant to section
6.08.160 of this chapter is that the applicant for the warrant has knowledge of
a violation or knowledge of facts which would indicate a violation of any
provision of this chapter pertaining to health, safety or welfare of the
public, and such applicant has stated the facts upon which his knowledge is
based in the affidavit provided for in section
6.08.160 of this chapter. (Ord. 382 §14(C), 1975)
6.08.180: APPLICATION FOR SEARCH WARRANT; ISSUANCE:
A.   The application for the search warrant shall be signed and sworn to by the
animal control officer or his representative and shall be accompanied by an
affidavit or affidavits containing facts within the personal knowledge of the
affiant or affiants that there is probable cause for the issuance of a search
warrant for certain premises, and that entry therein has been denied or unduly
delayed by the occupant or person in apparent charge.
B.   Thereupon, the proper magistrate may issue a search warrant directed to
the animal control officer or his representative authorizing him to enter and
inspect the premises. The search warrant shall name and describe with
reasonable particularity the place to be inspected, the reason for inspection,
and the name of the applicant on whose written application the warrant was
issued. (Ord. 382 §14(D)(1),(2), 1975)
6.08.190: INSPECTION:
An inspection under the authority of the search warrant shall be made within
fifteen (15) calendar days from the date of the issuance, and after the
expiration of the fifteen (15) day period the warrant shall be null and void.
(Ord. 382 §14(D)(3), 1975)
6.08.200: UNRELATED INFORMATION TO BE CONFIDENTIAL:
Information unrelated to inspection obtained by search is confidential, with
the exception that any inspector who gains entrance to premises under the
authority of section
6.08.150 or
6.08.160 of this chapter shall not obtain or furnish evidence for, or testify
to, an offense other than a violation of the standards, rules and regulations
of the city pertaining to particular violations for which he is inspecting,
except with respect to a felony or misdemeanor involving an act of violence
which has been committed in his presence. (Ord. 382 §14(E), 1975)
6.08.210: CITATION FOR VIOLATIONS:
The animal control officer and/or his representative is authorized to advise
the owner and issue a citation to any person or persons within the city for an
offense of this chapter:
A.   Upon a complaint signed by a third party making such complaint; or
B.   Upon his own observation of an ordinance violation; or
C.   Upon probable cause when the cause is supported by proper evidence. (Ord.
408 §1, 1976: Ord. 382 §10(A), 1975)
6.08.220: PROCEDURE FOR CITATION:
In issuing the citation and complaint authorized by section
6.08.210 of this chapter, the animal control officer shall proceed as follows:
A.   He shall prepare a written citation to appear in court, on a citation form
to be provided by the city, which shall contain the name and address of the
cited person, the offense charged, and the date thereof. Such citation shall
state the date when the cited person shall appear in court.
B.   Such cited person shall sign the citation agreeing to appear as directed,
and one copy of the citation shall be delivered to such person, whereupon the
officer may release such cited person from custody.
C.   As soon as practicable, the officer shall verify the citation to appear
and cause the citation to be filed with the clerk of the municipal court,
retaining one copy for the records of the officer. (Ord. 408 §1, 1976: Ord. 382
§10(B), 1975)
6.08.230: SERVICE OF CITATION:
All citations issued shall be served personally upon the person or persons in
violation of this chapter, and the party served and named in the complaint
shall have at least ten (10) days prior to notice for appearance in the
municipal court to answer the complaint. (Ord. 408 §1, 1976: Ord. 382 §10(C),
1975)
6.08.240: PENALTY:
Any person pleading guilty or found guilty by the municipal court of an offense
in violation of this chapter shall be fined as provided in this chapter and
where no penalty is specifically provided, the fine shall be an amount not to
exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 692 §6, 1989)
CHAPTER 6.10
SWINE AND GOATS
SECTION:
6.10.010: Regulations; Exceptions
6.10.010: REGULATIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to keep, maintain or
feed swine or goats within the city, except as specifically provided for in
this section.
B.   The keeping of not more than one Asian potbellied pig or similar small
swine per lot or premises shall be allowed under the following conditions:
   1.   For purposes of this chapter, "potbellied pig" means: Asian potbellied
pigs, Sharpei pigs, Vietnamese, Chinese or Asian pigs, or other similar swine
meeting the provisions of this chapter.
   2.   A potbellied pig shall be a pet that is to be kept for personal
enjoyment and not kept or raised for human consumption.
   3.   A potbellied pig shall be licensed with the city under such conditions
as the animal control division deems appropriate, including, but not limited
to, rabies vaccination, if available, and registry through a bona fide registry
firm.
   4.   A potbellied pig shall not exceed seventy five (75) pounds in weight,
and twenty one inches (21") in height.
   5.   There shall not be more than one potbellied pig more than three (3)
months of age per lot of residence.
   6.   The keeping of a potbellied pig for commercial breeding purposes is
prohibited in the city.
   7.   The premises where a potbellied pig is kept shall be cleaned regularly
and shall be maintained so that noxious odors are controlled.
   8.   Any person who keeps, maintains or harbors a potbellied pig shall keep
it confined on the premises. The confinement shall be accomplished by the
following means:
      a.   A fence or similar enclosure to prevent escape;
      b.   Keeping inside a house or other building;
      c.   Keeping on a leash to prevent escape. (Ord. 742 §1, 1993)
CHAPTER 6.12
ANIMAL ADOPTION
SECTION:
6.12.010: General Policy
6.12.020: Retrieval Of Unlicensed Dogs
6.12.030: Adoption Of Dogs And Cats
6.12.040: Adoption Of Cats (Rep. by Ord. 999 §9, 2004)
6.12.050: Shelter Hours For Adoptions
6.12.060: Holding Animal In Shelter
6.12.010: GENERAL POLICY:
The city's main concerns with respect to adoption of a cat or dog from the
shelter are: a) that the animal be in apparent good health, that all dogs or
cats be immunized against rabies, licensed, spayed or neutered, not vicious by
nature, and b) that the animal will be assured of a good home under the control
of a responsible person. The location of residence of the proposed owner is
immaterial, however, if it is within the city limits, a Warr Acres license will
be required. (Ord. 747 §1, 1994)
6.12.020: RETRIEVAL OF UNLICENSED DOGS:
The city resident owner of a dog that has been impounded and is not currently
licensed may have his pet returned upon payment of all outstanding shelter
charges and upon payment of deposits ensuring rabies immunization and
licensing. A nonresident must pay the shelter charges and have his animal
immunized against rabies if it has not had this treatment within the past
twelve (12) months. (Ord. 747 §2, 1994)
6.12.030: ADOPTION OF DOGS AND CATS:
A.   Qualifications For Adoption:
   1.   Apparent good health;
   2.   Not vicious;
   3.   Immunized;
   4.   Licensed (when place of residence is within the city);
   5.   Spayed or neutered;
   6.   In the case of a licensed dog or cat turned in at the shelter by the
owner of record or his authorized representative, the owner or representative
must give a release in writing for the animal's disposal or adoption;
   7.   In the case of a licensed dog or cat picked up by the animal control
officer as a stray or while running at large, or in response to a complaint,
the animal will not be available for adoption (other qualifications being met)
until the prescribed waiting period of seventy two (72) hours has expired and
the owner of record has failed to claim such animal; or the owner has given
written consent to the adopter for the animal's adoption; or the adopter (after
the waiting period) certifies that his efforts to locate the owner were
unsuccessful;
   8.   In the case of an unlicensed animal picked up by an animal control
officer as a stray or while running at large, or in response to a complaint,
the animal will not be available for adoption (other qualifications being met)
until the prescribed waiting period of seventy two (72) hours has expired and
the owner has failed to claim it.
B.   Adoption Fees: The adopter will be required to pay an adoption deposit as
set by the council. All payments will be paid to the city clerk. From such
deposit, the operating veterinarian shall be paid for any immunization or
spaying or neutering services where required, as well as any licensing fees.
The balance, if any, shall be accounted for according to state law or the
direction of the council. (Ord. 999 §8, 2004: Ord. 747 §3, 1994)
6.12.040: ADOPTION OF CATS:
(Rep. by Ord. 999 §9, 2004)
6.12.050: SHELTER HOURS FOR ADOPTIONS:
The city animal shelter will be open to the public for the claiming or adoption
of animals as follows: Monday through Friday, ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. to four
o'clock (4:00) P.M. (Ord. 747 §5, 1994)
6.12.060: HOLDING ANIMAL IN SHELTER:
An animal considered by the control officer to be suitable for adoption may be
held in the shelter for seven (7) calendar days following the mandatory
retention period if not claimed by the owner during the retention period. (Ord.
747 §6, 1994)
CHAPTER 6.13
EXOTIC WILDLIFE ABATEMENT
SECTION:
6.13.010: Short Title
6.13.020: Citation Of Authorities
6.13.030: Legislative Findings, Purpose And Intent
6.13.040: Definitions
6.13.050: Public Nuisance
6.13.060: Violations And Penalties
6.13.070: Registration Required
6.13.080: Exemptions
6.13.090: This Chapter Not Exclusive Legal Remedy
6.13.100: Running At Large
6.13.110: Reserved
6.13.120: Impoundment
6.13.130: List Of Institutions Qualified To Impound
6.13.140: Reserved
6.13.150: Procedure For Abatement Of Public Nuisances
6.13.160: Reserved
6.13.170: Enforcement Of This Chapter
6.13.180: Failure To Appear In Response To Citation
6.13.190: Right Of Entry
6.13.010: SHORT TITLE:
The provisions of this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the WARR
ACRES EXOTIC WILDLIFE ABATEMENT ORDINANCE. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.020: CITATION OF AUTHORITIES:
The provisions of this chapter are being enacted pursuant to the authority of
11 Oklahoma Statutes section 22-121 and the authority of 50 Oklahoma Statutes
sections 16 and 17. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.030: LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS, PURPOSE AND INTENT:
A.   The council hereby makes the following findings:
   1.   That "exotic wildlife", as defined in this chapter, when kept or
harbored within the corporate limits of the city of Warr Acres ("the city"),
poses a serious threat to the health, safety and/or general welfare of the
residents of this community by virtue of the physical attributes, natural
behaviors, habits, modes of life, and/or natural instincts of such animals; and
   2.   That exotic wildlife poses a serious threat to the health, safety and/
or welfare of the residents of the city because such animals, due to the
characteristics of their species, are incapable of being domesticated and
because the proper and safe keeping of such animals requires the exercise of
professional art, force, and/or skill; and
   3.   That keeping or harboring of exotic wildlife within the city, outside
of control by persons or organizations listed in section
6.13.080 of this chapter, can and often does render certain residents of this
community insecure in their daily lives and fearful for their health, safety
and/or general welfare and is an unwarranted and unnecessary intrusion into the
lives of such residents; and
   4.   That numerous incidents have been documented in other cities around the
United States and the world of exotic wildlife getting out of control and
killing, maiming, or injuring human beings; and
   5.   That even when in a juvenile stage of life, exotic wildlife can
seriously injure human beings, especially children, and can kill or seriously
injure animals such as domestic dogs, cats, and/or birds being kept by humans
as pets; and
   6.   That certain exotic wildlife, such as nonhuman primates, poses a threat
of disease to human beings due to their close biological relationship with
humans; and
   7.   That based upon the foregoing findings, it is clear that exotic
wildlife poses a serious hazard to the public health, safety and/or general
welfare of the citizens of this community and that such wildlife must be
prohibited outside the control of those persons or organizations listed in
section
6.13.080 of this chapter.
B.   Based upon the foregoing findings, as set forth in subsections A1 through
A7, inclusive, of this section, council states that the public purposes and the
intent of the provisions of this chapter are to legally prevent the keeping or
harboring of exotic wildlife within the city, to summarily impound exotic
wildlife within the city under certain circumstances, and, if necessary, to
abate by civil action in district court the keeping or harboring of exotic
wildlife within the city. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.040: DEFINITIONS:
A.   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall
have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context
clearly indicates a different meaning:
   ANIMAL: A member of the animal kingdom.
   ANIMAL CONTROL DEPARTMENT: The Warr Acres animal control department.
   ANIMAL CONTROL OFFICER: The person appointed and designated by the mayor or
police chief as the director of the animal welfare department.
   EXOTIC WILDLIFE: Any of the following animals:
   1.   A lion, tiger, leopard, panther, cougar, bobcat, ocelot, cheetah,
margay, mountain lion, lynx, jaguar, jaguarundi, or any and all other felines
(family Felidae), except the domestic cat (species Felis domesticus);
   2.   A grizzly bear, black bear, or any and all other bears (family
Ursidae);
   3.   A wolf, coyote, jackal, hyena, or any and all other canines (family
Canidae), except the domestic dog (species Canis familiaris) or the fox;
   4.   Any and all venomous reptiles (venomous members of the class Reptilia),
including, without limitation, Gila monsters (species Heloderma suspectum),
beaded lizards (species Heloderma horridum), and venomous snakes (venomous
members of the suborder Serpentes);
   5.   Any anaconda (species Eunectes murinus);
   6.   Any and all crocodiles, caimans, or alligators (family Crocodilia);
provided, alligators kept in a secure container by a currently established
commercial business on commercially zoned land pursuant to a state commercial
breeder's license shall be excluded from this definition;
   7.   Gorillas, orangutans, baboons, macaques or chimpanzees; or any nonhuman
primate (order Primata) that is not licensed pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter; or any nonhuman primate (order Primata) that tests positive for
tuberculosis or herpes B; provided, macaques that were kept or harbored within
the city limits prior to the effective date hereof, and that are duly licensed
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be excluded from this
definition;
   8.   Cassowaries (genus Casuarius); or
   9.   Any crossbreed or hybrid of any two (2) animals defined as "exotic
wildlife" in subsections A1 through A8, inclusive, of this section.
Provided, exotic wildlife shall not include native wildlife that is living in
the wild and is not owned or possessed or intentionally being kept by any
person.
   NATIVE WILDLIFE: Any and all species of wildlife that are indigenous to or
occur naturally within the state of Oklahoma.
B.   The mayor, the police chief and the animal control officer shall have no
power to add animals to the definition of "exotic wildlife" as set forth above,
and only the animals specified above shall be considered exotic wildlife for
purposes of this chapter; provided, however, the mayor or police chief may
recommend to the council of the city that animals be added to the definition of
"exotic wildlife" as specified above if any mammal, reptile, bird, or other
animal is found to pose a serious threat to the public health, safety and/or
general welfare of the residents of the city; provided, further, no such
additions shall be made by council except upon public notice and public hearing
as otherwise required for the formal adoption of a city ordinance. (Ord. 999
§10, 2004)
6.13.050: PUBLIC NUISANCE:
Keeping or harboring exotic wildlife declared a public nuisance; use of land
for keeping or harboring exotic wildlife declared a public nuisance; keeping or
harboring exotic wildlife prohibited; use of land for keeping or harboring
exotic wildlife prohibited.
A.   The keeping or harboring of exotic wildlife within the corporate limits of
the city is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance per se.
B.   The use of any land within the corporate limits of the city to keep or
harbor exotic wildlife is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance per
se.
C.   The keeping or harboring of exotic wildlife within the corporate limits of
the city is hereby prohibited.
D.   The use of any land within the corporate limits of the city to keep or
harbor exotic wildlife is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.060: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
A.   Any person found keeping or harboring exotic wildlife in violation of this
chapter shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), and
costs. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense and
shall be subject to a separate fine and costs as provided herein.
B.   Any person who permits or allows any land owned or leased by him/her to be
used for keeping or harboring any exotic wildlife in violation of this chapter
shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be
subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), and costs. Each
day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be
subject to a separate fine and costs as provided herein. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.070: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
A.   Any person keeping or harboring exotic wildlife within the city on the
effective date hereof shall register with the animal control department by no
later than July 1, 2005. Such registration shall include the name, address, and
telephone number of the person keeping or harboring such wildlife, a list of
all such animals being kept or harbored, and a description of the location or
locations where and the conditions under which such animals are being kept or
harbored. The registration shall also include photographs sufficient to
demonstrate to the superintendent that such animals are being adequately
restrained. The registration shall also include the name and address of all
owners or then current lessees of any land upon which such animals are being
kept or harbored.
B.   Any person keeping or harboring exotic wildlife within the city at the
time this chapter becomes effective shall remove all such wildlife from the
city by not later than July 1, 2005.
C.   Any person who fails to register, as required by subsection A of this
section, or who fails to remove from the city any exotic wildlife being kept or
harbored by him or her, as required by subsection B of this section, shall be
deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a
fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), and costs. Each day a
violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be subject to
a separate fine and costs as provided herein.
D.   Any person who permits or allows land owned or leased by him/her to be
used for the keeping or harboring of any exotic wildlife in violation of
subsection C of this section shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred
dollars ($200.00), and costs. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a
separate offense and shall be subject to a separate fine and costs as provided
herein. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.080: EXEMPTIONS:
The following persons or organizations shall be exempt from the provisions of
this chapter:
A.   The Warr Acres animal control department;
B.   Any circus appearing in the city of Warr Acres for less than thirty (30)
days;
C.   Any agency or official of the federal, state or local government acting in
an official capacity;
D.   A licensed veterinarian while providing treatment for exotic wildlife;
E.   A duly licensed and authorized research facility, including, without
limitation, a university or college research facility; and
F.   Nature parks or centers professionally qualified to handle exotic animals
when presenting educational programs or performing other public services within
the city. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.090: THIS CHAPTER NOT EXCLUSIVE LEGAL REMEDY:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the filing and
prosecution of any other criminal charges and/or any other civil actions
allowed by law or to prohibit the allowance of any other legal remedies allowed
by law. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.100: RUNNING AT LARGE:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person keeping or harboring any lion, tiger,
leopard, panther, cougar, bobcat, ocelot, cheetah, margay, mountain lion, lynx,
jaguar, or jaguarundi pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to allow such
animal to run at large within the corporate limits of the city.
B.   Any person violating the provisions of subsection A of this section shall
be deemed guilty of an offense. Each day such offense occurs or continues shall
constitute a separate violation.
C.   The first violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute an
offense, and any person convicted of such first offense shall be subject to a
fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus costs. The second and
any subsequent violations of the provisions of this section shall also
constitute an offense, and any person convicted of any such second or
subsequent offense or offenses shall be subject to a fine not exceeding seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus costs. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.110: RESERVED:
(Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.120: IMPOUNDMENT:
A.   If at any time a particular animal defined in this chapter as "exotic
wildlife" poses an imminent hazard to public health or safety by reason of its
running at large, being diseased, or being inadequately restrained by the
person keeping or harboring it, the animal control officer is authorized to
summarily impound the animal to a shelter designated by the animal control
officer and approved by the police chief and to therein confine the animal in a
humane manner; provided, prior to seizure and impoundment hereunder of animals
that are diseased or inadequately restrained, the animal control officer shall
obtain a search warrant from the court authorizing such seizure and
impoundment, which search warrant, if issued, shall be based on facts or
circumstances demonstrating that there is probable or reasonable cause to
believe that diseased or inadequately restrained wildlife exists and is present
on particular property; provided, further, no such search warrant shall be
required if immediate seizure and impoundment of a diseased or inadequately
restrained animal is necessary due to an emergency that threatens the public
health or safety.
B.   The owner of any exotic wildlife summarily impounded pursuant to
subsection A of this section shall be given written notice of such impoundment
within seventy two (72) hours after the impoundment. Notice shall be given by
personal delivery to the owner or by certified mail, return receipt requested,
to the last known address of such owner; provided, if the identity of the owner
is unknown and cannot be reasonably ascertained, or if the whereabouts or
mailing address of the owner is unknown and cannot reasonably be ascertained,
notice may be given by publication, one time, in a newspaper of general
circulation within the city. The notice shall state that such animal or animals
have been summarily impounded and shall describe the circumstances surrounding
the impoundment. The notice shall also state that the owner has only a
specified period of time within which to reclaim such animal and that such
animal shall be disposed of by the animal control officer if not timely
reclaimed, as provided by subsection C of this section.
C.   The owner of any exotic wildlife summarily impounded pursuant to
subsection A of this section may reclaim the animal within five (5) working
days from the date of the notice required by subsection B of this section;
provided, such reclamation shall be conditioned upon an adequate showing by the
owner that the animal will be kept at a lawful location, upon an adequate
showing that a diseased animal will be provided all necessary veterinary care,
upon a showing that the animal will be adequately restrained and upon the
payment of all impoundment, custody, veterinary fees and/or other costs related
to the impoundment, keeping and/or care of such animal, as determined by the
police chief or his/her designee.
D.   In the event any exotic wildlife summarily impounded pursuant to
subsection A of this section is not reclaimed by the owner thereof within five
(5) working days after the date of the notice required by subsection B of this
section, such animal shall be deemed to have been abandoned by its owner. Upon
such abandonment, the animal control officer shall have the authority and
option to remove the animal from the shelter and place the animal with a duly
licensed wildlife refuge, sanctuary, habitat or area or with a qualified person
or institution that can provide assurance that the animal will be properly
protected and cared for, with such placement to be approved by the mayor, or to
humanely dispose of said animal, with such disposal to be approved by the
mayor.
E.   For purposes of this section, the term "inadequately restrained" shall
mean and refer to a mode or method of keeping or harboring exotic wildlife that
may not be sufficient to prevent such wildlife from escaping captivity and/or
threatening humans, domestic animals or livestock. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.130: LIST OF INSTITUTIONS QUALIFIED TO IMPOUND:
The animal control officer is hereby directed to prepare a list of available
institutions with the means, knowledge, training and facilities to capture,
keep, harbor, board and dispose of any exotic wildlife that may be impounded
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. Such list shall be prepared with
the advice and concurrence of the executive director/CEO of the Oklahoma City
zoological park and shall be approved by the mayor. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.140: RESERVED:
(Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.150: PROCEDURE FOR ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES:
To abate the public nuisances declared by this chapter, the mayor or his/her
designee, and the municipal counselor or his/her designee, acting on behalf of
the city of Warr Acres, shall have the option to bring a civil action in
district court as authorized by 50 Oklahoma Statutes section 17. The following
procedures shall be adhered to:
A.   Before a civil action for abatement of a public nuisance is filed in
district court, as authorized by 50 Oklahoma Statutes section 17 and the
provisions of this section, the mayor or his/her designee, on behalf of the
city, shall serve the owner and/or keeper of any exotic wildlife and the owner
and/or lessee of record, if any, of any land upon which such exotic wildlife is
being kept or harbored, with a written statement demanding that such persons
immediately cause the removal of such wildlife from such land and from the
corporate limits of the city.
B.   The written statement to the owner and/or keeper of any exotic wildlife
and to the owner and/or lessee of record, if any, of any land where such
wildlife is being kept or harbored, as required by subsection A of this
section, shall contain the following information:
   1.   A statement that certain exotic wildlife is being kept or harbored on
certain land within the city, with such wildlife being identified and such land
being identified by a street address and/or legal description sufficient for
the owner and/or keeper of the exotic wildlife and the owner and/or lessee of
record of the land to locate the property on which the exotic wildlife is
located; and
   2.   A statement that the keeping or harboring of exotic wildlife within the
city has been declared a public nuisance per se pursuant to this chapter and is
in violation of this chapter; and
   3.   A statement that the use of any land within the city to keep or harbor
exotic wildlife has been declared a public nuisance per se pursuant to this
chapter and is in violation of this chapter; and
   4.   A statement ordering the owner and/or keeper of such wildlife, and the
owner and/or lessee of record, if any, of the land on which such wildlife is
being kept, to immediately abate the public nuisance and to immediately remove
the exotic wildlife permanently from such land and from the corporate limits of
the city.
C.   Service of the written statement required by this section shall be by
personal delivery to the owner and/or keeper of the exotic wildlife, and to the
owner and/or lessee of record, if any, of such land, or by certified mail,
return receipt requested, to the last known address of such owner and/or keeper
and landowner and/or lessee of record. Proof of such personal delivery or
certified mailing shall be kept in the regularly maintained files of the city.
If service of the written statement cannot be made by personal delivery or by
certified mail, return receipt requested, service of said statement shall be by
posting a copy of the statement on the property used for keeping or harboring
the exotic wildlife and/or by publication, as defined in 11 Oklahoma Statutes
section 1-102(8), once at least ten (10) days prior to any action by the city
pursuant to the provisions of this section or as otherwise allowed by law.
D.   If the order stated in the written statement required by subsection B4 of
this section is not complied with in full by the deadline set forth therein,
the mayor or his/her designee, and/or the municipal counselor or his/her
designee, in the name of the city, are hereby authorized to bring a civil
action in district court pursuant to 50 Oklahoma Statutes section 17 to abate a
public nuisance per se against any owner and/or keeper of such wildlife and/or
against any owner and/or lessee of record of any land being used for the
keeping or harboring of such wildlife. Said city officers are hereby further
authorized to seek any legal remedies in such civil action as may be allowed by
law.
E.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the mayor or his/her
designee, and/or the municipal counselor or his/her designee, in the name of
the city, are hereby authorized to assert a civil action in district court,
pursuant to 50 Oklahoma Statutes section 17, for abatement of exotic wildlife
as a public nuisance per se as a counterclaim against any person or persons
challenging the validity or applicability of this chapter without first giving
the notice otherwise required by subsections A through C, inclusive, of this
section. In such counterclaim said city officers may seek any legal remedies as
may be allowed by law in a civil action pursuant to 50 Oklahoma Statutes
section 17 for abatement of a public nuisance. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.160: RESERVED:
(Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.170: ENFORCEMENT OF THIS CHAPTER:
A.   The animal control officer, or his representative, are authorized to
enforce the provisions of this chapter. In carrying out such duties, an animal
control officer may issue a citation to any violator to appear in municipal
court, in compliance with the provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes sections 27-
117 and 27-117.1.
B.   In issuing a citation, the animal control officer shall proceed as
follows:
   1.   The officer shall prepare a written citation to appear in municipal
court containing the name and address of the cited person, the nature, location
and date of the alleged offense, and the time and date of the municipal court
appearance. Unless the person requests an earlier date, the time specified in
the citation to appear shall be at least five (5) days after the issuance of
the citation.
   2.   The citation, and any copies thereof, shall be signed by the cited
person and one signed copy thereof shall be given to him.
   3.   The officer shall thereupon release the cited person from custody.
   4.   The officer shall file one copy of the citation with the municipal
court within three (3) days after issuing the citation. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
6.13.180: FAILURE TO APPEAR IN RESPONSE TO CITATION:
If a person fails to appear in response to a citation issued pursuant to this
chapter, a warrant for his arrest shall be issued. Any person who wilfully
fails to appear in response to a citation is guilty of an offense. (Ord. 999
§10, 2004)
6.13.190: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
For the purpose of carrying out and enforcing the provisions of this chapter,
the animal control officer shall have authority to enter upon private premises
for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this chapter, provided such
entry is made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 999 §10, 2004)
