9.42.010: CERTAIN ACTS DEEMED OFFENSES:
Any person who conducts himself in a riotous or disorderly manner, or who
openly uses profane or indecent language, or who indecently exposes his or her
person, or who is guilty of any lewd or lascivious conduct in public, or who
commits any nuisance upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in
the city is guilty of an offense. (Prior code §13-27)
CHAPTER 9.44
DISTURBING THE PEACE 2
SECTION:
9.44.010: Disturbing Assemblies Or Funerals
9.44.020: Noise, Abusive Language Or Fighting
9.44.030: Warning Devices
9.44.040: Exceptions
9.44.050: Unusual Noises For Advertising
 
Notes
2 2. 21 OS § 1361 et seq.
9.44.010: DISTURBING ASSEMBLIES OR FUNERALS:
Any person who, in this city, disturbs or disquiets any congregation or
assembly or funeral met for religious worship, or for any other lawful purpose,
by making a noise or by rude or indecent behavior or profane discourses within
their place of worship, or so near the same as to disturb the order or
solemnity of the meeting, or disturbs any lawful assemblage of people by rude
or indecent behavior or otherwise, is guilty of an offense. Any person who
wilfully disturbs, interrupts or disquiets any assemblage of people for the
purpose of any funeral, or who, without authority of law, obstructs or detains
any person or persons engaged in carrying or accompanying any dead body of a
human being to a place of burial is guilty, upon conviction, of an offense.
(Prior code §13-30)
9.44.020: NOISE, ABUSIVE LANGUAGE OR FIGHTING:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to make any loud or unusual noise
or to use any abusive, violent, obscene or profane language, or to threaten to
fight, quarrel, challenge to fight, or to fight, or to shoot any firearms or
brandish the same, which by reason of said act, disturbs, either by day or
night, the peace and quiet of the city, or any part thereof, or any persons
therein, or annoys the inhabitants thereof. (Prior code §13-23)
9.44.030: WARNING DEVICES:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to sound, use, or operate any
horn, bell, whistle, or other warning device on any motor vehicle within the
city limits for any purpose other than as a warning device in traffic on any
day between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
The use of horns, bells, whistles or other warning devices as a means of
attracting the attention of persons in residences or places of business, during
the hours set forth in this section, is unlawful and constitutes a nuisance,
and any person so doing shall be deemed to have committed an offense against
the ordinances of the city. (Prior code §13-24)
9.44.040: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of section
9.44.030 of this chapter shall not be deemed to apply to music furnished by any
person, firm or corporation for the exclusive enjoyment of persons actually
upon the premises or within the place of business of such person, firm or
corporation, provided the music so furnished is not sufficiently loud or
offensive as to annoy the public generally or to disturb the peace; provided,
further, that no loudspeaker located upon any premises outside walls of any
building located thereon shall be operated between the hours of ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Prior code §13-25)
9.44.050: UNUSUAL NOISES FOR ADVERTISING:
It is unlawful and an offense, in the city, to make, or persist in making, in
any street or upon any private property, any unnecessary, unusual or
objectionable noise, calculated to or resulting in the annoyance of other
persons, or ringing of bells to attract attention to auctions, or for other
purposes. The practice ordinarily known as "barking", used as calling the
attention of persons to certain businesses, whether in or near the street, is
expressly forbidden as an offense. (Prior code §13-26)
CHAPTER 9.46
RIOT 2
SECTION:
9.46.010: Committing And Permitting
 
Notes
2 2. 21 OS §§ 1311 et seq., 1321.1 et seq., 1321.9.
9.46.010: COMMITTING AND PERMITTING:
Any three (3) or more persons who, in this city, assemble together, or act in
concert, to do any unlawful act with force or violence against the property of
this city, or the person or property of another, or against the peace or to the
terror of others, and who make any movement or preparation therefor, and every
person present at such meeting or assembly who does not endeavor to prevent the
commission or perpetration of such unlawful act, is guilty of an offense.
(Prior code §13-31)
V.   OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 1
CHAPTER 9.54
CITY PROPERTY 2
SECTION:
9.54.010: Trespassing On Or Taking Possession Of
9.54.020: Injury To Streets, Curbs Or Alleys
9.54.030: Mutilation Or Removal Of Signs
9.54.040: Reward For Information
9.54.050: Penalties For Violating Section 9.54.030 Of This Chapter
 
Notes
1 1. 21 OS part VII.
2 2. 11 OS § 660; 21 OS §§ 1753, 1754.
9.54.010: TRESPASSING ON OR TAKING POSSESSION OF:
Any person who unlawfully takes possession of any property, real or personal,
belonging to the city, or to the possession of which the city is entitled, or
who commits any wilful trespass thereon, or who unlawfully withholds the
possession thereof from the city is guilty of an offense. The unlawful
withholding of the possession of any property mentioned in this section, after
demand therefor has been made under the direction of the council, is a separate
and new offense for every day the possession is withheld after such demand, and
shall be punished in like manner as provided in this title. (Prior code §13-59)
9.54.020: INJURY TO STREETS, CURBS OR ALLEYS:
Any person who, in the city, wilfully or wantonly cuts, breaks or removes, or
in any manner displaces any curbing, guttering, street crossing, paved streets
or alleys, or any part thereof, or who recklessly or intentionally drives any
car, truck, tractor, or wagon loaded with asphalt materials, lumber, or
building materials of any kind into or on the curbing or concrete guttering of
any paved street is guilty of an offense. (Prior code §13-60)
9.54.030: MUTILATION OR REMOVAL OF SIGNS:
It is an offense for any person to mutilate, remove or destroy any signs put up
by the city, or any other public property. (Prior code §13-96)
9.54.040: REWARD FOR INFORMATION:
Any person who furnishes information and appears against a person violating the
terms of section
9.54.030 of this chapter, shall be entitled to receive and shall receive a
reward in the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) payable from an appropriation of the
city made for that purpose. (Prior code §13-98)
9.54.050: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATING SECTION 9.54.030 OF THIS CHAPTER:
Persons convicted of violating the provisions of section
9.54.030 of this chapter shall be punished by a monetary fine in the amount of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs, plus restitution at the court's
discretion. (Ord. 906 §4, 2000: Ord. 657 §2, 1987)
CHAPTER 9.56
TRESPASSING AND VANDALISM 2
SECTION:
9.56.010: Street Trees Or Public Ways
9.56.020: Occupancy Of Land; Unauthorized
9.56.030: Unauthorized Entry
9.56.040: Parking Or Use Of Land; Unauthorized
9.56.045: Acts Of Trespassing
9.56.050: Penalty
 
Notes
2 2. 21 OS § 1835.
9.56.010: STREET TREES OR PUBLIC WAYS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to wilfully or wantonly cut,
deface or in any way injure any tree or sapling standing or growing in any of
the streets, alleys or public places within the city, or to attach any
guywires, telephone, telegraph or electric wires, or any wire to any live tree,
or to dig any hole, ditch or trench in any public street, road, avenue or alley
or other public premises or ground within, belonging to or under the
supervision or control of the city, or to take or remove any dirt, earth or any
substance therefrom, or to cut, break or otherwise injure any pavement, curb or
gutter therein or to connect any driveway thereto without first securing
permission from the city inspector to do so, and all such digging, removing, or
driveway connection shall be done under the supervision of the street and
superintendent or city engineer. (Prior code §17-1)
9.56.020: OCCUPANCY OF LAND; UNAUTHORIZED:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to intrude, enter or squat upon
any lot or piece of land within the city without license or authority from the
owner thereof, or to erect or occupy thereon any hut, hovel, shanty, or other
structure whatever without such license or authority; or to erect or occupy
within the bounds of any street, alley or avenue of the city any hut, hovel,
shanty, or other structure whatever. (Prior code §17-2)
9.56.030: UNAUTHORIZED ENTRY:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to enter upon the property of
another or into an area or structure on such property (whether such property,
area or structure is public or private) when such entrance is plainly forbidden
by signs or otherwise or when the property, area or structure is enclosed,
except when such entrance is in the line of duty, or with the expressed or
tacit consent of the owner or person in charge, or otherwise by authority of
law or ordinance. (Prior code §17-3)
9.56.040: PARKING OR USE OF LAND; UNAUTHORIZED:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to park an automobile or other
vehicle, or to place any structure or object on the driveway, yard or property
of another without the expressed or tacit consent by the owner or person in
charge thereof, or when necessary for the performance of a duty. (Prior code
§17-4)
9.56.045: ACTS OF TRESPASSING:
A.   No person shall trespass on the real property of another, either public or
private. The term "public property" means any property dedicated to public use
over which the federal, state, or municipal governments, or any political
subdivision thereof, exercises dominion or control. The term "private property"
means any property other than public property. The term "trespass" as used in
this section shall be defined and mean the following acts:
   1.   Each and every actual entry upon the premises of an owner or other
person in lawful possession of the premises without the express or implied
consent of the owner or other person in lawful possession;
   2.   Each and every entry upon real property contrary to the provisions of
any posted sign or published warning to stay out of or off the premises or
otherwise regulates entry or use of the property;
   3.   Remaining upon the premises of an owner or other person in lawful
possession after having been told or directed to leave the premises by the
owner, or an agent or employee of the owner or other person in lawful
possession of the premises;
   4.   Remaining on private property at any time other than during posted
hours of business operation after having been directed to vacate the premises
by a police officer; provided that the provision of this subsection shall not
apply to persons, including employees, whose presence upon such premises is
authorized by the owner or by a person in lawful possession of such premises,
nor shall the provisions of this subsection apply unless the hours of business
operation are posted upon such premises;
   5.   Returning to private property before the posted time of opening for
business operation on the next business day after having been directed to
vacate the premises under the terms of subsection A4 of this section;
   6.   Entering or remaining upon any public or private property wherein a
healthcare or treatment facility is located when such person enters or remains
therein in defiance of an order not to enter or direction to leave such
premises personally communicated to such person by the owner or operator of the
healthcare facility or other authorized person;
   7.   Remaining on any property owned or in possession of the public school
system or other institution devoted to the education of children from preschool
through twelfth grade, after such person has been requested to leave or vacate
school premises by any faculty member, principal, authorized security guard or
police officer.
B.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction
be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 726 §1, 1992)
9.56.050: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter is guilty of an offense and
each violation shall be considered a separate offense; and upon conviction of
any offense, any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be
punished by a fine as set by the court for each offense. (Ord. 431 §1, 1976:
prior code §17-5)
CHAPTER 9.58
MOLESTING PROPERTY 2
SECTION:
9.58.010: Utility Or City Property
9.58.020: Automobiles Or Machinery Of Others
9.58.030: Malicious Mischief
 
Notes
2 2. 21 OS §§ 1787, 1788, 1786.
9.58.010: UTILITY OR CITY PROPERTY:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person in the city to alter, remove,
molest or tamper with any wire, fixture, pipe, conduit, meter or other
appliance of any waterworks plant, gas, electrical, telephone, or telegraph
company, or other company, association or person, operating a similar business
or calling, or to tap any such supply wires or pipes, or to fraudulently or
secretly extract or use any water, electricity or gas of such plant or company,
or to uncover or open up any manhole or other opening to any such property, or
to uncover or open up any manhole or other opening to any sewer, unless the
person doing so is an employee of the company or city or under authority and
direction to do so. It is unlawful and an offense for any person in the city to
leave any manhole or other opening so opened without replacing the fixtures and
appliances thereto in their proper place and position. (Prior code §13-35)
9.58.020: AUTOMOBILES OR MACHINERY OF OTHERS:
From and after the passage of the ordinance codified herein, it is unlawful for
any person or persons to loiter in or upon any automobile or motor vehicle, or
to molest, drive or attempt to drive any automobile for joyriding or any other
purpose, or to meddle with any machinery or appliances thereof, without the
consent of the owner of such automobile or motor vehicle. (Prior code §13-36)
9.58.030: MALICIOUS MISCHIEF:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to maliciously or intentionally
injure, deface or destroy any real or personal property not his own, and upon
conviction thereof, he or she shall be fined as provided by this code. (Ord.
477 §1, 1978)
CHAPTER 9.60
FLOODLIGHTS
SECTION:
9.60.010: Requirements 
9.60.010: REQUIREMENTS:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person, firm or corporation to have, keep
or maintain, or cause or permit to be kept or maintained, either as the owner
or as the one in possession or in charge thereof, any floodlight or any other
reflector type light on any property in the city in such a manner that the
light therefrom is unnecessarily thrown into the residence of any person or
persons in the vicinity where the light is located, so as to constitute, while
the light is on, a continuous annoyance to the person or persons occupying the
residence into which the light is thrown. (Prior code §13-58)
CHAPTER 9.62
LARCENY 2
SECTION:
9.62.010: Defined
9.62.020: Crimes Against Rented Or Leased Personal Property
 
Notes
2 2. 21 OS ch. 68.
9.62.010: DEFINED:
It is unlawful and an offense to commit larceny within the City. "Larceny" is
defined as taking the private property of another, the value of which does not
exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), accomplished by fraud or stealth, with
the intent to deprive the other thereof. (Ord. 1179, 2017)
9.62.020:  CRIMES AGAINST RENTED OR LEASED PERSONAL PROPERTY:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person who is given the temporary right to
possess and use any personal property by way of any lease or rental agreement,
who, after the term of such agreement has expired, willfully fails to return
possession of such property to its rightful owner. Any person found guilty of a
violation of this division shall be punished as provided in section
9.90.010 .
   B.   It is unlawful for any person to lease or rent for any period of time
whatsoever, any motor vehicle, and, with the intent to cheat or defraud, who
pays the fees for such lease or rental by means of a false, bogus, or worthless
check written for the sum of less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Any
person found guilty of a violation of this division shall be punished by a fine
not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court costs and fees. (Ord.
1194, 2019)
CHAPTER 9.64
OTHER OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY RIGHTS
SECTION:
9.64.010: Anonymous Campaign Literature
9.64.020: Use Of City Address And Phone Numbers
9.64.030: Misleading Communications
9.64.040: Penalty
9.64.010: ANONYMOUS CAMPAIGN LITERATURE:
A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership,
organization, or association to cause to be broadcast, written, printed,
posted, or distributed a statement, circular, poster, or advertisement which is
designed to influence the voters on the nomination or election of a candidate
or to influence the voters on any constitutional or statutory amendment or on
any other issue in a state, county, city, or school district election, or to
influence the vote of any member of the legislature, unless there appears in a
conspicuous place upon such circular, poster, or advertisement, or within a
broadcast statement, either the name and address of the person who paid for the
communication, if an individual, or the name and address of the president,
chairman, or secretary, or of two (2) officers of the organization, if an
organization, which paid for the communication.
B.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to material purchased
before the effective date hereof; provided, that proof of purchase can be
properly documented. The provisions of this section shall not apply to bumper
stickers, pins, buttons, and other small items upon which the required
information cannot be conveniently printed. The provisions of this section
shall not apply to skywriting, water towers, or other means of displaying of
such a nature that the inclusion of the required information would be
impractical. Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to any matter
broadcast by the electronic media or thing published in any newspaper,
magazine, or journal recognized and circulating as such, which matter is
broadcast by the electronic media or published by such newspaper, magazine, or
journal on its own behalf and upon its own responsibility and for which it
shall not charge or receive any compensation whatsoever, nor shall the
provisions of this section apply to any publication issued by any legally
constituted election officials in the performance of their duties.
C.   Persons violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, shall be assessed a fine in the amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00), plus court and related costs. (Ord. 1048 §2, 2008)
9.64.020: USE OF CITY ADDRESS AND PHONE NUMBERS:
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, firm, corporation,
partnership, organization, association or entity of any kind to use or to
incorporate the official address, phone numbers, city seal, logo, or any other
identifying information of the city in any written, posted or distributed
statement, circular, poster, advertisement, document, paper, or verbal or
electronic communication of any kind which is, or which contains material that
is, designed to influence voters on the nomination or election of a candidate
or to influence voters on any matter requiring a vote of the qualified voters
of the city or state to approve or disapprove any issue or question presented.
The use of disclaimers of any kind shall not excuse a violation of this
section. (Ord. 1065 §1, 2009)
9.64.030: MISLEADING COMMUNICATIONS:
It shall be a violation of this section for any person, firm, corporation,
partnership, organization, association or entity of any kind to make any
communication of any kind, whether written, verbal, or electronic, with the
intent to cause the recipient of such communication to believe that such
communication is an official communication originated or endorsed by the city.
The use of disclaimers of any kind shall not excuse a violation of this
section. (Ord. 1065 §1, 2009)
9.64.040: PENALTY:
A violation of the provisions of section
9.64.020 or
9.64.030 of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense plus court costs and fees. Each
separate copy or instance of any communication in violation, whether written,
electronic, or verbal, shall be considered a separate offense. (Ord. 1065 §1,
2009)
VI.   CONSUMER PROTECTION
CHAPTER 9.70
CONFIDENCE GAMES
SECTION:
9.70.010: Certain Acts Deemed Unlawful
9.70.010: CERTAIN ACTS DEEMED UNLAWFUL:
It is unlawful and an offense in the city for any person to:
A.   Play at or attempt to play at any game commonly known as a "confidence
game";
B.   Keep or permit to be kept or operated in any room, tent or other place
under his control, any confidence game, or any trick, device or game, whether
ordinarily known as a confidence game or not, in which, or by which, any person
is or may be unsuspectingly tricked or duped into turning over or giving up
money or any other thing of value;
C.   By any false claim or representation of supernatural or occult powers,
secure possession of any money or other thing of value belonging to or owned by
another person;
D.   Induce or attempt to induce any person to give up or pay over any money or
other thing of value by any false representation or pretense, or in exchange
for any false or bogus coin or check, draft or other false evidence of value,
or in consideration of refraining from a lawful or unlawful arrest, or in
consideration of refraining from reporting any lawful or unlawful act to any
public official;
E.   Act as a solicitor, capper or procurer for any of the unlawful games or
businesses forbidden in this section, or in any manner persuade or attempt to
induce any person to play at or patronize any such unlawful game or business.
(Prior code §13-71)
CHAPTER 9.72
PRICE GOUGING
SECTION:
9.72.010: During Times Of Emergency Or Disaster
9.72.010: DURING TIMES OF EMERGENCY OR DISASTER:
A.   It is unlawful for any person, contractor, landlord, lessor, business or
other entity to sell or offer to sell or to rent or lease or offer to rent or
lease consumer food items, repair or reconstruction services, emergency or
medical supplies or gasoline, equipment or any shelter or housing, for an
amount which is ten (10) or more percent greater than the price charged by such
person, contractor, landlord, lessor, business or other entity for said goods
or services, equipment, or shelter or housing immediately prior to an emergency
or disaster, unless said person, contractor, landlord, lessor, business or
other entity can prove that the increase in price was directly attributable to
additional costs imposed on it by the supplier of the goods or for labor and
materials used to provide the service.
B.   For purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply:
   CONSUMER FOOD ITEM: Any article which is used or intended for use for food,
drink, confection or condiment by man or other animal.
   EMERGENCY: Any occurrence, or threat thereof, whether accidental, natural,
or caused by man, in war or peace, which results or may result in substantial
injury or harm to the population or substantial damage to or loss of property.
   EMERGENCY SUPPLIES: Shall include, but are not limited to, water,
flashlights, radios, lumber, plastic, generators, batteries, candles, blankets,
soaps and diapers.
   MEDICAL SUPPLIES: Includes, but is not limited to, prescription and
nonprescription drugs, bandages, gauzes and isopropyl alcohol.
   REPAIR OR RECONSTRUCTION SERVICES: Are those contractor services for repairs
to residential and commercial property of any type which are damaged as a
result of the disaster.
C.   Any person who shall be convicted of violating the provisions of this
section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof in the
municipal court shall be punished by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00)
plus court costs for each violation. (Ord. 885 §1, 1999: Ord. 880 §1, 1999)
VII.   OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS
CHAPTER 9.76
CURFEW
SECTION:
9.76.010: Title
9.76.020: Definitions
9.76.030: Curfew For Minors
9.76.040: Exceptions
9.76.050: Parental Responsibility
9.76.060: Police Procedures
9.76.070: Responsibility Of Owners Of Public Places
9.76.080: Violations And Penalties
9.76.010: TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the ORDINANCE REGULATING THE
PRESENCE AND CONDUCT OF MINORS ON STREETS AND PUBLIC PLACES. (Ord. 713 §1,
1991)
9.76.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words, and their
derivations, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to
them in this section:
CITY: The city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma County, Oklahoma.
MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18).
PARENT: Any person having legal custody of a minor: a) as a natural or adoptive
parent; b) as a legal guardian; c) as a person who stands in loco parentis; or
d) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground or place
to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business,
entertainment, or other lawful purpose. A public place shall include, but not
be limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe,
theater, drugstore, poolroom, shopping center and any other place devoted to
amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall also include the
front or immediate area of the above.
REMAIN: To stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets,
including the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) totaling four
(4) or more persons in which any minor involved would not be using the streets
for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home.
STREET: A way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as
a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel or in the case of a sidewalk
thereof for pedestrian travel. The term street includes the legal right of way,
including, but not limited to, the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the
sidewalks whether paved or unpaved, and any grass plots or other grounds found
within the legal right of way of a street.
TIME OF NIGHT: Referred to here is based upon the prevailing standard of time,
whether Central Standard Time or Central Daylight Saving Time, generally
observed at that hour by the public.
YEAR OF AGE: Continues from one birthday, such as the seventeenth to (but not
including the day of) the next, such as the eighteenth birthday, making it
clear that seventeen (17) or less years of age is herein treated as equivalent
to the phrase "under eighteen years of age". (Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.030: CURFEW FOR MINORS:
It is unlawful for any person less than eighteen (18) years of age to be or
remain in or upon the streets within the city at night during the period of
time ending at six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and beginning:
A.   At twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Sunday through Thursday; and
B.   At one o'clock (1:00) A.M. on Saturday morning and Sunday morning. (Ord.
1023 §1, 2006: Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.040: EXCEPTIONS:
In the following exceptional cases a minor on a city street during the
nocturnal hours for which section
9.76.030 of this chapter is intended to provide the maximum limits of
regulation shall not, however, be considered in violation of the curfew
ordinance:
A.   When accompanied by a parent of such minor;
B.   When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take
said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time
and purpose within a specified area;
C.   When exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States
constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the
right of assembly. Such minor shall evidence the bona fide of such exercise by
possessing a written communication, signed by a parent of such minor with their
home address and telephone number, specifying when, and where and in what
manner said minor will be on the streets at night (during hours when the curfew
ordinance is otherwise applicable to said minor) in the exercise of a first
amendment right specified in such communication;
D.   In case of reasonable necessity, but only if the minor has in said minor's
possession a written communication signed by the minor, countersigned by a
parent of such minor evidencing their home address and telephone number, and
establishing such reasonable necessity relating to specified streets at a
designated time for a described purpose including points of origin and
destination;
E.   When the minor is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor resides,
or on the sidewalk of either next door neighbor not communicating an objection
to the police officer;
F.   When returning home, by a direct route from (and within 30 minutes of the
termination of) a school activity, or an activity of a religious or a voluntary
association, provided the minor has a written communication in the minor's
possession, countersigned by the parent indicating the home address and
telephone number, the purpose of the event, when, where, and in what manner
said minor will be on the streets at night;
G.   When authorized, by regulation issued by the city council, in other
similar cases of reasonable necessity, similarly handled but adapted to
necessary nighttime activities of more minors than can readily be dealt with on
an individual special permit basis. Normally such regulation by the city
council permitting use of the streets should be issued sufficiently in advance
to permit appropriate publicity through news media and through other agencies
such as the schools, and shall define the activity, the scope of the use of the
streets permitted, the period of time involved not to extend more than thirty
(30) minutes beyond the time for termination of such activity, and the reason
necessary and is consistent with public interest and the purposes of the curfew
ordinance codified in this chapter;
H.   When the minor carries a certified card of employment, briefly identifying
the minor, the addresses of his home and his place of employment and his hours
of employment or carries a valid proof of employment which may include the
latest payroll receipt not over thirty (30) days old;
I.   When the minor is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle. This
contemplates normal travel. This clearly exempts bona fide interstate movement
through the city, particularly on normal routes. (Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.050: PARENTAL RESPONSIBILITY:
It is unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit
or by inefficient control to allow, such minor to be or remain upon any city
street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise
beyond the scope of, the curfew ordinance. The term "knowingly" includes
knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the
whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to
continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community
standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall, a
fortiori, be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the
activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. (Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.060: POLICE PROCEDURES:
A.   A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to
any minor on the streets or in or around a public place in prima facie
violation of the curfew ordinance, normally shall take the minor to the city
police station, or other places designated by the chief of police, where a
parent shall immediately be notified to come for such minor, whereupon they
shall be interrogated. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under
constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility
in the personnel then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial and
uniform enforcement, and recording, thus making available experienced
supervisory personnel, the best of facilities and access to information and
records. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a
police officer on the street shall in the first instance use his best judgment
in determining age.
B.   Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience
and may provide, inter alia, that the police officer may deliver to a parent
thereof a minor under appropriate circumstances, for example a minor of tender
age near home whose identity may readily be ascertained or are known.
C.   In any event such police officer shall within twenty four (24) hours file
a written report with the chief of police, or shall participate to the extent
of the information for which he is responsible; said report shall be treated
for purposes of juvenile records in accordance with state statutes.
D.   When a parent, immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor,
and the appropriate information has been recorded, the minor shall be released
to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to
take charge of the minor, then the minor shall be released to the juvenile
authorities, except to the extent that in accordance with police regulations,
approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the minor may temporarily be
entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will on behalf of a
parent assume the responsibility of caring for the minor pending the
availability or arrival of a parent.
E.   In all cases of a violation by a minor the chief of police shall cause to
be personally delivered or by certified mail, send to a parent written notice
of said violation with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in
full enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including enforcement of parental
responsibility of applicable penalties. (Ord. 957 §1, 2002: Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.070: RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS OF PUBLIC PLACES:
It is unlawful for any person operating or having charge of any public place to
knowingly allow, permit or suffer the presence of minors in violation of the
curfew established by this chapter. (Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
9.76.080: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
The penalty upon a plea of guilty, nolo contendere, or finding of guilt shall
be a fine of up to two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 957
§1, 2002: Ord. 713 §1, 1991)
CHAPTER 9.77
PREVENTION OF YOUTH ACCESS TO TOBACCO
SECTION:
9.77.010: Short Title
9.77.020: Definitions
9.77.030: Furnishing Or Sale Of Tobacco Products To Minors
9.77.040: Receipt Of Tobacco Products By Minors
9.77.050: Distribution Of Tobacco Product Samples
9.77.060: Sale Of Tobacco Products Except In Original, Sealed Package
9.77.070: Public Access To Displayed Tobacco Products
9.77.080: Report Of Violations And Compliance Checks
9.77.010: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter may be cited as the PREVENTION OF YOUTH ACCESS TO TOBACCO
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.020: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
CIGARETTE: Any product that contains nicotine, is intended to be burned or
heated under ordinary conditions of use, and consists of or contains:
A. Any roll of tobacco wrapped in paper or in any substance not containing
tobacco,
B. Tobacco, in any form, that is functional in the product, which, because of
its appearance, the type of tobacco used in the filter, or its packaging and
labeling, is likely to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as a cigarette
described in subsection A of this definition.
The term "cigarette" includes "roll your own" (i.e., any tobacco which, because
of its appearance, type, packaging, or labeling, is suitable for use and likely
to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as tobacco for making cigarettes).
For purposes of this definition of cigarette, nine one-hundredths (0.09) of an
ounce of "roll your own" tobacco shall constitute one individual "cigarette".
PROOF OF AGE: A driver's license, license for identification only, or other
generally accepted means of identification that describes the individual as
eighteen (18) years of age or older and contains a photograph or other likeness
of the individual and appears on its face to be valid.
SAMPLE: A tobacco product distributed to members of the public at no cost for
the purpose of promoting the product.
SAMPLING: The distribution of samples to members of the public in a public
place.
TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product that contains tobacco and is intended for human
consumption.
TRANSACTION SCAN: The process by which a seller checks, by means of a
transaction scan device, the validity of a driver's license or other government
issued photo identification.
TRANSACTION SCAN DEVICE: Any commercial device or combination of devices used
at a point of sale or entry that is capable of deciphering in an electronically
readable format the information encoded on the magnetic strip or bar code of a
driver's license or other government issued photo identification. (Ord. 1054
§1, 2008)
9.77.030: FURNISHING OR SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO MINORS:
A.   Prohibition: It is unlawful and an offense for any person to sell, give,
or furnish in any manner any tobacco product to another person who is under
eighteen (18) years of age or to purchase in any manner a tobacco product on
behalf of any such person. It shall not be unlawful for an employee under
eighteen (18) years of age to handle tobacco products when required in the
performance of the employee's duties.
B.   Proof Of Age: Any person engaged in the sale or distribution of tobacco
products shall demand proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient if
an ordinary person would conclude on the basis of appearance that the
prospective purchaser may be under eighteen (18) years of age. If an individual
engaged in the sale or distribution of tobacco products has demanded and was
shown proof of age from a prospective purchaser or recipient who is not under
eighteen (18) years of age, the failure to subsequently require proof of age
shall not constitute a violation of this subsection.
C.   Defenses: Proof that the defendant demanded, was shown, and reasonably
relied upon proof of age shall be a defense to prosecution under subsection A
or B of this section. A person cited for violation of this section shall be
deemed to have reasonably relied upon proof of age, and such person shall not
be found guilty of such violation, if such person proves that:
   1.   The individual who purchased or received the tobacco product presented
a driver's license or other government issued photo identification purporting
to establish that such individual was eighteen (18) years of age or older; and
   2.   The person cited for the violation confirmed the validity of the
driver's license or other government issued photo identification presented by
such individual by performing a transaction scan by means of a transaction scan
device.
Provided, that this defense shall not relieve from liability any person cited
for a violation of this section if such person failed to exercise reasonable
diligence to determine whether the physical description and picture appearing
on the driver's license or other government issued photo identification was
that of the individual who presented it. The availability of the defense
described in this subsection does not affect the availability of any other
defense under any other provision of law.
D.   Fines: When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a
continued sentence for a violation of subsection A or B of this section, the
total of any fines, fees, or costs shall not exceed the following:
   1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense;
   2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense within a two (2)
year period following the first offense; and
   3.   Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third or subsequent offense
within a two (2) year period following the first offense. (Ord. 1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.040: RECEIPT OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person who is under eighteen (18)
years of age to purchase, receive, or have in his or her possession a tobacco
product, or to present or offer to any person any purported proof of age which
is false or fraudulent for the purpose of purchasing or receiving any tobacco
product. It shall not be unlawful for an employee under eighteen (18) years of
age to handle tobacco products when required in the performance of the
employee's duties.
B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of subsection A of this section, the total of any
fines, fees, or costs shall not exceed the following:
   1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense; and
   2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second or subsequent offense within
a one year period following the first offense. (Ord. 1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.050: DISTRIBUTION OF TOBACCO PRODUCT SAMPLES:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to distribute tobacco
products or product samples to any person under eighteen (18) years of age.
B.   No person shall distribute tobacco product samples in or on any public
street, sidewalk, or park that is within three hundred feet (300') of any
playground, school, or other facility when the facility is being used primarily
by persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
C.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of subsection A or B of this section, the total of any
fines, fees, or costs shall not exceed the following:
   1.   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense;
   2.   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense; and
   3.   Three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the third or subsequent offense.
(Ord. 1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.060: SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS EXCEPT IN ORIGINAL, SEALED PACKAGE:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to sell cigarettes except in
the original, sealed package in which they were placed by the manufacturer.
B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of this section, the total of any fines, fees, or
costs shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (Ord.
1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.070: PUBLIC ACCESS TO DISPLAYED TOBACCO PRODUCTS:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person or retail store to display or
offer for sale tobacco products in any manner that allows public access to the
tobacco product without assistance from the person displaying the tobacco
product or an employee or the owner of the store. The provisions of this
subsection shall not apply to retail stores which do not admit into the store
persons under eighteen (18) years of age.
B.   When a person is convicted or enters a plea and receives a continued
sentence for a violation of this section, the total of any fines, fees, or
costs shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (Ord.
1054 §1, 2008)
9.77.080: REPORT OF VIOLATIONS AND COMPLIANCE CHECKS:
A.   Any conviction for a violation of this chapter and any compliance checks
conducted by the police department pursuant to subsection B of this section
shall be reported in writing to the alcoholic beverage laws enforcement (ABLE)
commission within thirty (30) days of the conviction or compliance check. Such
reports shall be compiled in the manner prescribed by the ABLE commission.
Convictions shall be reported by the court clerk or his designee and compliance
checks shall be reported by the chief of police or his designee.
B.   Persons under eighteen (18) years of age may be enlisted by the police
department to assist in enforcement of this chapter pursuant to the rules of
the ABLE commission. (Ord. 1054 §1, 2008)
VIII.   WEAPONS 1
CHAPTER 9.82
FIREARMS AND WEAPONS
SECTION:
9.82.010: Definitions
9.82.011: Carrying Weapons Generally
9.82.012: Discharging Firearms
9.82.013: Throwing Weapons Or Objects
9.82.014: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 21 OS ch. 53.
9.82.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the
meanings set forth below unless the context clearly indicates a different
meaning:
PISTOLS: Any firearm capable of discharging a projectile composed of any
material which may reasonably be expected to be able to cause lethal injury,
with a barrel or barrels less than sixteen inches (16") in length, and using
either gunpowder, gas or any means of rocket propulsion, but not to include
flare guns, underwater fishing guns or blank pistols.
RIFLES: Any firearm capable of discharging a projectile composed of any
material which may reasonably be expected to be able to cause lethal injury,
with a barrel or barrels more than sixteen inches (16") in length, using either
gunpowder, gas or any means of rocket propulsion, but not to include archery
equipment, flare guns or underwater fishing guns. In addition, any rifle
capable of firing "shot" but primarily designed to fire single projectiles will
be regarded as a rifle.
SHOTGUNS: Any firearm capable of discharging a series of projectiles of any
material which may reasonably be expected to be able to cause lethal injury,
with a barrel or barrels more than eighteen inches (18") in length, and using
either gunpowder, gas or any means of rocket propulsion, but not to include any
weapon so designed with a barrel less than eighteen inches (18") in length. In
addition, any "shotgun" capable of firing single projectiles but primarily
designed to fire multiple projectiles such as "shot" will be regarded as a
shotgun.
STUN GUN: Any weapon, instrument or electronic device capable of discharging an
electrical charge which may reasonably be expected to stun, temporarily
paralyze or cause a debilitating or lethal injury as a result of the electrical
charge. (Ord. 842 §1, 1998)
9.82.011: CARRYING WEAPONS GENERALLY:
It is unlawful for any person to carry upon or about his person, or in his
portfolio or purse, a stun gun, sword cane, blackjack, loaded cane, bill, hand
chain, metal knuckles, or any other offensive weapon, except as in this chapter
provided. Provided further, that this section shall not prohibit the proper use
of guns and knives for hunting, fishing or recreational purposes, nor shall
this section be construed to prohibit any uses of weapons in a manner otherwise
permitted by municipal ordinance or by state law. (Ord. 1164, 2015)
9.82.012: DISCHARGING FIREARMS:
No person shall discharge any species of firearms, air guns, stun guns, or
weapons except as provided hereinafter:
A.   Police Officers: Police officers, or those impressed into peace officers'
duties by the police department, who in the performance of their duties,
discharge firearms as the occasion warrants;
B.   Shooting Gallery; Annual Permit: Any type of firearm discharged in an
approved shooting gallery or on an approved shooting range, but not until the
shooting gallery or shooting range has been approved by the chief of police
and, an annual permit issued to the owner or operator to conduct the shooting.
The chief of police or his designee shall inspect each place for which a permit
is requested for a shooting gallery or shooting range, and a permit shall be
issued if the chief or his designee finds that the gallery or range is arranged
with adequate safeguards so as not to endanger the public, and if he finds that
the shooting gallery or shooting range is operated and supervised in a manner
so as not to endanger the lives of persons and property including those
participating in the shooting. (Ord. 842 §1, 1998)
9.82.013: THROWING WEAPONS OR OBJECTS:
It is unlawful for any person to throw in any public or private place or any
place where there is any person or property to be endangered or injured
thereby, any stone, piece of brick, wood or any other missile or object upon or
across any street or at any person, building or vehicle irrespective of whether
injury or damage is caused by such action. (Ord. 842 §1, 1998)
9.82.014: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00),
plus court costs, as may be determined by the municipal court, except where
otherwise specified or hereafter set out. (Ord. 842 §1, 1998)
IX.   PENALTIES
CHAPTER 9.90
PENALTY FOR VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
9.90.010: Penalties Designated
9.90.015: Violation Of Section 9.26.020 Of This Title
9.90.010: PENALTIES DESIGNATED:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this title shall, upon
conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars
($200.00), excluding court costs, as may be determined by the municipal court
except where otherwise specified herein:
A.   For an offense established by section
9.02.030 of this title, the maximum fine shall be a sum not to exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) plus court costs.
B.   For offenses established by sections
9.02.020,
9.02.040 and
9.02.050 of this title, the maximum fine shall be a sum not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 1083 §1, 2010)
9.90.015: VIOLATION OF SECTION 9.26.020 OF THIS TITLE:
Any person who sells or furnishes low point beer to a minor shall violate
section
9.26.020 of this title and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by the
payment of a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus court
costs. (Ord. 967 §2, 2002)
X.   MISCELLANEOUS
CHAPTER 9.94
COURT COSTS
SECTION:
9.94.010: Complainant Responsibility
9.94.020: Cases Referred To Collection Agency; Fee
9.94.010: COMPLAINANT RESPONSIBILITY:
Any person, except a police officer or other employee of the city, filing a
criminal offense complaint in the municipal court, shall deposit with the clerk
of the court, court costs in the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) or in the
amount allowed by state statute. The court costs so deposited by such a
complainant shall be refunded to the complainant or person depositing same upon
conviction or acquittal of the defendant; the court costs shall not be
refundable if the charges are dismissed at the request of the complainant who
made the deposit or because the complainant refused to appear in court to
testify or aid in the prosecution of the charges filed by such complainant.
(Ord. 753 §1, 1994)
9.94.020: CASES REFERRED TO COLLECTION AGENCY; FEE:
Any court case and fine which has been referred to a collection agency shall
have a collection agency fee assessed as a cost in the respective case. Said
fee shall be in the amount of thirty five percent (35%) of the amount due or
the actual fee charged by the collection agency pursuant to its contract with
the city, if different. (Ord. 1115, 2011)
TITLE 10
VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 1
Application Of Traffic Regulations   10.04
