CHAPTER 10.04
APPLICATION OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:
10.04.010: Animals And Nonmotorized Vehicles
10.04.020: Emergency Vehicles
10.04.030: Construction Or Maintenance Vehicles Or Machinery
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS §§ 11-101 – 11-107.
10.04.010: ANIMALS AND NONMOTORIZED VEHICLES:
Every person propelling or pulling any cart or riding an animal upon a roadway,
and every person driving any animal drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the
provisions of this title applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those
provisions which by their very nature can have no application. (Prior code §18-
20)
10.04.020: EMERGENCY VEHICLES:
A.   The provisions of this title regulating the operation, parking and
standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles (i.e., police
and other law enforcement vehicles, fire department vehicles and ambulances
when engaged in emergency runs), except as follows: The driver, when operating
any such vehicle in an emergency, or while engaged in the performance of his
duties or in pursuit of an actual or suspected violation of the law, except as
otherwise directed by a police officer, may:
   1.   Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this title;
   2.   Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing
down as may be necessary for safe operation;
   3.   Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he does not endanger
life or property;
   4.   Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in
specific directions so long as he does not endanger life or property.
B.   The exemptions in subsections A2 and A4 of this section shall apply only
when the driver of the emergency vehicle sounds a siren as may be reasonably
necessary, and the vehicle displays a lighted red lamp and/or lens visible from
the front under normal atmospheric conditions for a distance of five hundred
feet (500') as a warning to others. The foregoing exemptions shall not,
however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his
reckless disregard of the safety of others. (Ord. 435 §1, 1976: prior code §18-
21)
10.04.030: CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE VEHICLES OR MACHINERY:
The provisions of this title shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles
or vehicles or machinery used in the construction or maintenance of streets and
highways, and such vehicles or machinery may be operated on any part of the
street whether the same is open to traffic or closed, when such operation is
necessary in the maintenance or construction of the streets or highways. (Prior
code §18-23)
CHAPTER 10.08
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 1
SECTION:
10.08.010: Adoption Of Regulations; Enforcement
10.08.020: Police And Fire Departments; Powers And Duties
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 11-103.
10.08.010: ADOPTION OF REGULATIONS; ENFORCEMENT:
A.   The adoption of all traffic rules and regulations within the city is
reserved to the council, which shall have full authority to regulate traffic,
vehicles and parking by ordinance or resolution.
B.   It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the street
traffic regulations of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable
to street traffic in this city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to
investigate accidents, and to cooperate with other law enforcement officers in
developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and in protecting life
and property. (Ord. 433 §1, 1976: prior code §18-1)
10.08.020: POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS; POWERS AND DUTIES:
A.   Officers of the police department, subject to direction by the chief of
police, are authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in
conformance with this title; provided that in the event of a fire or other
emergency, to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers may direct
traffic as conditions may require.
B.   Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct
or assist the police in directing traffic and may make arrests for traffic and
parking violations.
C.   No person not properly authorized shall direct or attempt to direct
traffic.
D.   No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or
direction of a police officer or officer of the fire department.
E.   The police department is empowered to regulate and control traffic without
council action on a temporary basis, and pursuant thereto are authorized, on a
temporary basis, to:
   1.   Establish stop signs and traffic control devices at all intersections
that, in the opinion of the department, constitute a hazard;
   2.   Establish loading zones upon the streets for the loading and unloading
of buses and taxis, and to designate a portion of any street for that purpose;
and, when so designated and plainly marked, the same shall not be used for
parking or for any other purpose;
   3.   Establish either angle or parallel parking upon the streets of the city
in such manner as in its judgment to reduce traffic hazards;
   4.   Establish time limits upon parking, and designate the time that parking
shall be permitted with plain markers;
   5.   Erect or install, during short periods of time to assist in eliminating
traffic congestion or abnormal traffic conditions, signs prohibiting or
indicating required movements of traffic or prohibiting or indicating required
parking of vehicles;
   6.   Prohibit and prevent all obstructions and encroachments into and upon
all public and private property which interfere with the free movement of
traffic or the blocking of vision, and provide for the removal of all
encroachments and obstructions at the expense of the owner of the ground
fronting thereon, or the person placing the same there.
F.   Any police officer is authorized to make arrests for violations of traffic
ordinances of the city which he observes on any highway or street that forms
the boundary line of the city and any other adjoining political jurisdiction,
said authority to enforce traffic ordinance and make arrests on boundary lines
and streets provided for pursuant to title 47, section 108.1 of the Oklahoma
Statutes, subject to the provisions of section 15-101 et seq., of title 47 of
the Oklahoma Statutes. (Ord. 672 §2, 1988: Ord. 665 §1, 1988: Ord. 657 §4,
1987: Ord. 433 §1, 1976: prior code §18-2)
CHAPTER 10.12
TRAFFIC COMMISSION
SECTION:
10.12.010: Creation; Membership; Appointment
10.12.020: Ex Officio Members
10.12.030: Members; Terms
10.12.031: Absences To Terminate Membership
10.12.040: Officers; Meetings
10.12.050: Powers And Duties
10.12.060: Recommendations; Procedure
10.12.061: Adoption Of Guidelines
10.12.070: Authority To Exercise Emergency Traffic Control Powers
10.12.010: CREATION; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT:
There is established a traffic commission of the city. The commission shall
consist of five (5) residents of the city, to be appointed by the mayor with
consent and approval of the council. Membership shall consist of one member
appointed from each ward and one member at large, all of whom shall serve
without compensation. (Ord. 423 §1, 1976)
10.12.020: EX OFFICIO MEMBERS:
In addition to the five (5) members appointed as set forth in section
10.12.010 of this chapter, the fire chief and police chief shall serve as ex
officio members of the commission, but they shall act in an advisory capacity
and shall have no power to vote on matters coming before the commission. (Ord.
423 §2, 1976)
10.12.030: MEMBERS; TERMS:
The term of each member shall be three (3) years, or until his successor takes
office, except for the initial appointments which shall be as follows: Members
from wards 1 and 3, and the at large member shall be appointed for terms of two
(2) years, which shall thereafter be full three (3) year terms. Members
appointed from wards 2 and 4 shall be appointed for a full three (3) year term.
(Ord. 423 §3, 1976)
10.12.031: ABSENCES TO TERMINATE MEMBERSHIP:
If any individual member of the commission shall be absent from more than one-
half (1/2) of any four (4) consecutive meetings of the traffic commission, he
shall thereupon cease to hold office and the vacancy created thereby shall be
filled as provided in this chapter for original appointment to the commission.
(Ord. 879 §1, 1999: Ord. 557 §1, 1983)
10.12.040: OFFICERS; MEETINGS:
The commission shall elect a chairman and vice chairman from the membership who
shall serve for periods of one year, or until their successors are elected. The
commission shall meet in regular sessions not less than once per month; such
date to be established by the commission. In addition, the commission shall
meet upon special call by the mayor, chairman or vice chairman of the
commission at the request of the city council. (Ord. 557 §2, 1983)
10.12.050: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The general duties of the commission shall be to coordinate traffic activities,
review proposed traffic ordinances, receive complaints, and conduct hearings
having to do with traffic matters within the city. In addition, the commission
shall carry out any and all further duties which may be imposed on the
commission by the ordinances of the city. (Ord. 423 §5, 1976)
10.12.060: RECOMMENDATIONS; PROCEDURE:
The commission shall recommend to the council ways and means toward improving
or changing traffic or parking conditions, and the administration or
enforcement of traffic regulations. All recommendations made to the council
based upon proposed traffic ordinances or other traffic matters shall be in
writing, with copies of all such recommendations provided to all department
heads and the planning commission. (Ord. 423 §6, 1976)
10.12.061: ADOPTION OF GUIDELINES:
There is adopted and incorporated herein by reference as if fully set out for
use and as guidelines for the traffic commission in the exercise of its powers,
duties and recommendations as provided herein, the uniform traffic control
devices as adopted by the national advisory committee on traffic control in
1978, and as from time to time amended, and as published by the United States
department of transportation. The adoption of such uniform control code shall
be advisory to the commission in its duties; provided, however, any deviation
therefrom shall be supported by reasons to justify such variance. A current
copy of the uniform traffic control devices code shall be maintained at all
times by the city clerk for use by the commission and shall be available for
use and inspection by the public. (Ord. 557 §3, 1983)
10.12.070: AUTHORITY TO EXERCISE EMERGENCY TRAFFIC CONTROL POWERS:
Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the police chief or fire chief from
exercising powers over traffic control on a temporary basis in such situations
as they may deem emergencies. Any such action taken under this section shall be
effective as if adopted by the council, provided the temporary action taken
shall only be effective until the next council meeting following the next
traffic commission meeting. (Ord. 423 §7, 1976)
CHAPTER 10.16
DRIVERS' AND CHAUFFEURS' LICENSES
SECTION:
10.16.010: Required; Possession
10.16.011: Operation Of Motor Vehicle In Violation Of Restrictions
10.16.020: Permitting Unauthorized Persons To Drive
10.16.030: Invalid Licenses
10.16.040: Employment Of Unlicensed Chauffeur
10.16.050: Renting Vehicles
10.16.060: Penalties
10.16.010: REQUIRED; POSSESSION:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a motor vehicle
within the city without having been issued a valid driver's license from and as
required by the laws of the state.
B.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a motor vehicle
within the city without having a valid driver's license issued from the state
in his or her immediate possession. (Ord. 619 §1, 1985)
10.16.011: OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE IN VIOLATION OF RESTRICTIONS:
A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a motor
vehicle in any manner or under any conditions which are in violation of the
restrictions imposed on a driver's license issued to that person by the state
department of public safety.
B.   Any person who is convicted of the offense of operating a motor vehicle
under conditions which violate the restrictions imposed upon their driver's
license shall be required to pay a fine in the amount of thirty five dollars
($35.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 657 §5, 1987: Ord. 662 §1, 1985)
10.16.020: PERMITTING UNAUTHORIZED PERSONS TO DRIVE:
A.   It is an offense for any person to cause or knowingly permit his child or
ward under the age of sixteen (16) years to drive a motor vehicle on any
streets in the city, when such minor is not authorized to do so by the
provisions of the laws of the state.
B.   It is an offense for any person to authorize or knowingly permit any
vehicle owned by him or under his control to be driven upon any of the streets
of the city by any person who is not authorized under the provisions of this
title to operate such vehicle.
C.   No person who is under the age of fourteen (14) years shall operate a
vehicle on the streets of the city. (Prior code §18-15)
10.16.030: INVALID LICENSES:
A.   No person shall display or have in his possession any canceled, revoked,
suspended, fictitious, photostatic or fraudulently altered operator's or
chauffeur's license. It is unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a
motor vehicle within the city whose driver's license has been canceled,
suspended, revoked or denied by the state.
B.   No person shall lend his operator's or chauffeur's license to any other
person or knowingly permit the use thereof by another.
C.   No person shall display or represent as one's own any operator's or
chauffeur's license not issued to him. (Ord. 896 §1, 2000: prior code §18-17)
10.16.040: EMPLOYMENT OF UNLICENSED CHAUFFEUR:
No person shall employ as a chauffeur of a motor vehicle any person not then
licensed by the laws of the state. (Prior code §18-18)
10.16.050: RENTING VEHICLES:
A.   No person shall rent a motor vehicle to any other person unless the latter
person is then duly licensed as required by the laws of the state or, in the
case of a nonresident, then duly licensed under the laws of the state or county
of his residence, except a nonresident whose home state or county does not
require that an operator be licensed.
B.   No person shall rent a motor vehicle to another until he has inspected the
operator's or chauffeur's license of the person to whom the vehicle is to be
rented and compared and verified the signature thereon with the signature of
such person written in his presence. (Prior code §18-19)
10.16.060: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates the provisions of the following designated sections
shall, upon conviction thereof, be required to pay a fine in an amount as
follows:
A.   For violation of subsection
10.16.010A of this chapter, a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court
costs;
B.   For violation of subsection
10.16.010B of this chapter, a fine of thirty five dollars ($35.00), plus court
costs;
C.   For violation of section
10.16.030 of this chapter, a fine of one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00), plus
court costs. (Ord. 1000 §9, 2004: Ord. 657 §5, 1987)
CHAPTER 10.18
PROOF OF INSURANCE AND CERTIFICATION OF EXISTENCE OF SECURITY
SECTION:
10.18.010: Security Verification Form Required
10.18.020: Definitions
10.18.030: Possession Of Security Verification Form While Operating Or Using
Certain Vehicles
10.18.040: Penalty
10.18.010: SECURITY VERIFICATION FORM REQUIRED:
A.   The owner of a motor vehicle registered in this state and operating said
vehicle within the city's boundaries, shall carry in such vehicle at all times
a current owner's security verification form listing the vehicle, or an
equivalent form which has been issued by the department of public safety which
shall be produced by any driver thereof upon request for inspection by any law
enforcement officer and, in case of a collision, the form shall be shown upon
request to any person affected by said collision.
B.   The following shall not be required to carry an owner's or operator's
security verification form or an equivalent form from the department during
operation of the vehicle and shall not be required to surrender such form for
vehicle registration purposes:
   1.   Any vehicle owned or leased by the federal or state government, or any
agency or political subdivision thereof,
   2.   Any vehicle bearing the name, symbol or logo of the business,
corporation or utility on the exterior and which is in compliance with the
compulsory insurance law according to records of the department of public
safety which reflect a deposit, bond, self-insurance, or fleet policy,
   3.   Any vehicle authorized for operation, under a permit number issued by
the interstate commerce commission, or the Oklahoma corporation commission,
   4.   Any licensed taxicab, and
   5.   Any vehicle owned by a licensed used motor vehicle dealer. (Ord. 573
§1, 1983)
10.18.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the words set out in this section shall have
the following meanings:
COMPULSORY INSURANCE LAW: The law requiring liability insurance in conjunction
with the operation of a motor vehicle in this state as found in article VI,
chapter 7 of title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes.
OPERATOR'S POLICY: An operator's policy of liability insurance shall insure the
named person against loss from the liability imposed upon him by law for
damages arising out of the operation or use by him of any motor vehicle not
owned by him, subject to the same limits of liability required in an owner's
policy.
OWNER'S POLICY: An owner's policy of liability insurance:
A.   Shall designate by explicit description or by appropriate reference all
vehicles with respect to which coverage is thereby to be granted,
B.   Shall insure the person named therein and insure any other person, except
as provided in subsection D of this section, using an insured vehicle with the
express or implied permission of the named insured, against loss from the
liability imposed by law for damages arising out of the ownership, maintenance,
operation or use of such vehicle,
C.   May provide for exclusions from coverage in accordance with existing laws,
and
D.   Shall be issued by an authorized carrier providing coverage in accordance
with section 7-204 of title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes.
SECURITY: A. A policy or bond meeting the requirements of section 7-204 of
title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes,
B.   A deposit of cash or securities having the equivalency of limits required
under section 7-204 of title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes as acceptable limits
for a policy or bond, or
C.   Self-insurance, pursuant to the provisions of section 7-503 of title 47 of
the Oklahoma Statutes, having the equivalency of limits required under section
7-204 of title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes as acceptable limits for a policy or
bond.
SECURITY VERIFICATION FORM: A security verification form is a form, approved by
the state board for property and casualty rates, verifying the existence of
security required by the compulsory insurance law of the state of Oklahoma.
(Ord. 573 §1, 1983)
10.18.030: POSSESSION OF SECURITY VERIFICATION FORM WHILE OPERATING OR USING
CERTAIN VEHICLES:
Every operator of a motor vehicle registered in this state shall, while
operating or using such vehicle within the city's boundaries, carry either an
operator's or an owner's security verification form issued by a carrier,
providing the operator is not excluded from coverage thereon; or an equivalent
form issued by the department of public safety, reflecting liability coverage.
(Ord. 573 §1, 1983)
10.18.040: PENALTY:
A.   An owner or operator who fails to produce for inspection a valid and
current security verification form or equivalent form which has been issued by
the department upon request of any peace officer of the Warr Acres city police
department shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be
subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00).
B.   A sentence imposed for any violation of this section may be suspended or
deferred in whole or in part by the court.
C.   Upon conviction, bond forfeiture or deferral of sentence, the court shall
forward an abstract to the department of public safety within ten (10) days
reflecting the action taken by the court. (Ord. 1000 §5, 2004: Ord. 573 §1,
1983)
CHAPTER 10.20
COLLISIONS; ACCIDENT REPORTS 1
SECTION:
10.20.020: Information, Assistance And Notice To Police Required
10.20.030: Stopping And Remaining At Scene Of Accident
10.20.035: Penalties For Violating Section 10.20.030 Of This Chapter
10.20.040: Report; Time Limit; Confidentiality
10.20.050: Striking Unattended Vehicles; Notice Required
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS ch. 10.
10.20.020: INFORMATION, ASSISTANCE AND NOTICE TO POLICE REQUIRED:
The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or
death of any person, or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by
any person, shall give his name, address and the registration number of the
vehicle he is driving, and shall, upon request, and if available, exhibit his
operator's or chauffeur's license to the person struck, or the driver or
occupant of or person attending any vehicle collided with. He shall render to
any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the
carrying, or making of arrangements for the carrying, of such person to a
physician or hospital for medical treatment, if it is apparent that such
treatment is necessary, or if such carrying is requested by the injured person,
and he shall by the quickest means of communication, give notice of such
accident to the police department, as provided in this chapter. (Prior code
§18-3)
10.20.030: STOPPING AND REMAINING AT SCENE OF ACCIDENT:
The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or
death of any person, or damage to any vehicle or property, shall immediately
stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident and shall remain at the scene
of the accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section
10.20.020 of this chapter. Every stop shall be made without obstructing traffic
more than is necessary. (Prior code §18-4)
10.20.035: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATING SECTION 10.20.030 OF THIS CHAPTER:
Persons convicted of violating the provisions of section
10.20.030 of this chapter shall be punished by a monetary fine in the amount of
two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 907 §1, 2000)
10.20.040: REPORT; TIME LIMIT; CONFIDENTIALITY:
A.   The driver of any vehicle involved in any accident, or if physically
incapable then the owner of such vehicle, shall within forty eight (48) hours
report such accident to the police station, and make a full report upon the
forms to be provided by the police department; provided, further, that in any
accident where death, personal injury or property damage is involved, the
driver or drivers of the vehicles shall immediately report the same to the
police station and shall in all cases remain at the scene of the accident until
police officers have arrived.
B.   All accident reports made by persons involved in accidents shall be
without prejudice to the individual so reporting and shall be for the
confidential use of the police department, or other governmental agencies
having use of the records for accident prevention purposes, except that the
identification of a person involved in an accident may be disclosed when such
identity is not otherwise known, or when such person denies his presence at
such accident.
C.   No reports or information filed by the drivers as provided in this section
shall be used in any trial, civil or criminal, arising out of an accident,
except that the police department shall furnish, upon demand of any party to
such trial or upon demand of any court, an affidavit stating that a specified
accident report has or has not been made to the department, in compliance with
the law. (Prior code §18-5)
10.20.050: STRIKING UNATTENDED VEHICLES; NOTICE REQUIRED:
The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle which is unattended
shall immediately stop, and shall then and there either locate and notify the
operator or owner of such vehicle as to the name and address of the driver and
owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle, or shall leave, in a
conspicuous place in or on the vehicle struck, a written notice giving the name
and address of the driver and of the owner of the vehicle doing the striking.
(Prior code §18-6)
CHAPTER 10.24
TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES, SIGNS AND SIGNALS 1
SECTION:
10.24.010: Authority To Install And Maintain
10.24.020: Compliance Required; Exceptions
10.24.030: Traffic Control Signals; Legend
10.24.035: Penalties For Violating Section 10.24.030 Of This Chapter
10.24.040: Flashing Red Or Yellow Signals
10.24.050: Injury Or Removal Prohibited
10.24.060: Unauthorized Signs, Signals Or Devices Prohibited
10.24.070: Establishment Of Safety Zones, Traffic Lanes And Islands
10.24.080: Traffic Control In Construction Areas
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 11-201 et seq.
10.24.010: AUTHORITY TO INSTALL AND MAINTAIN:
Traffic control devices, signals and signs shall be placed and maintained when
and as provided in this title, to make effective the provisions of this title,
and such additional devices as may be required shall be placed and maintained.
(Prior code §18-41)
10.24.020: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic
control device, signal or sign applicable thereto placed in accordance with the
traffic ordinances of the city unless otherwise directed by a police officer,
subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle
in this title. (Prior code §18-42)
10.24.030: TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS; LEGEND:
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting the words
"Go", "Caution" or "Stop", or exhibiting different colored lights successively,
one at a time, or with arrows, the following colors only shall be used; and the
terms and lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and
pedestrians as follows:
A.   Green alone or "Go": Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed
straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits
either of such turns. Vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or
left shall yield the right of way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully
within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is
exhibited. Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within
any marked or unmarked crosswalk.
B.   Yellow alone or "Caution": Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby
warned that the red or "stop" signal will be exhibited immediately thereafter,
and such vehicular traffic shall not enter the intersection when the yellow or
"caution" signal is exhibited unless a stop cannot be made in safety, in which
event vehicles may proceed through the intersection, if such move can be made
with caution. No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until
the green or "go" signal is shown alone unless authorized to do so by a
pedestrian "walk" signal.
C.   Red alone or "Stop": Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before
entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then
before entering the intersection, and shall not proceed across the intersection
until green or "go" is shown alone. No pedestrian facing such signal, shall
enter the roadway until the green or "go" signal is shown alone unless
authorized to do so by a pedestrian "walk" signal.
D.   Red with green arrow: Vehicular traffic facing such signal may enter the
intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow, but shall yield
the right of way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other
traffic lawfully using the intersection. No pedestrian facing such signal shall
enter the roadway until the green or "go" signal is shown alone, unless
authorized to do so by a pedestrian "walk" signal. (Prior code §18-43)
10.24.035: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATING SECTION 10.24.030 OF THIS CHAPTER:
Persons convicted of violating the provisions of section
10.24.030 of this chapter shall be punished by a monetary fine in the amount of
one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 1000 §6, 2004: Ord. 907
§1, 2000)
10.24.040: FLASHING RED OR YELLOW SIGNALS:
Whenever flashing red or yellow signals are used, they shall require obedience
by vehicular traffic as follows:
A.   Flashing Red (Stop) Signal: When a red lens is illuminated with rapid
intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the
nearest crosswalk at an intersection and the right to proceed shall be subject
to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign.
B.   Flashing Yellow (Caution) Signal: When a yellow lens is illuminated with
rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the
intersection or past such signal only with caution. (Prior code §18-44)
10.24.050: INJURY OR REMOVAL PROHIBITED:
No person shall without lawful authority alter, deface, injure, knock down or
remove any official traffic control device or sign, or any railroad sign or
signal, or any inscription, shield or insignia thereupon or any other part
thereof, or attempt to do so. (Prior code §18-45)
10.24.060: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS OR DEVICES PROHIBITED:
No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any street or
highway within the limits of the city any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or
device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official
traffic control device or railroad sign or signal which attempts to direct the
movement of traffic, or which projects any flashing or revolving beams of
light, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any
official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal. (Prior code
§18-46)
10.24.070: ESTABLISHMENT OF SAFETY ZONES, TRAFFIC LANES AND ISLANDS:
A.   The council shall establish safety zones, traffic lanes, islands and other
traffic control devices, and the street department shall carry such directions
into effect to maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the
surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where there is particular
danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as deemed
necessary by the council.
B.   To mark or construct safety zones of such kind and character and at such
places as deemed necessary by the council for the protection of pedestrians.
C.   To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places, consistent
with this title, and the direction of the council.
D.   To construct and maintain traffic islands. (Ord. 438 §1, 1976: prior code
§18-70)
10.24.080: TRAFFIC CONTROL IN CONSTRUCTION AREAS:
A.   During such times as construction, repair and maintenance of North
MacArthur Avenue between the intersections of Northwest 50th Street and
Northwest 63rd Street is being performed under traffic, the chief of police is
authorized to erect, or cause to be erected, such traffic control devices as
he, in his discretion, may determine necessary to protect members of the public
and the construction personnel. Each person using or driving a vehicle on North
MacArthur during such times shall obey all signs, signals, markings, flagmen or
other traffic control devices which are placed to regulate, control, and guide
traffic through the construction or maintenance area. As used in this
subsection, "construction or maintenance area" means any area upon or around
North MacArthur that is visibly marked as an area where construction, repair,
and maintenance is temporarily occurring. The construction or maintenance area
also includes the streets accessing North MacArthur at designated construction
or maintenance areas, beginning at the point where properly posted traffic
control devices start to warn and guide the public into and through the
construction or maintenance including, but not limited to, instructions to
merge from one lane into another lane, to reduce speed, or to follow directions
of flagmen.
B.   Any person who violates any provision of this section by failure to comply
with any traffic control device established by the chief of police pursuant to
the authority granted by this section shall be guilty of an offense and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) not including court costs, assessments and fees. (Ord. 1012
§1, 2005)
CHAPTER 10.28
RULES OF THE ROAD 1

10.28.015: Texting While Driving Prohibited

10.28.100: U-Turns Permitted At Intersections; Exceptions
10.28.110: Turn And Stop Signals Required
10.28.120: Turn And Stop Signals; Devices Or Means
10.28.130: Turn And Stop Signals; Method Of Giving By Hand Or Arm
10.28.150: Leaving Vehicle Doors Open
10.28.160: One-Way Street; Driving In The Opposite Direction

1 1. 47 OS ch. 11.
10.28.010: RECKLESS, CARELESS OR NEGLIGENT DRIVING UNLAWFUL:
A.   It is unlawful and shall be deemed reckless, careless or negligent driving
for any person to drive any vehicle within the city recklessly, carelessly or
negligently in disregard of the rights or safety of others, or without due
caution under the circumstances then existing, or at a dangerous rate of speed,
or in such manner as to endanger the rights, life or property of any person.
B.   Any person who shall violate the provisions of subsection A of this
section shall, upon conviction thereof, be required to pay a fine, plus court
costs, as follows: reckless driving, a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars
($200.00); careless driving, a fine not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00); negligent driving, a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars
($100.00). (Ord. 657 §6, 1987)
10.28.015: TEXTING WHILE DRIVING PROHIBITED:
A.   Prohibited Actions: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor
vehicle on any street or highway within the city of Warr Acres while using a
handheld electronic communication device to manually compose, send or read an
electronic text message while the motor vehicle is in motion.
B.   Penalty: Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this
section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than seventy
dollars ($70.00).
C.   Exceptions: The provisions of subsection A of this section shall not apply
if the person is using the cellular telephone or electronic communication
device for the sole purpose of communicating with any of the following
regarding an imminent emergency situation:
   1.   An emergency response operator;
   2.   A hospital, physician's office or health clinic;
   3.   A provider of ambulance services;
   4.   A provider of firefighting services; or
   5.   A law enforcement agency.
D.   Definitions: For the purpose of this section:
   CELLULAR TELEPHONE: An analog or digital wireless telephone authorized by
the federal communications commission to operate in the frequency bandwidth
reserved for cellular telephones.
   COMPOSE, SEND OR READ: With respect to a text message means the manual
entry, sending or retrieval of a text message to communicate with any person or
device.
   ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATION DEVICE: An electronic device that permits the user
to manually transmit a communication of written text by means other than
through an oral transfer or wire communication. This term does not include a
device that is physically or electronically integrated into a motor vehicle or
a voice operated global positioning or navigation system that is affixed to a
motor vehicle, or a handsfree device that allows the user to write, send or
read a text message without the use of either hand except to activate,
deactivate or initiate a feature or function.
   TEXT MESSAGE: Includes a text based message, instant message, electronic
message, photo, video or electronic mail. (Ord. 1160, 2015)
10.28.020: FOLLOWING VEHICLES TOO CLOSELY PROHIBITED:
The driver of a vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is
reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicle, the
traffic, condition of the street, and surrounding circumstances. (Prior code
§18-27)
10.28.030: DRIVING ON RIGHT SIDE OF STREET REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
Upon a two-way street of sufficient width, vehicles shall be driven upon the
right half of the street except when passing another vehicle or when the right
half is obstructed. In crossing an intersection of streets or an intersection
of a street with a railroad, a vehicle shall at all such times be driven on the
right half of a two-way street unless the right half is obstructed. Slow moving
vehicles shall be driven as closely as practicable to the right edge or curb.
(Prior code §18-28)
10.28.040: TRAFFIC LANES:
When a street has been divided into lanes for traffic, drivers shall observe
the following rules:
A.   A vehicle shall normally be driven in the lane nearest the right edge or
curb of the street when this lane is available for travel, except when
overtaking another vehicle or in preparation for a left turn.
B.   A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as is practicable entirely within a
single lane, and shall not be moved from such lane until the driver has first
ascertained that such movement can be made with safety and has signaled for a
change of lane or direction. (Prior code §18-29)
10.28.050: PASSING:
Drivers of vehicles proceeding in opposite directions shall pass each other to
the right, and each shall give to the other half of the main traveled portion
of the street, as nearly as practicable. (Prior code §18-30)
10.28.060: OVERTAKING VEHICLES ON THE LEFT:
The driver of a vehicle overtaking on the left another vehicle proceeding in
the same direction shall give notice of his approach by horn, shall pass at a
safe distance to the left of the vehicle being overtaken, and shall not again
drive to the right side of the street until safely clear of such overtaken
vehicle. The driver of a vehicle being approached from the rear shall give way
to the right on audible signal in favor of the overtaking vehicle when
practicable, and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely
passed by the overtaking vehicle. No vehicle shall be driven to the left of the
centerline of a street in overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in
the same direction if the left side is not clearly visible and free of oncoming
traffic for a sufficient distance ahead to permit such overtaking and passing
to be made in safety, nor at any railway crossing, on a hill, nor when crossing
any intersection with another street. (Prior code §18-31)
10.28.070: OVERTAKING VEHICLES ON THE RIGHT:
A.   The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass on the right of another
vehicle only under the following conditions:
   1.   When the vehicle overtaken is making or about to make a left turn;
   2.   Upon a street with unobstructed pavement not occupied by parked
vehicles and of sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving vehicles
in each direction;
   3.   Upon a one-way street or upon any roadway on which traffic is
restricted to one direction of movement, where the roadway is free from
obstruction and of sufficient width for two (2) or more lines of moving
vehicles;
B.   The driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle on the right
only under conditions set out in subsection A of this section, and then
permitting such movement in safety. In no event shall such movement be made by
driving off the pavement or main traveled portion of the roadway, except in an
emergency. (Prior code §18-32)
10.28.080: RIGHT OF WAY:
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this title, the following rules
shall determine the right of way of vehicles:
A.   The driver of a vehicle approaching an intersection shall yield the right
of way to a vehicle which has already entered the intersection from a different
roadway.
B.   When two (2) vehicles enter an intersection having no traffic control
signals or signs from different roadways at approximately the same time, the
driver of the vehicle on the right shall have the right of way.
C.   Where two (2) or more vehicles face stop, slow, warning or caution signs
or signals on two (2) or more intersecting cross streets, and are approaching
so as to enter the intersection at the same time, the actions set out in this
subsection shall be taken. Where each vehicle is required to stop, the vehicle
coming from the right shall have the right of way. Where each vehicle is
required to slow, the vehicle coming from the right shall have the right of
way. Where each vehicle is required to take caution, the vehicle coming from
the right shall have the right of way. Where one vehicle is required to stop
and the other to slow or take caution, the one slowing or taking caution shall
have the right of way. Where one vehicle is required to slow and the other take
caution, the one required to take caution shall have the right of way. In any
event, a vehicle which has already entered the intersection shall have the
right of way over one which has not so entered the intersection.
D.   The driver of a vehicle within an intersection intending to turn to the
left shall yield the right of way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite
direction which is within the intersection or so close thereto as to constitute
an immediate hazard; but the driver, having so yielded and having given a
signal when and as required by this title, may make such left turn, and all
other vehicles approaching the intersection from the opposite direction shall
yield the right of way to the vehicle making the left turn.
E.   In all cases, emergency vehicles, as defined in this title, and when
plainly designated and marked, shall have the right of way on the roadways.
F.   Any vehicle parked parallel or at an angle with the curb when ready to
move shall yield the right of way to oncoming traffic in the street approaching
from the rear, and shall proceed into the line of traffic only after the driver
has indicated his intention of driving from the curb and into the line of
traffic by giving the signal for a left turn, and in no event shall enter the
line of traffic while a hazard exists.
G.   Any vehicle attempting to park by backing into a parking space shall have
the right of way to such parking space over any other vehicle heading into such
space. (Prior code §18-33)
10.28.090: TURNS AT INTERSECTIONS:
The driver of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall comply with
the following provisions:
A.   Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn itself shall be made
as close as practicable to the right hand curb or edge of the roadway.
B.   Approach for a left turn shall be made in that portion of the right half
of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof; and after entering the
intersection, the left turn shall be made so as to leave the intersection to
the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered.
C.   Approach for a left turn from a two-way street into a one-way street shall
be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline
thereof and by passing to the right of such centerline where it enters the
intersection. A left turn from a one-way street into a two-way street shall be
made from the left portion of the lane and by passing to the right of the
centerline of the street being entered upon leaving the intersection.
D.   Where both streets or roadways are one-way, both the approach for a left
turn and a left turn shall be made as close as practicable to the left hand
curb or edge of the roadway. (Prior code §18-34)
10.28.100: U-TURNS PERMITTED AT INTERSECTIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
It is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to turn such vehicle around on any
roadway within the city so as to proceed in the opposite direction except at an
intersection; provided, it is unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to make such
a turn at any intersection:
A.   Where traffic control signals, and/or four-way stop signs are installed,
except as authorized by U-turn signs;
B.   Where a police officer is directing traffic, except at his direction;
C.   Where an official "No U-turn" sign has been placed and is maintained;
D.   When otherwise permitted, a U-turn may be made only when it can be made in
safety and without interfering with other traffic. (Prior code §18-35)
10.28.110: TURN AND STOP SIGNALS REQUIRED:
No person shall turn a vehicle at an intersection or turn a vehicle to enter a
private road or driveway or otherwise turn a vehicle from a direct course or
move right or left upon a roadway, without giving an appropriate signal in the
manner provided in this chapter. A signal of intention to turn right or left
when required shall be given continuously during not less than the one hundred
feet (100') traveled by the vehicle before turning. No person shall stop or
suddenly decrease the speed of a vehicle without first giving an appropriate
signal in the manner provided in this chapter to the driver of any vehicle
immediately to the rear when there is opportunity to give such signal. (Prior
code §18-36)
10.28.120: TURN AND STOP SIGNALS; DEVICES OR MEANS:
Any turn or stop signal required shall be given either by means of the hand and
arm or by a signal lamp or lamps or mechanical signal device of proper type;
but when a vehicle is so constructed or loaded that a hand and arm signal would
not be visible both to the front and rear of such vehicle, then the signals
must be given by such a lamp or lamps or signal device. (Prior code §18-37)
10.28.130: TURN AND STOP SIGNALS; METHOD OF GIVING BY HAND OR ARM:
All signals required by hand and arm by this chapter shall be given from the
left side of the vehicle in the following manner, and such signals shall
indicate as follows:
A.   Left turn, hand and arm extended horizontally;
B.   Right turn, hand and arm extended upward;
C.   Stop or decrease speed, hand and arm extended downward. (Prior code §18-
38)
10.28.150: LEAVING VEHICLE DOORS OPEN:
No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle on the side available to
moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so, nor shall any
person leave a door open on the side of a vehicle available to moving traffic
longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. (Prior code §18-40)
10.28.160: ONE-WAY STREET; DRIVING IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION:
A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to drive a motor
vehicle in the opposite direction of any street within the city which has been
designated and marked by a sign as a one-way street.
B.   Any person who is convicted of the offense of driving in the opposite
direction down a one-way street shall be fined in the amount not to exceed
seventy dollars ($70.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 618 §1, 1985)
CHAPTER 10.32
MISCELLANEOUS DRIVING REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:

Coach Or Camper Containing Passengers
10.32.070: Objects In Roadway

10.32.090: Interference With Or Obstruction To Driver's Control Or View
Prohibited

10.32.110: False Reports Of Vehicle Theft Or Conversion Prohibited
10.32.120: Removal Or Affixing Of License Plates
10.32.130: Certificates Of Title And Number Plates

10.32.150: Littering From Vehicles

10.32.170: Meeting Or Overtaking A Stopped Church Bus

10.32.010: FUNERAL PROCESSIONS OR PARADES:
A.   No person shall operate a vehicle so as to drive or cut through any
funeral procession or parade. A funeral procession shall be identified as such
by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other
identifying insignia, by the headlights being turned on, or by such other
method as may be determined by the police department. Each driver in such
procession shall drive as near to the right hand edge of the roadway as
practicable and shall follow the vehicles ahead as close as is practicable and
safe.
B.   No procession or parade, excluding funerals, containing twenty (20) or
more persons or five (5) or more vehicles, except the armed forces of the
United States, the military forces of this state and the forces of the police
and fire department, shall occupy, march or proceed along any roadway, except
in accordance with the permit issued by the chief of police and such other
regulations of the city. (Prior code §18-61)
10.32.020: DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS:
The driver of a vehicle shall not drive upon any sidewalk or upon any sidewalk
area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. (Prior code §18-62)
10.32.030: LOADS EXTENDING FROM VEHICLE:
When vehicles are loaded with material extending more than two feet (2') in any
direction from the body of such vehicle, there shall be attached to such
material a red flag by day and a red light by night at the extreme end of such
extended material. (Prior code §18-63)
10.32.040: BACKING VEHICLE:
A.   The driver of a vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can
be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic.
B.   When a vehicle is being backed out of an angle parking space, it is the
responsibility of the driver to see that the way is clear and that no person,
vehicle or other property will be harmed or damaged thereby. (Prior code §18-
64)
10.32.050: DRIVING THROUGH SERVICE DRIVEWAYS OR PRIVATE PROPERTY:
No vehicle shall be driven through any service driveway or private property
except for the purpose of obtaining services or merchandise, or with
permission. (Prior code §18-65)
10.32.060: ATTACHING ONESELF TO A MOVING VEHICLE; PULLING OR TOWING TRAILER
COACH OR CAMPER CONTAINING PASSENGERS:
A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person on foot or riding upon
any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, skis, ice skates, or roller skates,
skateboard or any toy vehicle to attach the same or himself or herself to any
moving vehicle upon any street and it shall be unlawful and an offense for any
operator of a moving motor vehicle to knowingly pull such person.
B.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to knowingly pull or
tow a trailer coach or camp trailer containing any passengers.
C.   Any person who violates subsection A or B of this section shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not to exceed seventy dollars
($70.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 624 §1, 1985)
10.32.070: OBJECTS IN ROADWAY:
No person shall place, or cause to be placed, or let fall and remain in or upon
any roadway any material or thing which is likely to injure persons or damage
property; nor shall any person throw any substance at a vehicle or any occupant
thereof, nor shall any person throw any substance at a person on or adjacent to
a roadway. (Prior code §18-67)
10.32.080: USE OF WARNING DEVICES RESTRICTED:
No person shall sound, use or operate any horn or other warning device on any
vehicle within the city limits for any purpose other than a warning device in
traffic. The use of horns, bells, whistles, sirens or warning devices as a
means of attracting the attention of persons in residences or places of
business is unlawful and constitutes a nuisance. (Prior code §18-68)
10.32.090: INTERFERENCE WITH OR OBSTRUCTION TO DRIVER'S CONTROL OR VIEW
PROHIBITED:
A.   No person shall drive a vehicle when it is loaded, or when there are in
the front seat such a number of persons, but in no vehicle more than three (3),
so as to obstruct the view of the driver in any direction or so as to interfere
with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle.
B.   No passenger in a vehicle shall ride in such position as to interfere with
the driver's view in any direction or to interfere with his control over the
driving mechanism of the vehicle. (Prior code §18-69)
10.32.100: INJURE OR TAMPER WITH VEHICLES:
A.   No person shall, with intent and without right to do so, injure or tamper
with any vehicle or in any other manner damage any part or portion of any
vehicle or any accessories, appurtenances or attachments thereto.
B.   No person, without right to do so and with intent to commit a crime, shall
climb into or upon a vehicle, whether it is in motion or at rest, attempt to
manipulate any of the levers, starting mechanism, brakes or other mechanism or
device of a vehicle while the same is at rest and unattended, or set in motion
any vehicle while the same is at rest and unattended. (Prior code §18-71)
10.32.110: FALSE REPORTS OF VEHICLE THEFT OR CONVERSION PROHIBITED:
No person shall knowingly make a false report of the theft or conversion of a
vehicle to any member of the police department. (Prior code §18-72)
10.32.120: REMOVAL OR AFFIXING OF LICENSE PLATES:
No person shall remove a license plate from a vehicle or affix to a vehicle a
license plate not authorized by law for use on it, in either case with intent
to conceal or misrepresent the identity of the vehicle or its owner. (Prior
code §18-73)
10.32.130: CERTIFICATES OF TITLE AND NUMBER PLATES:
No person shall lend to, sell to, or knowingly permit the use of, by one not
entitled thereto, any certificate of title or number plate issued to or in the
custody of the person so lending or permitting the use thereof, or alter or in
any manner change a certificate of title, registration certificate, or number
plate issued under the laws of this state or any other state. (Prior code §18-
74)
10.32.140: FOLLOWING EMERGENCY APPARATUS:
The driver of any vehicle, other than one on official business, shall not
follow within six hundred feet (600') of any fire, police, ambulance or any
other emergency apparatus traveling in response to any emergency alarm; drive
into, or park such vehicle within the area where such emergency apparatus has
stopped in answer to any emergency; nor pass or obstruct roadways within three
hundred feet (300') of a fire. (Ord. 579 §1, 1983)
10.32.150: LITTERING FROM VEHICLES:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to throw or discard from any
automobile or motor vehicle being operated and driven upon and over the
streets, alleys and roadways of the city any litter, trash, wastepaper, cans or
any other substance or refuse whatever.
B.   No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle unless it is so
constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being
blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place.
C.   Any person who shall violate the provisions of subsections A and B of this
section shall upon conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed seventy
dollars ($70.00) plus costs. (Ord. 563 §1, 1983)
10.32.160: MEETING OR OVERTAKING A STOPPED SCHOOL BUS:
A.   The driver of a vehicle meeting or overtaking a school bus that is stopped
to take on or discharge school children, and on which the red loading signals
are in operation, shall stop his vehicle before it reaches the school bus and
shall not proceed until the loading signals are deactivated and then shall
proceed past such school bus at a speed which is reasonable and with due
caution for the safety of such school children and other occupants.
B.   Any violation of this section shall be deemed unlawful and an offense and
punishable by a fine not to exceed seventy dollars ($70.00). (Ord. 601 §1,
1985)
10.32.170: MEETING OR OVERTAKING A STOPPED CHURCH BUS:
A.   A "church bus" is a vehicle operated by a nonprofit religious organization
which transports persons, including school age children to and from religious
services and activities.
B.   The driver of a vehicle meeting or overtaking a church bus that is stopped
to take on or discharge passengers, and on which the red loading signals are in
operation, is to stop his vehicle before it reaches the church bus and not
proceed until the loading signals are deactivated and then proceed past such
bus at a speed which is reasonable and with due caution for the safety of such
occupants.
C.   Every church bus used for the transportation of persons to and from
religious services and activities shall bear upon the front and rear thereof
plainly visible signs containing the words "Church Bus" in letters not less
than eight inches (8") in height, and, in addition, must be equipped with
visual signals mounted as high and as widely spaced laterally as practicable
and which shall have sufficient intensity to be visible both to the front and
rear of the vehicle from a distance of at least three hundred feet (300') in
normal sunlight and which shall be actuated by the driver of said church bus
whenever, and only whenever, such vehicle is stopped for the purpose of
receiving or discharging passengers.
D.   Any violation of this section shall be deemed unlawful and an offense and
punishable by a fine not to exceed seventy dollars ($70.00). (Ord. 602 §1,
1985)
10.32.180: RIDING IN UNSAFE POSITIONS ON MOVING VEHICLE:
A.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to travel in a moving
motor vehicle and with any part or portion of their torso or lower extremities
of their body protruding outside of said vehicle or to ride in or on any
portion or area of a moving motor vehicle which is not properly equipped or
designed to safely transport passengers.
B.   It shall also be unlawful and an offense for any operator of a moving
motor vehicle to knowingly permit any passenger or occupant of such a vehicle
to travel in such a manner or in an area of the vehicle not properly equipped
or designed to safely transport passengers which is prohibited under subsection
A of this section.
C.   The prohibitions prescribed in this section shall not apply to operators
of moving motor vehicles who extend a part or portion of their body for the
purpose to signal turns and the like to other drivers in a manner which
conforms with accepted safe driving practices or for the purpose of gaining a
better view of the road and oncoming traffic where conditions and due caution
would make such action reasonable. The prohibitions prescribed in this section
shall also not apply to persons traveling in moving motor vehicles or riding in
or on mobile structures or vehicles being pulled or pushed by motor vehicles in
duly recognized and authorized parades or processions through the city nor
shall they apply to any person or employee engaged in the necessary and proper
discharge of his duties, or in the case of persons riding completely within or
upon vehicle bodies in space intended for any load on the vehicle, such as
sitting within the confines of the bed of a pickup truck with the gate door
secured shut.
D.   Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A or B of this
section shall, upon conviction of said offense, be punished by a fine not to
exceed seventy dollars ($70.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 630 §1, 1985)
10.32.190: SAFETY BELTS:
A.   Every operator and front seat passenger of a passenger car operated in
this municipality shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened safety seat belt
system required to be installed in the motor vehicle when manufactured pursuant
to federal motor vehicle safety standard 208. For the purposes of this section,
"passenger car", including vans and pickups, means "vehicle" as defined in 47
Oklahoma Statutes section 1102, except that "passenger car" does not include
trucks, truck-tractors, recreational vehicles, motorcycles, motorized bicycles
or vehicles used primarily for farm use and licensed pursuant to the provisions
of Oklahoma Statutes section 1134.
B.   This section shall not apply to an operator or passenger of a passenger
car in which the operator or passenger possesses a written verification from a
physician licensed in this state that he is unable to wear a safety seat belt
system for medical reasons.
C.   This section shall not apply to an operator of a motor vehicle who is a
route carrier of the U.S. postal service.
D.   This section shall not apply to any passenger vehicle which was
manufactured or assembled before the 1966 models, unless such vehicle is
equipped with a properly adjusted and fastened safety seat belt system.
E.   Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by a fine
of twenty dollars ($20.00) plus CLEET fee. (Ord. 905 §1, 2000: Ord. 677 §1,
1989)
10.32.200: CHILD PASSENGER RESTRAINT SYSTEM:
A.   Every driver, when transporting a child under eight (8) years of age in a
motor vehicle operated on the roadways, streets, or highways of this state,
shall provide for the protection of said child by properly using a child
passenger restraint system as follows:
   1.   A child under four (4) years of age shall be properly secured in a
child passenger restraint system. The child passenger restraint system shall be
rear facing until the child reaches two (2) years of age or until the child
reaches the weight or height limit of the rear facing child passenger restraint
system as allowed by the manufacturer of the child passenger restraint system,
whichever occurs first; and
   2.   A child at least four (4) years of age but younger than eight (8) years
of age, if not taller than four feet nine inches (4'9") in height, shall be
properly secured in either a child passenger restraint system or child booster
seat.
For purposes of this section, "child passenger restraint system" means an
infant or child passenger restraint system which meets the federal standards as
set by 49 CFR, section 571.213.
B.   If a child is eight (8) years of age or is taller than four feet nine
inches (4'9") in height, a seat belt properly secured to the vehicle shall be
sufficient to meet the requirements of this section.
C.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to:
   1.   The driver of a school bus, taxicab, moped, motorcycle, or other motor
vehicle not required to be equipped with safety belts pursuant to state or
federal laws;
   2.   The driver of an ambulance or emergency vehicle;
   3.   The driver of a vehicle in which all of the seat belts are in use;
   4.   The transportation of children who for medical reasons are unable to be
placed in such devices, provided there is written documentation from a
physician of such medical reason; or
   5.   The transportation of a child who weighs more than forty (40) pounds
and who is being transported in the back seat of a vehicle while wearing only a
lap safety belt when the back seat of the vehicle is not equipped with
combination lap and shoulder safety belts, or when the combination lap and
shoulder safety belts in the back seat are being used by other children who
weigh more than forty (40) pounds. Provided, however, for purposes of this
subsection C5, back seat shall include all seats located behind the front seat
of a vehicle operated by a licensed childcare facility or church. Provided
further, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that a child has met the
weight requirements of this subsection C5 if at the request of any law
enforcement officer, the licensed childcare facility or church provides the
officer with a written statement verified by the parent or legal guardian that
the child weighs more than forty (40) pounds.
D.   A law enforcement officer is authorized to stop a vehicle if it appears
that the driver of the vehicle has violated the provisions of this section and
to give an oral warning to the driver. The warning shall advise the driver of
the possible danger to children resulting from the failure to install or use a
child passenger restraint system or seat belts in the motor vehicle.
E.   A person convicted of violating this section shall be subject to a fine in
the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) and all court costs. The fine shall be
suspended by the municipal court and the court costs limited to a maximum of
fifteen dollars ($15.00) in the case of a first offense upon proof of purchase
or acquisition by loan of a child passenger restraint system. (Ord. 1162, 2015)
10.32.210: DOCUMENTS REQUIRED DURING OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided in division B. of this section, at all
times while a vehicle is being used or operated on the roads of this state, the
operator of the vehicle shall have in his or her possession, or carry in the
vehicle and exhibit upon demand to any police officer, either a:
      1.   Registration certificate or an official copy thereof;
      2.   True copy of rental or lease documentation issued for a motor
vehicle;
      3.   Registration certificate or an official copy thereof issued for a
replacement vehicle in the same registration period;
      4.   Temporary receipt printed upon self-initiated electronic renewal of
a registration via the internet; or
      5.   Cab card issued for a vehicle registered under the International
Registration Plan.
   B.   The provisions of division A. of this section shall not apply to the
first thirty (30) days after purchase of a replacement vehicle. (Ord. 1195,
2019)
CHAPTER 10.36
INTOXICATING SUBSTANCES; TRANSPORT AND USE
SECTION:
10.36.010: Driving Under The Influence
10.36.020: Driving While Impaired
10.36.030: Penalty For Violation Of Sections 10.36.010 And 10.36.020 Of This
Chapter
10.36.040: Transporting Nonintoxicating And Intoxicating Alcoholic Beverages
10.36.050: Driving Under The Influence While Underage
10.36.010: DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE:
It is unlawful for any person within this city to drive, operate or be in
actual physical control of any motor vehicle, who is under the influence of
intoxicating liquor, or who is a habitual user of or who is under the influence
of any substance included in the uniform control of dangerous substances act as
adopted by the Oklahoma legislature, or who is under the influence of any other
drug or substance to a degree which would render him incapable of safely
driving a motor vehicle. The fact that any person charged with a violation of
this section is or has been lawfully entitled to use such controlled dangerous
substance or any other drug shall not constitute a defense against any charge
of violating this section. (Ord. 388 §1, 1976)
10.36.020: DRIVING WHILE IMPAIRED:
It is unlawful for any person within this city to drive or operate a motor
vehicle while his ability to operate such motor vehicle is impaired by the
consumption of alcohol or intoxicating liquor which renders the person's
driving ability affected by the consumption of alcohol to the extent that the
public health and safety is threatened, or if the person has violated a state
statute or city ordinance in the operation of a motor vehicle. (Ord. 388 §2,
1976)
10.36.030: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION OF SECTIONS 10.36.010 AND 10.36.020 OF THIS
CHAPTER:
Every person who violates the provisions of section
10.36.010 or
10.36.020 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by
payment of a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus
court costs. (Ord. 1000 §10, 2004: Ord. 966 §1, 2002: Ord. 610 §1, 1985: Ord.
530 §1, 1982)
10.36.040: TRANSPORTING NONINTOXICATING AND INTOXICATING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
A.   It is unlawful for any person to knowingly transport, in any moving
vehicle upon a public highway, street or alley or within any park within the
city limits, any nonintoxicating beverage containing more than one-half of one
percent alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2 percent alcohol by volume or
any intoxicating alcoholic beverage, except in the original container which has
not been opened and from which the original cap or seal has not been removed,
unless the opened container is in the rear trunk or rear compartment, which
includes the spare tire compartment in a station wagon or panel truck or any
outside compartment which is not accessible to the driver or any other person
in the vehicle while it is in motion.
B.   Any person violating the provisions of subsection A of this section is
guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine
not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 610 §2,
1985: Ord. 550 §1, 1983)
10.36.050: DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE WHILE UNDERAGE:
A.   It is unlawful, and punishable as provided in subsection C of this
section, for any person under twenty one (21) years of age to drive, operate,
or be in actual physical control of a motor vehicle within this state who:
   1.   Has any measurable quantity of alcohol in the person's blood or breath
at the time of a test administered within two (2) hours after an arrest of the
person;
   2.   Exhibits evidence of being under the influence of any other
intoxicating substance as shown by analysis of a specimen of the person's
blood, breath, saliva, or urine in accordance with the provisions of sections
752 and 759 of title 47 of the Oklahoma Statutes; or
   3.   Exhibits evidence of the combined influence of alcohol and any other
intoxicating substance.
B.   As used in this section, the term "other intoxicating substance" means any
controlled dangerous substance as defined in the uniform controlled dangerous
substances act, section 2-101 et seq., of title 63 of the Oklahoma Statutes, or
any other substance, other than alcohol, which is capable of being ingested,
inhaled, injected, or absorbed into the human body and is capable of adversely
affecting the central nervous system, vision, hearing, or other sensory or
motor function.
C.   1. Any person under twenty one (21) years of age who violates any
provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of driving under
the influence while underage. A violator shall be punished by a fine of not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), excluding court costs, or by
completion of twenty (20) hours of community service, or by requiring the
person to attend and complete a treatment program, or by any combination of
fine, community service, or treatment.
   2.   The court may assess additional community service hours in lieu of any
fine. (Ord. 1000 §11, 2004: Ord. 813 §1, 1997)
CHAPTER 10.40
SPEED LIMITS 1
SECTION:
10.40.010: Regulations
10.40.020: Maximum Speed Limits Designated
10.40.030: Minimum Speed Limit
10.40.040: Temporary Speed Zones Established
10.40.050: Vehicles With Solid Rubber Or Metal Tires
10.40.060: Reduced Speeds Required
10.40.070: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS §§ 11-801 et seq., 11-803.
10.40.010: REGULATIONS:
A.   No person shall drive any vehicle in violation of the posted speed limits
on any street, road or highway within the city or on any street, road or
highway that forms the boundary line of the city and any other adjacent
political subdivision or otherwise in violation of the speed limit provisions
of this chapter.
B.   No person shall drive a vehicle on any street or roadway within the city
or on any street or roadway that forms the boundary line of the city and any
other adjacent political subdivision at a speed greater or less than is
reasonable or prudent under the conditions then existing, considering, among
other factors, the condition of the vehicle, roadway, weather, visibility,
traffic, presence of pedestrians, and any obstruction of view. No person shall
drive any vehicle upon a street or roadway within the city or on any street or
roadway that forms the boundary line of the city and any other adjacent
political subdivision at a speed greater than will permit him to bring said
vehicle to a safe stop within the assured clear distance ahead under the
conditions then existing. (Ord. 657 §7, 1987)
10.40.020: MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS DESIGNATED:
Unless otherwise posted by action of the council, the maximum speed at which a
motor vehicle may be operated upon the streets of the city shall be limited as
follows:
A.   On NW 39th Street, forty (40) miles per hour;
B.   On NW 50th Street, forty (40) miles per hour east of MacArthur and thirty
five (35) miles per hour west of MacArthur;
C.   On NW 63rd Street, forty (40) miles per hour east of MacArthur and forty
(40) miles per hour west of MacArthur;
D.   On MacArthur Street anywhere within the city limits, forty (40) miles per
hour;
E.   On Grove Street for NW 50th Street to NW 58th Street, thirty (30) miles
per hour;
F.   In all school zones as required, twenty five (25) miles per hour;
G.   On all other streets, twenty five (25) miles per hour. (Ord. 897 §1, 2000:
Ord. 508 §1, 1980: Ord. 503 §1, 1980: Ord. 436 §1, 1976: Ord. 299 §1, 1969:
prior code §18-48)
10.40.030: MINIMUM SPEED LIMIT:
No vehicle shall be driven at such an unreasonably slow speed as to constitute
a hazard to or interfere with the normal movement of other traffic, except when
such speed is unavoidable. (Prior code §18-49)
10.40.040: TEMPORARY SPEED ZONES ESTABLISHED:
The police department shall have the authority to temporarily establish posted
speed zones, reducing or increasing the speeds as set forth in section
10.40.020 of this chapter, if in the judgment of the department the speed limit
set forth is such as will constitute a hazard to life, limb or property, and to
provide for the orderly movement of traffic, such action to be reviewed as
provided by ordinance. (Ord. 437 §1, 1976: prior code §18-50)
10.40.050: VEHICLES WITH SOLID RUBBER OR METAL TIRES:
No person shall drive any vehicle or combination of vehicles with solid rubber
or metal tires at a speed greater than the maximum of ten (10) miles per hour.
(Prior code §18-51)
10.40.060: REDUCED SPEEDS REQUIRED:
The driver of every vehicle shall, consistent with the requirements of this
chapter, drive at an appropriately reduced speed when approaching and crossing
an intersection or railway grade crossing, when approaching and going around a
curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when driving upon any narrow or winding
roadway, and when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other
traffic, or by reason of weather or street conditions. (Prior code §18-52)
10.40.070: PENALTY:
A.   Every person who violates the provisions of section
10.40.020 of this chapter, except subsection
10.40.020F of this chapter, shall, upon conviction thereof, be required to pay
a fine in an amount not in excess of four dollars ($4.00) for each mile per
hour over the applicable or posted speed limit, plus court costs.
B.   Every person who violates the provisions of subsection
10.40.020F of this chapter, pertaining to school zone speed limits, shall, upon
conviction thereof, be required to pay a fine in an amount not in excess of six
dollars ($6.00) for each mile per hour over the speed limit, plus court costs.
(Ord. 1000 §12, 2004: Ord. 657 §7, 1987)
CHAPTER 10.44
ONE-WAY AND THROUGH STREETS; INTERSECTIONS 1
SECTION:
10.44.010: Authority To Designate; Signs Required
10.44.020: Sign Installation
10.44.030: Stop Sign Procedure
10.44.040: Slow And Yield Right Of Way Signs Procedure
10.44.050: Emerging From Alley, Driveway Or Building
10.44.060: Entering Intersections Or Crosswalks
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS §§ 11-308; 1-102; 15-108.
10.44.010: AUTHORITY TO DESIGNATE; SIGNS REQUIRED:
The council, by motion or resolution, may designate certain streets and alleys
or parts of streets and alleys as one-way streets, or through streets and
alleys, and may determine the direction of traffic thereon. Signs giving notice
thereof shall be placed and maintained, and no such regulation shall be
effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of
lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of
traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. (Prior code §18-53)
10.44.020: SIGN INSTALLATION:
Whenever a through street is designated as provided in section
10.44.010 of this chapter, a stop sign, slow sign or yield right of way sign,
as the council deems appropriate, shall be placed and maintained on every
street intersecting such through street, except at an intersection where
traffic control signals are operating. (Prior code §18-54)
10.44.030: STOP SIGN PROCEDURE:
When a stop sign is erected at or near the entrance to any intersection, every
driver of a vehicle shall stop such vehicle at such sign or at a clearly marked
stop line before entering the intersection, except when directed to proceed by
a police officer or traffic control signal. After stopping, the driver may
proceed cautiously, and shall yield the right of way to vehicles not so obliged
to stop which have entered the intersection from the other street or which are
approaching so closely thereon as to constitute an immediate hazard. (Prior
code §18-55)
10.44.040: SLOW AND YIELD RIGHT OF WAY SIGNS PROCEDURE:
When a slow or a yield right of way sign is erected as provided in section
10.44.020 of this chapter at or near the entrance to any intersection, every
driver of a vehicle shall slow such vehicle to a speed of not more than ten
(10) miles per hour by the time the vehicle is even with the sign, except when
directed to proceed by a police officer or a traffic control signal. The driver
may then proceed cautiously and shall yield the right of way to vehicles not
obliged to stop or to slow down, which have entered the intersection from the
other street or which are approaching so closely thereon as to constitute an
immediate hazard. (Prior code §18-56)
10.44.050: EMERGING FROM ALLEY, DRIVEWAY OR BUILDING:
The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop
such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or onto the sidewalk
area extending across the alleyway, driveway or exit, yielding the right of way
to any pedestrian as may be necessary to avoid collision, and, upon entering
the street, shall yield the right of way to all vehicles on the street which
are approaching or are near enough to constitute an immediate hazard. (Prior
code §18-57)
10.44.060: ENTERING INTERSECTIONS OR CROSSWALKS:
No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is
sufficient space on the other side of the intersection, in the intersection or
crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the
passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control
signal indication to proceed. (Prior code §18-58)
CHAPTER 10.48
STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 1
SECTION:
10.48.010: Prohibited In Specified Places
10.48.012: Adjacent To Schools, Hazardous Or Congested Places
10.48.015: Definitions
10.48.020: General Regulations
10.48.030: Parking Within Marked Spaces
10.48.031: Parking For Disabled
10.48.032: Enforcement
10.48.033: Penalties
10.48.040: Double Parking
10.48.050: Parking Time Limits And Prohibitions
10.48.060: Parking Commercial Vehicles In Residential Areas
10.48.070: Violations
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 11-1101 et seq.
10.48.010: PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES:
No person shall park, stop or stand a vehicle, except in emergencies and when
necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the
directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the
following places:
A.   On a sidewalk or sidewalk area, or in such manner as to obstruct or
interfere with pedestrian traffic thereon;
B.   In front of a public or private driveway or alley;
C.   In or within forty five feet (45') of an intersection;
D.   Within ten feet (10') of a fire hydrant or within one hundred fifty feet
(150') of the entrance to a fire station, except in parking spaces marked off
on the surface of the roadway, or on any street which is posted as a fire lane;
E.   On a crosswalk;
F.   Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk, except in parking spaces marked
off on the surface of the roadway, or on any street which is posted as a fire
lane;
G.   Within thirty feet (30') of any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic
control signal or device;
H.   Within any bus loading or taxicab zone when such zone has been officially
designated and appropriately marked, except that the driver of a private
passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein while actually engaged in
loading or unloading passengers, provided such stopping does not interfere with
any bus or taxicab about to enter such zone;
I.   Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing;
