J.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation, construction or obstruction
when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic, interfere with the
work, or create a hazard;
K.   On the paved or surfaced area of any highway without curbing and having a
graded or improved shoulder area intended for use of vehicles in case of a
necessity;
L.   At any place where official signs prohibit stopping, standing or parking,
or in any manner that will interfere with the orderly, free movement of
traffic, including, but not limited to:
   1.   Either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property,
together with other places as designated by the chief of police, where parking,
standing or stopping of vehicles would interfere with the flow of traffic or
create a hazardous situation.
M.   Upon a street in such manner or under such condition as to leave available
less than ten feet (10') of width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular
traffic;
N.   Within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave
available less than ten feet (10') of the width of the roadway for the free
movement of traffic; and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within
an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting
property. No person shall park a vehicle in any alley except for the purpose
of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading merchandise or other
materials;
O.   On any street for a period of time longer than seventy two (72) hours;
P.   Upon any street for the principal purpose of:
   1.   Displaying such vehicle for sale, or
   2.   Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except as necessitated by
an emergency; or
Q.   Upon the posted property of another without first obtaining permission
from the landowner or the person in charge of such property, except where said
placing or parking is casual or involuntary. (Ord. 1037 §1, 2007: Ord. 867 §1,
1998: prior code §18-90)
10.48.012: ADJACENT TO SCHOOLS, HAZARDOUS OR CONGESTED PLACES:
In addition to the traffic commission, the police chief is hereby authorized to
determine and designate by proper signs, places, including sides of streets
adjacent to any school property, when in his or her opinion such parking,
standing or stopping of vehicle would create any hazardous condition or would
cause a delay to traffic. After such signs are so erected and in place, no
person shall park, stand or stop a vehicle in any such designated place, and a
violation thereof shall constitute an offense. (Ord. 1037 §2, 2007)
10.48.015: DEFINITIONS:
The words "vehicle" or "motor vehicle" shall include any automobile, truck,
bus, motor home, recreational or hauling trailer, any trailer, boat or boat
trailer, camper, golf cart, go-cart, motorcycle, motorbike or motor scooter.
(Ord. 911 §1, 2000)
10.48.020: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than next to the
edge of the roadway, on the right side thereof, and with the right hand wheels
of the vehicle within eighteen inches (18") of the curb or edge of the roadway,
except as otherwise provided in this title. No driver of a vehicle shall leave
the vehicle with the motor running while parked. (Prior code §18-88)
10.48.030: PARKING WITHIN MARKED SPACES:
In an area where parking spaces have been marked off on the surface of the
roadway, a driver parking a vehicle shall park it within a parking space as
thus marked off, and not on or across the lines delimiting the spaces. (Prior
code §18-89)
10.48.031: PARKING FOR DISABLED:
It is unlawful for any person to place or park a motor vehicle in any parking
space that is designated and posted as a reserved area for parking of motor
vehicles of a physically disabled person unless such vehicle is eligible for a
detachable insignia or reflective insignia is displayed as provided in
accordance with state law or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. The
provisions of this section and sections
10.48.032 and
10.48.033 of this chapter shall apply to any such designated or posted area on
public or private property accessible to the public and where the public is
invited. (Ord. 545 §1, 1982)
10.48.032: ENFORCEMENT:
The chief of police and persons under his authority are authorized to enforce
the provisions of this section and sections
10.48.031 and
10.48.033 of this chapter on private property where the public is invited.
(Ord. 545 §1, 1982)
10.48.033: PENALTIES:
Any person convicted of violation of section
10.48.031 of this chapter shall pay a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00)
including court costs. (Ord. 545 §1, 1982)
10.48.040: DOUBLE PARKING:
No driver shall double park or double stop a vehicle upon any street, except
along the south side of 40th Street, between Grove and MacArthur, during normal
school hours, and then only when loading and unloading passengers; provided the
driver must not leave the vehicle unattended for any period of time. (Prior
code §18-91)
10.48.050: PARKING TIME LIMITS AND PROHIBITIONS:
The council by motion or resolution is authorized to have established parking
time limits or to prohibit parking on designated streets or parts of streets.
Whenever any parking time limit or prohibition is thus imposed, appropriate
signs or markings giving notice thereof shall be placed, and no such time limit
or prohibition shall be effective unless such signs or markings are in place at
the time of any alleged offense. (Prior code §18-92)
10.48.060: PARKING COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS:
It is an offense for any commercial vehicle in excess of three-quarter ton
rating to park on the streets within the residential areas of the city for a
period greater than one hour, except during periods of loading and unloading.
(Prior code §18-93)
10.48.070: VIOLATIONS:
Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle standing upon a street in violation
of any of the provisions of this chapter, such officer is authorized to move
such vehicle or require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to
move the same to a position off of the paved or main traveled part of the
street. (Prior code §18-94)
CHAPTER 10.52
LOADING ZONES AND PUBLIC CARRIER STOPS
SECTION:
10.52.010: Loading Zones
10.52.020: Public Carrier Stops
10.52.010: LOADING ZONES:
The council, by motion or resolution, may have established passenger and
freight curb loading zones. Appropriate signs indicating the same and stating
the hours during which the respective zones are to be reserved for loading
zones shall be placed and maintained. (Prior code §18-95)
10.52.020: PUBLIC CARRIER STOPS:
The council, by motion or resolution, is authorized to have established bus and
taxicab stops or other passenger common carrier vehicle stops on such public
streets, in such places, and in such manner as it determines to be of the
greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus and taxicab stop
or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. (Prior code §18-96)
CHAPTER 10.56
EMERGENCY VEHICLES
SECTION:
10.56.010: Right Of Way
10.56.020: Eluding Police Officer Prohibited
10.56.030: Violation; Penalties
10.56.010: RIGHT OF WAY:
Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle, the driver of
every other vehicle shall yield the right of way, and shall immediately drive
to a position parallel to and as close as possible to the right hand edge of
curb of the roadway, clear of any intersection, and shall stop and remain in
such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when
otherwise directed by a police officer. (Prior code §18-22)
10.56.020: ELUDING POLICE OFFICER PROHIBITED:
A.   No person operating a motor vehicle who has received a visual and audible
signal (a red light and a siren in the case of a clearly designated police
vehicle driven by a police officer) directing the operator to bring his vehicle
to a stop shall wilfully increase his speed or extinguish his light or in any
other manner attempt to or actually elude such police officer. (Ord. 537 §2,
1982: Ord. 477 §1, 1978)
10.56.030: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
A.   Any person who shall violate section
10.56.010 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by the
payment of a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court
costs.
B.   Any person who shall violate section
10.56.020 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by the
payment of a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), plus
court costs. (Ord. 1000 §8, 2004: Ord. 966 §2, 2002: Ord. 650 §2, 1987)
CHAPTER 10.60
TRUCK ROUTES
SECTION:
10.60.010: Definitions
10.60.020: Application
10.60.030: Exceptions
10.60.040: Routes Established
10.60.050: Truck Traffic In The City
10.60.060: Enforcement
10.60.070: Penalty
10.60.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms and words shall have the
meanings given herein. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
CITY: The city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma.
DEVIATING TRUCK: A truck which travels upon a route other than a truck route
while traveling inside the city.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
TRUCK: Any vehicle exceeding two (2) axles designed or operated for the
transportation of property; provided, truck shall not be construed to include
recreational vehicles or vehicles towing trailers transporting recreational
vehicles and recreational equipment.
TRUCK ROUTE: A way over certain streets as designated herein over and along
which trucks must operate. (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.020: APPLICATION:
All trucks within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck
routes established herein or other designated streets over which truck travel
is permitted. (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.030: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not prohibit:
A.   Operation On Street Of Destination: The operation of trucks upon any
street where necessary to the conduct of business of delivering or picking up
materials, merchandise or property at a destination point, provided streets
upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection
nearest the destination point;
B.   Emergency Vehicle: The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in
the city;
C.   Public Utilities: The operation of trucks owned or operated by the city,
public utilities, franchise holders, any contractor or material man, while
engaged in the repair, maintenance, or construction on public easements or
rights of way. (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.040: ROUTES ESTABLISHED:
The following streets are designated as truck routes within the city:
A.   All officially designated federal and state highways;
B.   North MacArthur from the southern to northern limits of the city;
C.   Northwest 39th Street from the eastern to western limits of the city;
D.   Northeast Highway from the eastern to western limits of the city;
E.   Northwest 63rd Street east of MacArthur to eastern limits of the city;
F.   Northwest 50th Street east of MacArthur to eastern limits of the city.
(Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.050: TRUCK TRAFFIC IN THE CITY:
All trucks operating in the city shall proceed only over established truck
routes. Provided for destination points of such truck routes, the truck shall
deviate only along the shortest route between destinations, and only when such
shortest route is significantly shorter than a route utilizing a return to the
truck route. Upon leaving the final destination point, a deviating truck shall
return to the truck route the shortest permissible route. (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.060: ENFORCEMENT:
A.   The city clerk shall keep and maintain maps setting out truck routes which
shall be on file in the office of the city clerk and available to the public.
B.   The chief of police shall cause all truck routes and streets upon which
such traffic is permitted to be posted by appropriate signs providing notice of
the ordinance codified in this chapter. In addition, he shall post such signs
as he deems necessary to provide notice of streets where truck traffic is
prohibited. (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
10.60.070: PENALTY:
Any person who violates this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and, upon
conviction, shall be subject to a fine of not more than thirty five dollars
($35.00). (Ord. 523 §1, 1982)
CHAPTER 10.64
INSPECTION OF VEHICLES
SECTION:
10.64.010: Vehicle Defined
10.64.020: License Plate
10.64.030: Headlights And Taillights
10.64.040: Vehicle Equipment
10.64.050: Radios On Law Enforcement Agency Or Fire Department Frequency
10.64.060: Television Sets Visible From Driver's Seat Prohibited
10.64.065: Sound Amplification Systems
10.64.070: Authority; Vehicles Suspected Of Being In Violation
10.64.075: Lamp Restrictions
10.64.080: Penalties For Violating Section 10.64.075 Of This Chapter
10.64.010: VEHICLE DEFINED:
Within the meaning of this chapter, a "vehicle" is defined to be any device in,
upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon
a roadway, excepting devices moved by human powers. (Prior code §18-12)
10.64.020: LICENSE PLATE:
All vehicles shall have displayed the current year's license plate assigned to
it, in compliance with the laws of the state, and the same shall be kept in a
clean condition and lighted in such manner as to be visible and easily read at
all times during the day or night. (Prior code §18-8)
10.64.030: HEADLIGHTS AND TAILLIGHTS:
All vehicles, except motorcycles, must have two (2) headlights and two (2) red
taillights, with a white light illuminating the license plate. All headlights
must have a high and a low beam in proper working condition. Driving with
blinding lights such as to impair or hinder the ordinary vision is prohibited.
The use of red or blue lights and/or lenses showing from the front, a bell or
siren on any vehicle, with the exception of authorized emergency vehicles (and
school buses, i.e., red lights), is prohibited. Motorcycles and bicycles must
have one headlight and one red taillight. All types of trailers, including, but
not limited to, hauling, utility, boat, motorcycle and semitrailers, must be
equipped with at least one red taillight which is visible from a distance of
five hundred feet (500') to the rear and located at heights of not more than
seventy two inches (72") and not less than twenty inches (20"). All trailers
required to have a license must also have a white light to illuminate the
license plate. Additionally all trailers shall be coupled with stay chains or
cables to the vehicle by which they are being drawn. Such chains or cables
shall be of sufficient size and strength to prevent parting from the drawing
vehicle should the regular coupling device break or become otherwise
disengaged. (Ord. 934 §1, 2001: Ord. 856 §1, 1998: prior code §18-9)
10.64.040: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT:
All vehicles shall be equipped with the following:
A.   Mirrors: Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with: 1) a mirror mounted
on the left side of the vehicle and so positioned and located as to reflect to
the driver a view of the highway or street to the rear of the motor vehicle;
and 2) an additional mirror mounted either inside the vehicle in approximately
the center or outside of the vehicle on the right side and so positioned and
located as to reflect to the driver a view of the highway or street to the rear
of the vehicle;
B.   Brakes: Brakes, adequate to control the movement, to stop and hold such
vehicle within a reasonably safe distance under the conditions;
C.   Steering Apparatus: Steering apparatus, maintained in good condition so as
to be secure and free from excessive wear and/or play;
D.   Windshields And Windows: Windshields and windows shall be kept clean so
that the vision of the driver, in any direction shall not be impaired. No
person shall drive any motor vehicle with any sign, poster, or other
nontransparent material upon the front windshield, side wings, or side or rear
windows of such vehicle, which obstructs the driver's clear view of the
highway/roadway or any intersecting highway/roadway. The windshield on every
motor vehicle shall be equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other
moisture from the windshield, which device shall be so constructed as to be
controlled or operated by the driver of the vehicle. Every windshield wiper
upon a motor vehicle shall be maintained in good working order;
E.   Mufflers: Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a
muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or
unusual noise and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cutout,
bypass or similar device upon a motor vehicle in any manner which will amplify
or increase the noise or sound emitted louder than that emitted by the muffler
originally installed on the vehicle;
F.   Horn: A horn, in good working order capable of emitting a sound under
normal conditions from a distance of not less than two hundred feet (200'), but
no horn or other warning device shall emit an unreasonably loud, harsh sound or
a whistle. (Ord. 1064 §1, 2009: Ord. 934 §1, 2001: prior code §18-10)
10.64.050: RADIOS ON LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY OR FIRE DEPARTMENT FREQUENCY:
No vehicle shall be equipped with a radio capable of transmitting or receiving
on any law enforcement agency or fire department radio frequency unless
properly licensed and authorized. (Prior code §18-11)
10.64.060: TELEVISION SETS VISIBLE FROM DRIVER'S SEAT PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to operate a vehicle upon the
streets of the city in which there is installed a television set, the screen of
which can be seen by any person sitting in the seat from which such vehicle is
operated. (Ord. 434 §1, 1976: prior code §18-13)
10.64.065: SOUND AMPLIFICATION SYSTEMS:
A.   No person operating or occupying a motor vehicle on a street, highway,
alley, parking lot, or driveway shall operate or permit the operation of any
sound amplification system from within the vehicle so that the sound is plainly
audible at a distance of fifty feet (50') or more from the vehicle.
B.   "Sound amplification system" means any radio, tape player, compact disc
player, loudspeaker, or other electronic device used for the amplification of
the human voice.
C.   "Plainly audible" means any sound produced by a sound amplification system
from within the vehicle which clearly can be heard at a distance of fifty feet
(50') or more. Measurement standards shall be by the auditory senses, based
upon the direct line of sight. Words or phrases need not be discernible and
bass reverberations are included. The motor vehicle may be stopped, standing,
parked or moving on a street, highway, alley, parking lot or driveway.
D.   It is an affirmative defense to a charge under this section that the
operator was not otherwise prohibited by law from operating the sound
amplification system, and that any of the following apply:
   1.   The system was being operated to request medical or vehicular
assistance or to warn of a hazardous road condition;
   2.   The vehicle was an emergency or public safety vehicle;
   3.   The vehicle was owned and operated by the city or public or private
utility company;
   4.   The vehicle was used in authorized public activities, such as parades,
fireworks, sports events, or other activities which are approved by the city
council, mayor, or police chief.
E.   Any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction,
shall be subject to a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord.
715 §1, 1991)
10.64.070: AUTHORITY; VEHICLES SUSPECTED OF BEING IN VIOLATION:
Police officers shall have authority to stop, inspect and test vehicles upon
the streets of the city at any time, upon belief that such vehicle is being
operated in violation of any provision of this title, to determine whether it
is safe, whether it is properly equipped and/or whether its equipment is in
proper operating condition, adjustment or repair. (Prior code §18-7)
10.64.075: LAMP RESTRICTIONS:
A.   No person shall drive or move any vehicle or equipment upon any highway,
street, or other public roadway with any lamp or device thereon displaying a
red or blue light visible from directly in front of the center thereof. This
section shall not apply to any vehicle, which a red or blue light visible from
the front is expressly authorized or required by this or any other title.
B.   Flashing lights are prohibited except on an authorized emergency vehicle,
school bus, or "church bus" as defined by this title and state law, snow
removal equipment, wreckers and tow vehicles while at the scene of an
emergency, or any vehicle as a means of indicating a right or left turn, or the
presence of a vehicular traffic hazard requiring unusual care in approaching,
overtaking or passing. Flashing red or blue lights or a combination of flashing
red and blue lights may be used on authorized emergency vehicles, or on
vehicles or machinery owned or operated by any agency of the state, or by any
county or city while engaged in the performance of emergency work or on the
construction or maintenance of highways or bridges, or on wreckers and tow
vehicles at the scene of an emergency.
C.   Blue lights are prohibited except as allowed in subsection B of this
section. (Ord. 958 §1, 2002)
10.64.080: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATING SECTION 10.64.075 OF THIS CHAPTER:
Any person who violates the provisions of section
10.64.075 of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs. (Ord. 958 §1,
2002)
CHAPTER 10.68
UNLAWFUL VEHICLES
SECTION:
10.68.010: Vehicles Capable Of Injuring Street
10.68.020: Construction Or Load Of Vehicle Causing Hazard Or Delay
10.68.030: Oversized Vehicle
10.68.040: Toy Vehicles
10.68.010: VEHICLES CAPABLE OF INJURING STREET:
No vehicle or object which injures or would injure the surface of a street
shall be driven or moved on any roadway. (Prior code §18-24)
10.68.020: CONSTRUCTION OR LOAD OF VEHICLE CAUSING HAZARD OR DELAY:
No person shall drive any vehicle in such condition, so constructed or so
loaded as to cause delay or to be likely to cause delay in traffic, or as to
constitute a hazard to persons or property, except by permit issued by the
chief of police and in accordance with the terms of such permit. (Prior code
§18-25)
10.68.030: OVERSIZED VEHICLE:
No person shall drive upon any roadway any vehicle the width, height, length,
weight or load of which exceeds that authorized by state law, except in
accordance with a permit issued by state authority or by the chief of police.
(Prior code §18-25(a))
10.68.040: TOY VEHICLES:
A.   No person shall operate a golf cart, go-cart, scooter, minibike or an all-
terrain vehicle upon the streets of the city except as provided in this
subsection. Such vehicles shall be permitted if:
   1.   The street is designated for speeds of twenty five (25) miles per hour
or less; and
   2.   The operation of the vehicle occurs not less than one hour prior to
sunset and not earlier than one hour after sunrise; and
   3.   The vehicle has not been modified from the basic factory
specifications; and
   4.   The vehicle is operated in a safe and reasonable manner consistent with
public safety and in compliance with all applicable rules of the road.
B.   Any person, firm or corporation who violates the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of an offense and assessed a fine of
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 1019 §1,
2006)
CHAPTER 10.72
PEDESTRIANS 1
SECTION:
10.72.010: Traffic Control Devices
10.72.020: Crosswalks; Right Of Way
10.72.030: Crossing Roadways
10.72.040: Crossing At Other Than Crosswalk
10.72.050: General Regulations
10.72.060: Drivers To Exercise Due Caution
10.72.070: Soliciting Rides Or Business
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 11-501 et seq.
10.72.010: TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control devices as heretofore provided
in this title, but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted the rights
and be subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter. (Prior code §18-75)
10.72.020: CROSSWALKS; RIGHT OF WAY:
A.   When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation, the
driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way, slowing down or stopping if
need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk
when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is
traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite
half of a roadway as to be in danger; but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a
curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which
is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield.
B.   Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked
crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the
driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and
pass such stopped vehicle. (Prior code §18-76)
10.72.030: CROSSING ROADWAYS:
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any point other than within a marked
crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (Prior code §18-77)
10.72.040: CROSSING AT OTHER THAN CROSSWALK:
Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked
crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the
right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (Prior code §18-78)
10.72.050: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
A.   Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control devices are in
operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk.
B.   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any
business district.
C.   No pedestrian shall cross a street designated as a through street, as
provided in this title, other than in a crosswalk. (Prior code §17-79)
10.72.060: DRIVERS TO EXERCISE DUE CAUTION:
Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter relative to pedestrians, every
driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any
pedestrian upon any roadway, and shall give warning by sounding the horn when
necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any
confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. (Prior code §18-80)
10.72.070: SOLICITING RIDES OR BUSINESS:
A.   No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride,
donation, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle.
B.   Any person who violates the provisions of subsection A of this section,
shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than seventy
five dollars ($75.00), plus court costs. (Ord. 952 §1, 2001)
CHAPTER 10.76
MOTORCYCLES AND MOTOR SCOOTERS 1
SECTION:
10.76.010: Short Title
10.76.020: General Regulations
10.76.030: Speed Limitations
10.76.040: Equipment
10.76.050: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS §§ 22.12 et seq., 11-1103, ch. 40.
10.76.010: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be cited as the MOTORCYCLE AND MOTOR SCOOTER REQUIREMENTS of
the city. (Prior code §18-108(c))
10.76.020: GENERAL REGULATIONS:
No driver of a two (2) wheel or three (3) wheel motor vehicle shall carry any
person on, upon or within such vehicle on any street or highway in the city,
except as provided in this section; provided, however, that if any two (2)
wheel or three (3) wheel motor vehicle with a wheel diameter of twelve inches
(12") or greater has either a double seating device with double footrests or a
sidecar attachment providing a separate seat space within such sidecar
attachment for each person riding therein so that such person is seated
entirely within the body of the sidecar, then it shall be permissible for an
operator who has attained the age of sixteen (16) years or older to carry a
passenger. A demonstration ride by a licensed dealer or his employee is
excepted from the provisions of this section. No motorcycle or motor scooter
shall be ridden upon any sidewalk of the city. Handlebars on motorcycles and
motor scooters shall not exceed twelve inches (12") in height, measured from
the crown or point of the attachment. No rider of a motorcycle or motor scooter
shall hold to any moving vehicle for the purpose of being propelled. (Prior
code §18-105)
10.76.030: SPEED LIMITATIONS:
No person shall operate any motorcycle or motor scooter at a speed greater than
the speed limit legally posted; provided however, in no event nor at any time
may an operator under the age of sixteen (16) years operate a motorcycle or
motor scooter at a speed greater than thirty (30) miles per hour. (Prior code
§18-106)
10.76.040: EQUIPMENT:
A.   Rear View Mirrors: All vehicles covered under this section shall be
equipped with two (2) mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than
three inches (3") in diameter, mounted one on each side of the vehicle and
positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a
distance of two hundred feet (200') to the rear of such vehicle.
B.   Windshield: All vehicles covered under this chapter shall be equipped with
a windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect the operator
from foreign objects, except that in lieu of such windshield the operator shall
wear goggles or a face shield of material and design to protect him from
foreign objects.
C.   Brakes: All vehicles covered under this chapter shall be equipped with
brakes adequate to control the movement of the same to stop and hold such
vehicle, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes. One means
shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel and one means shall
be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheels.
D.   Speedometer: All vehicles covered under this chapter shall be equipped
with a properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least thirty
five (35) miles per hour.
E.   Fenders: All vehicles covered under this chapter shall be equipped with a
fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type provided by the
manufacturer.
F.   Lights: All vehicles covered under this chapter shall carry at least one
headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at least three hundred feet
(300') in the direction in which the same are proceeding, and one taillamp
mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall emit a red light plainly visible
from at least three hundred feet (300') to the rear; and such lights required
by this chapter shall be burning whenever such vehicles are in motion during
the period from one-half (1/2) hour after sunset to one-half (1/2) hour before
sunrise and at any time when due to insufficient light or unfavorable
atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the streets are not clearly
discernible at a distance of at least five hundred feet (500') ahead.
G.   Headgear: No person shall operate or ride upon any vehicle covered under
this chapter unless such person is equipped with and wearing on the head a
crash helmet of the type and design manufactured for use by the operators of
such vehicles. All crash helmets shall include lining, padding and chinstraps.
(Prior code §18-107)
10.76.050: PENALTY:
Any person violating a provision of this chapter is guilty of an offense, and
each violation shall be considered a separate offense; and upon conviction of
any offense, any person violating a provision of this chapter shall be punished
by a fine not exceeding seventy dollars ($70.00) for each offense. (Ord. 943
§1, 2001: prior code §18-109)
CHAPTER 10.80
BICYCLES 1
SECTION:
10.80.010: Traffic Regulations
10.80.020: Equipment
10.80.030: Clinging To Vehicles
10.80.060: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS § 11-1201 et seq.
10.80.010: TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
Traffic laws and regulations shall apply to persons riding bicycles. Every
person riding a bicycle upon a roadway or street in the city shall be granted
all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the
driver of any vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road
applicable to vehicles, or the ordinances of the city applicable to drivers of
vehicles, except as to special regulations therein which by their nature can
have no application. (Prior code §18-81)
10.80.020: EQUIPMENT:
Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the
front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five
hundred feet (500') to the front and with red reflector on the rear of the
bicycle of a type which shall be visible from distances from fifty feet (50')
to three hundred feet (300') to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper
beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting red light visible from a
distance of five hundred feet (500') to the rear may be used instead of or in
addition to the red reflector. Every person operating a bicycle shall equip the
same with a bell or horn for giving a signal audible for a distance of one
hundred feet (100'). Sirens and whistles are prohibited as signal devices.
Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to
make the braked wheels skid on a dry, level, clean pavement. (Prior code §18-
82)
10.80.030: CLINGING TO VEHICLES:
No person riding on any bicycle shall attach the same or himself to any other
vehicle which may be in motion upon any street or roadway. (Prior code §18-83)
10.80.060: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation, either as principal or agent, who violates any
provision of this chapter is guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be
fined not to exceed nineteen dollars ($19.00) and one dollar ($1.00) costs, and
upon conviction of two (2) or more violations of this chapter the municipal
judge, in his discretion, may order the impoundment of such convicted person's
bicycle for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days. Any person who aids,
abets, or assists in the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not to exceed nineteen dollars ($19.00) and one dollar ($1.00)
costs. (Prior code §18-86)
CHAPTER 10.84
ABANDONED VEHICLES 1
SECTION:
10.84.010: Short Title
10.84.020: Definitions
10.84.030: Public Property; Nuisance
10.84.040: Private Property; Nuisance
10.84.045: Additional Requirements; Off Street Parking
10.84.050: Notice Of Removal
10.84.060: Notice Of Procedure
10.84.070: Hearing Procedures
10.84.080: Removal Of Vehicles Or Trailers
10.84.090: Notification Of Removal
10.84.100: Disposition Of Motor Vehicles Or Trailers
10.84.120: Alternative Sales Procedure
10.84.130: Redemption Of Motor Vehicle Or Trailer Prior To Sale
10.84.140: Liability For Towing And Storage Expenses
10.84.150: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS ch. 71.
10.84.010: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the ABANDONED, WRECKED,
DISMANTLED OR INOPERATIVE MOTOR VEHICLE OR HAULING TRAILER ORDINANCE. (Ord. 866
§1, 1998)
10.84.020: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their
derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with
the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the
plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
CITY: The city of Warr Acres.
COSTS: The expense of removing, transporting, storing and selling an impounded
vehicle or trailer including the costs of notification.
INOPERABLE HAULING TRAILER: A hauling trailer, the condition of which is
wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, incapable of being pulled behind an
automobile or truck upon a public street, or from a wheel or wheels or any
substantial part thereof have been removed.
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: A motor vehicle, the condition of which is wrecked,
dismantled, partially dismantled, incapable of operation by its own power upon
a public street, or from which the wheel(s), engine, transmission or any
substantial part thereof have been removed, which lawfully has affixed thereto
an unexpired license plate and a current motor vehicle inspection certificate.
LIEN HOLDER: Those persons shown as lien holders on the vehicle title.
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle which is self-propelled and designed to travel along
the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses,
motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, go-carts, golf carts
or recreational vehicles (RVs).
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
POLICE DEPARTMENT: The police department of the city of Warr Acres.
PRIVATE PROPERTY: Any real property within the city which is privately owned
and which is not public property as defined in this section.
PROPERTY: Any street, right of way or highway which shall include the entire
width between the boundary lines of every such way and shall also mean any
other publicly owned property or facility.
TRAILER, HAULING: "Hauling trailer" means a conveyance transport with an axle
and tongue designed to be pulled behind an automobile or truck to haul animals,
produce goods, commodities, boats, watercraft, motorcycles, trash, etc.
WRECKED MOTOR VEHICLE: Any motor vehicle which does not have lawfully affixed
thereto both an unexpired license plate and a current motor vehicle safety
inspection certificate, and the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled,
partially dismantled, incapable of operation by its own power on a public
street, or from which the wheel(s), engine, transmission or any substantial
part thereof have been removed. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.030: PUBLIC PROPERTY; NUISANCE:
No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or leaving of
any motor vehicle or hauling trailer of any kind which is in an abandoned,
wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, junked or partially dismantled condition
whether attended or not, upon any public property within the city for a period
of time in excess of seventy two (72) hours. The presence of an abandoned,
wrecked, dismantled, inoperative, junked or partially dismantled vehicle or
hauling trailer or parts thereof, on public property is declared a public
nuisance which may be abated as such in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.040: PRIVATE PROPERTY; NUISANCE:
A.   No person shall park, store, leave or permit the parking, storing or
leaving of any wrecked or inoperable motor vehicle or hauling trailer of any
kind, whether attended or not, upon any private property within the city,
except that, with respect to an inoperable motor vehicle or hauling trailer,
such vehicle may be parked, stored or left on such property for a period of
time not to exceed seventy two (72) hours. The presence of such vehicles or
hauling trailer, or parts thereof, on private property is declared a public
nuisance which may be abated in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
B.   This section shall not apply to:
   1.   Any motor vehicle or hauling trailer parked or stored within a
building, private garage, or behind a sightproof fence meeting the fencing
requirements as set out in title 16,
chapter 16.40 of this code;
   2.   Any motor vehicle or hauling trailer held in connection with a business
enterprise lawfully licensed by the city for the servicing and repair of such
vehicles and properly operated in an appropriate business zone pursuant to the
zoning ordinances of the city;
   3.   Any motor vehicle for which a permit has been obtained, said permit to
be obtained from the office of the city clerk at a cost of one hundred dollars
($100.00) each; provided, that no such permit may exceed a period of ninety
(90) days and shall not be renewable, extended or reissued on any one vehicle.
(Ord. 1026 §1, 2006: Ord. 921 §1, 2001: Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.045: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS; OFF STREET PARKING:
A.   Noncommercial Vehicles: No operator or owner of any noncommercial motor
vehicle or trailer, nor owner or person exercising dominion over any real
property within the city shall park or allow the parking of any motor vehicle
or trailer upon any property in the city of Warr Acres except upon an
artificial surface meeting adopted design specifications as set out in title 12
of this code. In particular, the surface shall always meet the following
requirements:
   1.   A Portland cement concrete pavement surface with a minimum depth of
four inches (4") and wide enough to extend from side to side of the vehicles or
trailers parked on said surface and of sufficient length to extend from bumper
to bumper of the vehicle parked on said surface; or
   2.   Asphalt-concrete pavement of uniform thickness of two inches (2") and
meeting all other requirements of subsection A of this section.
B.   Exceptions: The provisions of subsection A of this section shall not be
applicable to the following situations:
   1.   To real property under active construction and improvement pursuant to
a valid and duly issued building permit.
   2.   To legally nonconforming off street parking surfaces.
   3.   To vehicles parked completely to the rear of the front wall of the main
building on the property.
   4.   In any case where a variance from the provisions of this section has
been granted by the board of adjustment of the city of Warr Acres and the
parking is in accordance with the terms of the variance.
C.   Vacant Or Undeveloped Lot Requirements: No vacant or undeveloped lot shall
be used for temporary or permanent storage or parking of any vehicle, whether
operable or inoperable, motorized or designed to be towed, unless such lot is
within a zoning district that permits such activity. Adjoining lots, owned by
the same person, one of which is residential in nature, shall be considered as
one.
D.   Specific Vehicles Prohibited: In no instance shall truck tractors,
semitrailers, or any commercial vehicles in excess of two (2) axles or in
excess of twenty five feet (25') in length, be permitted to be parked, stored
or displayed on residential lots or any tracts which are not zoned to permit
such use regardless of the type of parking surface. No residentially zoned
vacant or undeveloped lot shall be interpreted as permitting such activity.
E.   Additional Vehicle Parking: The front yard of a lot containing a single-
family residence or duplex may be used for the parking of motor homes,
recreational vehicles, boat trailers, travel trailers, or utility trailers or
parts thereof for over seventy two (72) hours in any one week's time provided
either of the two (2) requirements listed below are met:
   1.   The vehicles are parked on a driveway, which conforms to standards set
forth in title 12 of this code;
   2.   There is no access to the side or rear yard for such parking; provided,
that a corner lot shall always be deemed to have such access.
F.   Variances: Any person subject to the provisions of this section may apply
for, and the city council may grant, a variance from the provisions of this
section to any property, where the city council finds that due to unusual or
particular circumstances of the case, the strict application of the provisions
of this section would result in an undue hardship. The variance shall be
limited to the time during which the hardship exists.
G.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court
costs and fees. Each day a violation is allowed to exist shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. 1011 §1, 2005: Ord. 923 §1, 2001)
10.84.050: NOTICE OF REMOVAL:
Whenever it comes to the attention of the police department that any nuisance,
as defined in this chapter appears to exist on a public property, the police
department shall cause a written notice to be affixed to the vehicle or
trailer, declaring the existence of the nuisance and ordering whomsoever has an
interest in the vehicle or trailer to comply with this chapter by removing the
vehicle or trailer within seventy two (72) hours of the notice. If such
nuisance is found to exist on private property, the police department shall
cause the notice to be affixed and, in addition to the affixed notice, a copy
thereof shall be delivered to the owner or occupant of the property; if a copy
of the notice cannot be delivered to the owner or occupant, a copy of the
notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the private property, with a
duplicate copy sent to the owner or occupant of the private property by
certified mail return, receipt requested. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.060: NOTICE OF PROCEDURE:
The notice so affixed or posted shall contain the request for removal within
the time specified in section
10.84.050 of this chapter. The notice shall advise that upon failure to comply
with the notice of removal, the police department, in the case of public
property or private property, shall undertake such removal or cause to be
removed by a private wrecker service, with the cost of removal to be levied
against the owner or occupant of the property. The notice shall also advise the
person to whom the notices are applicable of his right to contest the
determination of the police department that a violation under this chapter
exists by requesting a hearing before the city council, and that, if such a
hearing is desired, the request can be made by filing a written request with
the city clerk, whose office is located in the offices of the Warr Acres city
hall. A request for a hearing must be made within the time for removal set
forth in section
10.84.050 of this chapter. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.070: HEARING PROCEDURES:
A.   Upon receiving a request for a hearing pursuant to this chapter, the city
clerk shall set the hearing before the next regular meeting of the city
council. Notice of the hearing shall be given to the person requesting the
hearing and to the police officer issuing the notice, at least ten (10) days
prior to the hearing. No other notices are required. A request for hearing
under this section stays all enforcement proceedings until an order of the city
council is entered.
B.   At any such hearing, the city and persons to whom the notices have been
directed may introduce such witnesses and evidence as either party deems
necessary.
C.   The city council shall determine either that there exists a nuisance as
defined herein or that there does not exist a nuisance as defined herein.
D.   The city council shall issue a written order, either finding the existence
of a nuisance or finding that a nuisance does not exist. It shall state in its
order the findings of fact on which it based its decision and the order shall
indicate the vote of the council.
E.   The city clerk shall certify copies of the findings of fact and the
decision of the council, and remit copies of same to the property owners
involved and to the police department. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.080: REMOVAL OF VEHICLES OR TRAILERS:
Within the time for removal set forth in the notice for removal, or in the case
of private property within forty eight (48) hours of the date on which an order
is entered by the city council affirming the determination of the police
department, the owner of the abandoned, wrecked or inoperable vehicle or
trailer and the owner or occupant of the private property on which the same is
located, either or all of them, shall cause the removal of the vehicle or
trailer. If the violation is not remedied within the time set forth herein, the
police department shall have the right to take possession of the motor vehicle
or trailer and remove it from the premises or cause it to be removed by a
private wrecker service. In the event of removal and disposition of the motor
vehicle or trailer, the owner of the motor vehicle or trailer and the owner and
occupant of the private property from which the motor vehicle or trailer is
removed shall be jointly and severally liable for the expenses incurred in so
doing. The city shall possess a special lien to recover costs. It is unlawful
for any person to interfere with, hinder or refuse to allow the police
department to enter upon private property for the purpose of removing a motor
vehicle or trailer under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.090: NOTIFICATION OF REMOVAL:
A.   The police department, after taking possession of any motor vehicle or
trailer pursuant to this chapter, shall furnish notice in accordance with this
section by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner of
the motor vehicle or trailer at his last known address within fifteen (15) days
of the date on which possession of the motor vehicle or trailer is taken. In
the case of removal from private property, notice shall also be given to the
owner or occupant of the property from which the vehicle or trailer was taken.
If notice cannot be accomplished through certified mailing or posting, the
police department may give notice by publishing the notice once in a newspaper
of general circulation within the city.
B.   The police department shall also contact the department of public safety,
state of Oklahoma, and such other agencies and departments of the government in
this and other states as are reasonably necessary to ascertain the names and
addresses of other persons with record interest in the motor vehicle or
trailer, including lien holders. Such other persons shall be given notice in
the same manner as stated in subsection A of this section.
C.   Notice under this section shall contain the following information:
   1.   The name and address of the last known registered owner of the motor
vehicle or trailer plus the name and address of any person claiming any
interest therein;
   2.   A full description of the vehicle or trailer, giving all available
information as to the make, year, serial and registration numbers, license tag
with year and state issuing such tag or registration;
   3.   A full statement of all the facts concerning the removal of the vehicle
or trailer including, but not limited to, the location from which the vehicle
or trailer was removed and the date(s) on which the motor vehicle was removed
and stored; and
   4.   The date, time and place of sale. The notice shall also advise the
person to whom it is given that the person who is entitled to possession of the
motor vehicle or trailer may reclaim it upon payment to the city of all charges
incurred by the city in the removal and storage of the motor vehicle or
trailer, except that if such reclamation is not made within thirty (30) days
after date of notice, the right to reclaim the motor vehicle or trailer, as
well as all right, title and interest of such person, shall be deemed to have
terminated and such person shall be deemed to have consented to the disposition
of the motor vehicle or trailer by the city.
D.   If unable to properly identify the last registered owner of any motor
vehicle or trailer, or if unable to obtain with reasonable certainty the names
and addresses of the owner or other interested parties, including lien holders,
it shall be sufficient notice under this section to publish the notice
described in subsection C of this section once in one newspaper of general
circulation in the city of Warr Acres. Such notice by publication may contain
multiple listings of motor vehicles and trailers.
E.   A copy of any notice required in this section, as well as a copy of any
certificates of sale issued hereunder by the city, or its designee, shall be
forwarded to the department of public safety, state of Oklahoma. (Ord. 866 §1,
1998)
10.84.100: DISPOSITION OF MOTOR VEHICLES OR TRAILERS:
A.   The motor vehicles or trailers shall be disposed of at public sale in
accordance with the provisions of this section, provided that no motor vehicle
or trailer shall be sold at public sale prior to thirty (30) days from the date
on which notice is given, pursuant to this section.
B.   At public sale, at least twenty one (21) days prior to the sale the police
department shall cause a notice to be published once in a newspaper of general
circulation in the city of Warr Acres, which notice shall state:
   1.   The sale is of a motor vehicle or trailer in the possession of the city
by virtue of seizure pursuant to this chapter;
   2.   A description of the motor vehicle or trailer, including, if available,
make, model, license number, title number, vehicle or trailer identification
and any information which shall accurately identify the vehicle or trailer;
   3.   The terms of the sale; and
   4.   The date, time and place of the sale.
The chief of police shall also cause a copy of this notice to be mailed to the
last known registered owner of the motor vehicle or trailer and to the owner or
occupant of the property from which the motor vehicle or trailer was taken
(unless they are one and the same), and to any other persons known to the chief
of police to be interested in the motor vehicle or trailer.
C.   On the date, time and place set forth in the notice, the motor vehicle or
trailer shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash or certified funds,
provided that any motor vehicle or trailer which cannot be sold for an amount
at least equal to the costs of the sale and other charges owed may be summarily
disposed of in the manner set forth in subsection A of this section. At the
time of payment of the purchase price, the police department shall execute a
certificate of sale for the motor vehicle or trailer in duplicate, the original
of which to be given to the purchaser and a copy to be retained by the police
department. Any certificate of sale issued under this section shall not
guarantee title or purport to give any title to the motor vehicle or trailer
greater than that which is possessed by the city. Should the sale be invalid
for any reason, the liability of the city shall be limited to the return of the
purchase price upon return of the motor vehicle or trailer.
D.   Proceeds of any sale pursuant to this section, after payment of all
reasonable costs of the auction, including notice and publication costs, and
the expenses of the city in towing and storing the motor vehicle or trailer,
shall be held in suspense by the city for a period of thirty (30) days from the
date of the receipt of the funds, during which time, upon presentation of
proper evidence of ownership of the disposed vehicle or trailer to the chief of
police, the owner or lien holder of the motor vehicle or trailer may recover
back from the city such proceeds, less the costs and expenses as stated above.
After thirty (30) days, the proceeds may be distributed to the general fund of
the city. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.120: ALTERNATIVE SALES PROCEDURE:
Nothing contained in this chapter shall prohibit the police department or a
private wrecker service from following the procedures established by applicable
laws of the state of Oklahoma governing the sale and disposition of personal
property and motor vehicles specifically, but not limited to, the provisions of
title 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 34-104 et seq., and title 47 Oklahoma
Statutes section 901 et seq., as an alternative to the procedures for disposing
of vehicles or trailers as set forth herein. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.130: REDEMPTION OF MOTOR VEHICLE OR TRAILER PRIOR TO SALE:
The owner of any motor vehicle or trailer which has come into the possession of
the city under the provisions of this chapter may redeem such vehicle or
trailer after its removal, but prior to its disposition upon presentation of
proper evidence of ownership and payment to the city of all charges incurred
regarding towing, storage and expenses of the sale, if any. This right of
redemption shall expressly terminate upon disposition of the motor vehicle or
trailer by the city. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.140: LIABILITY FOR TOWING AND STORAGE EXPENSES:
Any person from whose private property a motor vehicle or trailer is removed
and stored pursuant to this chapter is liable to the city for the expenses
incurred by it in the towing, storing or disposing of the motor vehicle or
trailer. In the event of the failure to pay such charges to the city if the
motor vehicle or trailer is redeemed or if the disposition of the motor vehicle
or trailer fails to generate sufficient funds to cover the costs of towing,
storage and disposition, the person from whose private property the motor
vehicle or trailer was removed shall pay to the city any costs incurred; if
these costs are not paid to the city immediately upon redemption or within the
sixty (60) days upon sale, such obligation may be collected under the law as
provided for any other indebtedness to the city. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
10.84.150: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of not more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court cost. Each act in violation of any of
the provisions hereof and/or each day such violation is allowed to continue
shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 866 §1, 1998)
CHAPTER 10.88
VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT
SECTION:
10.88.010: Purpose
10.88.020: Definition
10.88.030: Authorized
10.88.040: Seized And Impounded Vehicle Storage
10.88.050: Notice To Owner Of Impounded Vehicle
10.88.060: Place Of Impoundment
10.88.070: Release Of Impounded Vehicle
10.88.080: Redemption Of Impounded Vehicle
10.88.010: PURPOSE:
The impoundment of vehicles under authority of the provisions of this chapter
shall be construed as an enforcement procedure for protection of the public
peace, safety and welfare, and the safeguarding of property. Such procedure
shall be used generally for the prevention and removal of traffic hazards,
prevention and abatement of public nuisances arising from traffic law
violations, protection of the public rights and privileges in the use of city
streets and thoroughfares from obstructions placed and left in derogation of
such rights, to safeguard and protect recovered stolen vehicles, and to protect
the property of persons arrested from damage or theft. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.020: DEFINITION:
The word "vehicle" as used in this chapter, shall, in addition to its common
meaning, mean any vehicle, whether motorized or designed to be pulled, towed or
otherwise moved by another vehicle or power source, which is intended for use
on public roads and streets. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.030: AUTHORIZED:
   A.   Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove a
vehicle from any street, highway, private property or public property to a
storage facility as herein provided for in this chapter under the following
circumstances:
      1.   When any vehicle is left unattended, or is disabled upon any public
right-of-way, or where the person in charge of the vehicle is, by reason of
physical or mental injury, incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to
provide for the custody or removal of the vehicle, and such vehicle is so
parked as to constitute a hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of
traffic, or parked where parking is prohibited;
      2.   When a derelict vehicle has been parked upon a public right-of- way
for a period of forty eight (48) hours;
      3.   When any vehicle is left unattended for forty eight (48) hours,
police officers are authorized to give the owner of such vehicle notice of
complaint by delivery or affixing such notice to the vehicle and shall direct
the owner of the vehicle to remove the vehicle within twenty four (24) hours.
After notice of complaint is issued and the vehicle is not removed from the
roadway within the time provided such failure shall constitute prima facie
evidence of abandonment; or is so parked for any period of time as to
constitute a hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic and in
violation of this title. A vehicle will be deemed removed if it is either moved
to private property or is moved at least fifty feet (50') from its current
location;
      4.   When any vehicle has been parked for more than one (1) hour in
excess of the time allowed for parking in any place;
      5.   When any vehicle which has been involved in two (2) or more
violations of this title for which complaints have been issued and not
presented as required, is parked in violation of any provision of this title,
or when the driver or owner thereof is arrested or incarcerated as provided
herein;
      6.   When a vehicle has been parked on private property without the
consent of the owner or occupant of the property in violation of this chapter;
      7.   When any vehicle is left abandoned upon a public right-of-way in
excess of three (3) days from the date it was first reported or observed by
officers;
      8.   When officers recover a vehicle reported stolen and the owner cannot
be located, is unable or unwilling to effect the removal of the vehicle within
a reasonable amount of time not to exceed one (1) hour, or the preservation and
collection of evidence requires removal;
      9.   Where the vehicle has any evidentiary value, has directly or
indirectly been involved in the commission of a crime, has been used to
transport any person who has committed any offense involving the use of a
firearm, or was directly or indirectly associated with a drive by shooting;
      10.   When a police officer effects the arrest of the owner or operator
of a vehicle out of said vehicle, and no person immediately present can
lawfully or reasonably be given custody of such vehicle;
      11.   When the vehicle bears a license plate which has expired for a
period in excess of ninety (90) days, bears a license plate which has been
altered or tampered with, or bears a temporary paper tag which has been expired
for a period in excess of ninety (90) days, or bears no license plate which
would be in conformance with the Oklahoma Vehicle License Act; or
      12.   Any place, including place of residence, when a police officer
effects the arrest of the operator of the vehicle, out of said vehicle, and the
operator is found to have operated the vehicle under any of the following
violations: reckless driving, careless driving, driving under the influence of
drugs or alcohol, driving while impaired, driving under a suspended, revoked or
denied license, driving with no state driver's license, eluding a police
officer, duty to give information and render aid, or otherwise involved in a
hit and run accident, or where applicable under subsection B of this section;
      13.   When a police officer has issued a citation under
chapter 10.18  of this title for failure to possess a valid security
verification, if the officer has probable cause to believe that the vehicle is
not insured as required by the compulsory insurance law of the state of
Oklahoma. If the operator of the vehicle produces what appears to be a valid
security verification form and the officer is unable to confirm compliance
through the state's online verification system or noncompliance by a subsequent
investigation, the officer shall be prohibited from seizing the vehicle and
causing such vehicle to be towed and stored. Further, no vehicle shall be
seized and towed under the provisions of this division if said vehicle is
displaying a valid temporary license plate that has not expired pursuant to the
provisions of Oklahoma Statutes, title 47, sections 1137.1 and 1137.3;
      14.   When the operator of a motor vehicle does not have the registration
certificate in the operator's possession or when a police officer determines
that the registration certificate has been obtained by misrepresentation of any
essential or material fact, or when any number or identifying information
appearing on such certificate has been changed, altered, obliterated or
concealed in any way, until the proper registration or identification of such
vehicle has been made or produced by the owner thereof.
   B.   Members of the police department shall remove a vehicle from any
street, highway, private property or public property to a storage facility as
provided for in section
10.88.040  of this chapter, when the person operating said vehicle fails to
produce valid security verification in addition to committing any one of the
following violations: reckless driving, careless driving, driving under the
influence of drugs or alcohol, driving while impaired, driving under a
suspended license, driving with an invalid driver's license, driving with no
state driver's license, driving with an expired, improper or no tag displayed,
avoiding a traffic stop, duty to give information and render aid or otherwise
involved in a hit and run accident, or eluding a police officer where it
involves the use of the subject vehicle. (Ord. 1102, 2011; Ord. 1195, 2019)
10.88.040: SEIZED AND IMPOUNDED VEHICLE STORAGE:
Vehicles seized or impounded by the city of Warr Acres may, at the direction of
the police department, be transported to the Warr Acres storage yard or other
place of storage owned and operated by the city of Warr Acres or to such place
as the city may designate. The owner of said vehicle shall be responsible to
the city or the city's designee for the following costs prior to the city or
the city's designee releasing said vehicle to the owner. The police chief, or
his designee, may, to meet the best ends of justice or expedite ongoing
investigations, release the owner of part or all of the cost owed the city or
the city's designee.
A.   The actual cost paid by the city or the city's designee to have said
vehicle transported to the place of storage, including the actual towing
expenses.
B.   A storage charge of nine dollars ($9.00) per day, or any portion thereof,
or the amount allowed by law charged by the city's designee. For purposes of
this section, the day of receipt shall constitute the first day and the day of
release shall constitute the last day.
C.   All fees incurred by the city or the city's designee, including lien
filing fees, to either return the vehicle to the owner or sell the vehicle
pursuant to statutory authority.
Prior to releasing said vehicle, the owner shall obtain authorization to
release from the Warr Acres police department, and pay to the city clerk, or
the city's designee, all costs listed above. If said vehicle is impounded
pursuant to any lawful authority, then those provisions shall apply in addition
to the requirements of this section. If said vehicle is impounded pursuant to
the provisions of subsection
10.88.030B of this chapter, then the owner of said vehicle, or anyone
authorized by the owner of the vehicle, shall show proof of valid security
verification, valid operator's license and valid vehicle tag registration
before the police department will authorize release of the vehicle. If said
owner fails to claim said vehicle within the time prescribed by law, then the
city manager, or the city's designee, is directed to institute proceedings to
have the vehicle sold under the applicable statutes of the state of Oklahoma.
(Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.050: NOTICE TO OWNER OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
Whenever an officer removes an unattended vehicle from a street or highway as
authorized in this chapter, and the officer has knowledge of or is able to
ascertain from the motor vehicle registration the name and address of the last
registered owner thereof, such officer shall give or cause to be given notice
in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal, the reasons therefor and
the place to which such vehicle has been removed. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.060: PLACE OF IMPOUNDMENT:
Every vehicle that is impounded hereunder shall be removed to the location that
is designated by the police chief or his designee. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.070: RELEASE OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
A.   Any vehicle impounded under the authority granted herein shall be stored
and held safely until a written order for its release, signed by an authorized
officer of the city, has been issued. Such order of release shall be
conditioned upon the payment of an impound fee in the amount of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) by the person to whom the release is issued. This impound fee
shall be independent of any fines, costs or fees which may be assessed from
citations issued to any person for violation of traffic laws or other ordinance
violations involving the impounded vehicle.
B.   There is hereby created within the police fund, a special account into
which all impound fees shall be deposited from which expenditures may be used
for enforcement of traffic safety. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
10.88.080: REDEMPTION OF IMPOUNDED VEHICLE:
Presentation of the order of release as provided in section
10.88.070 of this chapter at the place of impoundment, together with payment or
tender of payment of all impoundment costs and accrued storage charges due,
shall entitle the person presenting such release to obtain possession of such
vehicle. (Ord. 1066 §1, 2009)
CHAPTER 10.92
VIOLATIONS; CITATIONS; PENALTY 1
SECTION:
10.92.010: Traffic Ticket Complaints
10.92.020: Bond Posted
10.92.030: Failure To Appear
10.92.040: Prima Facie Presumption Of Vehicle Owner To Be Violator
10.92.050: Violations
10.92.060: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. 47 OS ch. 16. See also title 2,
  chapter 2.24 of this code.
10.92.010: TRAFFIC TICKET COMPLAINTS:
A.   Police officers are authorized to give notice to persons violating any
provision of this title, except chapters
10.12 and
10.36, and section
10.64.080 of this title, by delivering traffic ticket complaints to violators
or, in cases where vehicles without drivers are parked or stopped in violation
of this title, except chapters
10.12 and
10.36, and section
10.64.080 of this title, by affixing such complaint to the vehicle. Such
complaint, among other things, shall indicate briefly the charge or violation,
shall bear the registration number of the vehicle, and shall direct the
violator to present the complaint at the police station or municipal court in
or before a time as may be specified thereon. Nothing in this section shall
abridge the power of a police officer to arrest any violator and to take him
into custody, or to file a complaint against him at any time.
B.   The police department shall use traffic complaints furnished by the city,
and such complaints shall be serially numbered. (Prior code §18-99)
10.92.020: BOND POSTED:
When any bond is required for appearance for any violation, as provided in this
chapter, the person charged with an offense shall be released from custody on
posting with the municipal court a bond for each offense, in the amount to be
determined by the court. (Prior code §18-100)
10.92.030: FAILURE TO APPEAR:
A.   Any person who has been charged with a violation of any provision of this
title, except chapters
10.12 and
10.36, and section
10.64.080 of this title, having been duly issued a traffic ticket complaint as
provided in this chapter, who fails to appear in accordance with the
instructions on the complaint, shall be subject to having a warrant of arrest
and a contempt citation, at the discretion of the municipal court, issued
against him or her.
B.   Any person who violates this section shall be subject to being charged
with the offense of failure to appear and, upon conviction thereof in the
municipal court, fined in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus
costs, for each complaint said person failed to appear on. In addition, if the
city has entered into a contract with a collection agency for the purpose of
collecting fines for failure to appear, and such contract authorizes the
collection of a fee of up to thirty five percent (35%) for the collection of
said fine, then the court shall order the person to pay said fee. (Ord. 1116,
2011)
10.92.040: PRIMA FACIE PRESUMPTION OF VEHICLE OWNER TO BE VIOLATOR:
In any prosecution charging a violation governing the standing or parking of a
vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was
parked in violation of any such regulation or provisions, together with proof
that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such standing or
parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a
prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the
person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time
during which, such violation occurred. (Prior code §18-102)
10.92.050: VIOLATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to do any act forbidden, or
to fail to perform any act required, in this title. It is unlawful for a parent
of a child or the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly to permit any
such child or ward to violate any provision of this title. It is unlawful for
any person, firm or corporation to authorize or knowingly to permit any vehicle
registered in his or its name to be driven or to stand or be parked in
violation of any provision of this title. (Prior code §18-103)
10.92.060: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this title,
except chapters
10.12 and
10.36 and section
10.64.080 of this title, shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of an
offense and fined in a sum not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus
costs for each offense; and upon default of the payment of such fine and costs,
may be ordered held and incarcerated until he or she has served out the same at
the rate of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day for each dollar of fine and
cost, or to work on the streets, alleys, areas and public grounds of the city,
under the direction of a proper city official, at such rate, until such fine
and costs are satisfied. (Ord. 1000 §7, 2004: Ord. 657 §8, 1987)
TITLE 11
RESERVED
TITLE 12
CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS
General   12.01
Streets   12.02
Sidewalks   12.03
Driveways   12.04
Approaches, Curbs And Gutters   12.05
CHAPTER 12.01
GENERAL
SECTION:
12.01.010: Access To Fire Hydrants And Watergates
12.01.020: Penalty
12.01.010: ACCESS TO FIRE HYDRANTS AND WATERGATES:
Free and unobstructed access to all fire hydrants and watergates shall be
maintained at all times. No material of any kind whatsoever shall be placed
within ten feet (10') of any hydrant, no more excavations made than absolutely
necessary. (Ord. 861 §1, 1998)
12.01.020: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this title, upon conviction
thereof in the municipal court, shall be guilty of an offense and subject to a
fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus court costs for each day
such person is found to be in violation of this title plus the costs of proper
replacement of streets, sidewalks, driveways, and approaches, curbs and gutters
not in compliance with the standards provided in this title. (Ord. 861 §1,
1998)
CHAPTER 12.02
STREETS
SECTION:
12.02.010: Paving Standards And Specifications
12.02.020: New Construction; Materials
12.02.030: Licensed And Bonded
12.02.040: Excavations; Permit Required
12.02.050: Deposit; Guarantee Cost Of Repair For Excavation
12.02.060: Permit And Inspection Fees For Excavation
12.02.070: Drilling; Permit, Deposit Required
12.02.080: Permit And Inspection Fees For Drilling
12.02.090: Limitations Of Permits
12.02.100: Depth; Size Of Holes; Drilling
12.02.110: Restoration Of Pavement After Paving Cuts
12.02.120: Emergency Cuts And Excavations
12.02.130: Interfering With Paving Cuts And Excavations
12.02.140: Barriers And Warning Lights
12.02.150: Sheeting And Bracing
12.02.160: Excavation Length
12.02.170: Bridges Or Walks Over Excavations
12.02.180: Passageways During Excavations
12.02.190: Least Inconvenience To The Public; Unobstructed Waterway
12.02.200: Tunneling Under Pavement
12.02.210: Open Trenches; Time Limit
12.02.220: Backfilling Generally
12.02.230: Backfilling; Unsatisfactory Work
12.02.240: Permanent Repair Standards
12.02.250: Removal Of Excavated Materials
12.02.260: Contractors
12.02.010: PAVING STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Any person, persons, firm or corporation desiring to construct or pave
dedicated streets within the city limits shall construct or pave the streets
according to the standards and specifications as set forth in this section as
follows:
A.   If hot asphalt concrete is used, it shall be six inches (6") in depth,
over eight inches (8") of stabilized soil compacted to at least ninety five
percent (95%) standard proctor density; or
B.   If portland cement concrete is used, it shall be eight inches (8") in
depth, three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi, over eight inches (8") of
stabilized soil compacted to at least ninety five percent (95%) standard
proctor density. Provided, however, that for streets in areas only zoned
residential, C-1 and/or C-2, portland cement concrete which is six inches (6")
in depth, three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi, over six inches (6") of
stabilized soil (95 percent standard proctor density) may be used unless it is
determined by the city engineer that the street in question may be used as a
collector or arterial street, or where it is determined by the city engineer
that other considerations warrant use of eight inches (8") concrete and/or
eight inches (8") stabilized soil. (Ord. 1140, 2014)
12.02.020: NEW CONSTRUCTION; MATERIALS:
In all new additions to the city, only portland cement concrete shall be
allowed according to the standards and specifications set forth in section
12.02.010 of this chapter. This requirement applies only to new addition
construction on dedicated streets and does not apply to existing roadways where
widening, reconstruction or resurfacing is needed or required. For the purposes
of this section, the term "new addition" or "new additions" shall mean any
construction on land which had not been platted for any purpose by the city of
Warr Acres as of October 6, 1998. (Ord. 1077 §1, 2009)
12.02.030: LICENSED AND BONDED:
A.   Any person, persons, firm or corporation desiring to construct or pave
streets, using asphalt, concrete and/or portland cement concrete within the
city limits must be licensed and bonded. A performance bond in the amount of
ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) is required to be on file with the city clerk
before a permit can be issued and work is commenced.
B.   No surety will be accepted who is now in default or delinquent on any bond
or who is interested in any litigation against the city. All bonds shall be
executed by surety companies licensed to do business in the state and
acceptable to the council. Each bond shall be executed by the contractor and
the surety. (Ord. 861 §1, 1998)
12.02.040: EXCAVATIONS; PERMIT REQUIRED:
A.   Any person, persons, firm, corporation or municipality desiring to tear
up, open, drill under or push under the pavement or curbing on any street,
avenue, alley or public grounds, or to make any excavation in any street, alley
or public grounds in the city shall, before commencing any such operation, make
written application to the city clerk for permission to do so, which
application shall state the dimensions, the exact locations and any other
information that the city clerk may require, and which application shall be
made on a form to be supplied by the city clerk; and such permission shall in
all cases be granted upon compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
B.   Notwithstanding and in addition to the provisions of subsection A of this
section, all applications for and issuance of paving cut permits shall be
approved by the city. (Ord. 861 §1, 1998)
12.02.050: DEPOSIT; GUARANTEE COST OF REPAIR FOR EXCAVATION:
Upon receipt of an application to make a cut into pavement, the city clerk may
issue a permit to make such pavement cut. Before such permit is issued, the
city clerk shall collect from the applicant a deposit of money to guarantee the
