1 1. See section
  8.08.151 of this Code.
13.04.080: SEWER TIE-ON OR TAP INTO SYSTEM; FEE:
There is hereby established and levied the following sewer tie-on or tap-in
fees inside the City limits and outside the City limits of Warr Acres as
follows:
A.   Inside The City Limits: No person or entity shall connect any house,
business, building or other establishment to the sanitary sewer system within
the City limits of the City without first paying to the City Treasurer the
sewer tie-on or tap-in fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each single-family
residence, business, or establishment; and for multiple-family residences, the
fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first unit, and twenty dollars
($20.00) for each additional unit, which fee shall be in addition to other
charges which may be levied by other ordinances of the City.
B.   Outside The City Limits: No person or entity shall connect any house,
business, building, or other establishment located outside the City limits of
the City, to the sanitary sewer system of the City without first paying to the
City Treasurer the sewer tie-on or tap-in fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for each single- family residence, business, or other establishment; and for
multiple-family residences, the fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
the first unit, and forty dollars ($40.00) for each additional unit, which fee
shall be in addition to other charges which may be levied by other ordinances
of the City.
C.   Employee Presence Required: In addition to the foregoing subsections, no
person or entity shall connect any house, business, building or establishment
to the sewer system of the City, unless a City employee is present to observe
the tap-in or tie-in. Additionally, no person or entity shall connect any
house, business, building or establishment to the sanitary sewer system of the
City without also installing a backflow preventer device and/or an accessible
cleanout/overflow line adjacent to or on the sanitary sewer riser within the
utility easement. (Ord. 1013 §1, 2006)
13.04.090: BILLING AND PAYMENT OF ACCOUNTS:
The rates, fees, and charges provided in this chapter shall be monthly rates
and shall be made for a period of one month in arrears. Statements for each
sewer service account shall be mailed to the customer on a monthly basis. The
statement is due in full upon receipt and shall become delinquent unless paid
in full on or before the fifth day of the month following the date of billing.
Failure to make payment in full by the date of delinquency shall result in an
administrative fee (late charge) of ten percent (10%) being assessed on the
account. In addition, failure to pay by the delinquency date may also be
considered the basis for termination of service or initiation of collection
procedures as established by the City. All payments on account shall be in U.S.
currency, by check, money order, or an electronic funds transfer (EFT)
transaction. All checks and EFTs will be accepted subject to collection at the
bank. In the event a check or EFT is not honored by the bank and is returned
for any reason, the utility account credit previously made to the account will
be removed and the account will be charged an additional fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) as a return check fee. When a check or EFT payment is
dishonored by the bank, the Billing Clerk shall notify the payor either in
person or in writing of the action of the bank. Upon such notification, the
payor shall immediately redeem or make restitution of the check. Restitution or
redemption of a dishonored payment shall be in the form of cash, cashier's
check or money order only. Upon the dishonoring by the bank of any two (2)
payments, all future payments on the account must be in the form of cash,
cashier's check, or money order until the Billing Clerk determines that such
payments are no longer at risk of being dishonored. (Ord. 1171, 2016)
13.04.100: BILLING AND COLLECTION:
The Utility Billing Clerk of the City of Warr Acres shall be responsible for
the billing and collection of sanitary sewer charges, which shall be assessed,
levied and collected in conjunction with the administration of the charges for
sewer service supplied by the City. The same shall be subject to and governed
by the valid and applicable rules and regulations from time to time established
by the City with respect to the collection of sewer charges. The sanitary sewer
charges shall be a lien upon all real property served by the City sewer system.
Upon payment in full to the City of delinquent sanitary sewer charges and fees,
together with all other costs and fees authorized by this chapter that have
been secured by a lien filed with the Oklahoma County Clerk, the Billing Clerk
shall file with the Oklahoma County Clerk an appropriate release of the lien.
(Ord. 1171, 2016)
13.04.110: INTEREST, ATTORNEY FEES AND COSTS:
Unless otherwise provided in the utility service agreement, the customer agrees
that delinquent accounts shall accrue interest on the unpaid balance until paid
in full in an amount equal to the statutory rate of interest or the rate of
interest on judgments as established by the Supreme Court, whichever shall be
the greater. In addition, the City shall be entitled to recover a reasonable
attorney fee and costs incurred in the event collection efforts are required to
recover sums due on accounts. Interest, attorney fees and other costs may be
included in and secured by the lien filed against the property as provided
herein. (Ord. 1013 §1, 2006)
13.04.120: SANITARY SEWER FUND:
The funds received from the collection of the user charges or rates authorized
by this chapter shall be deposited monthly with the City Treasury and shall be
accounted for and be known as the Sanitary Sewer Fund. Appropriate accounting
procedures shall be established for separating the revenues received from each
component part of both the user charges and debt service charges and, when
appropriated by Council, monies from such fund shall be available for the
payment of the following expenses:
A.   Operation, maintenance and replacement costs for the sewage treatment
plant and collection system, which shall include the following applicable
General Government Fund expenses pertaining to the management of the sewage
works:
   1.   Engineering;
   2.   General administration of public service and safety;
   3.   Buildings, inspections, licenses and permits;
   4.   Operation and maintenance of the City building and public lands;
   5.   Vehicle insurance.
B.   Administrative costs for billing, collection and data processing.
C.   Industrial monitoring costs.
D.   Cost for treating extra strength sewage.
E.   Debt service costs for payment of the principal and/or interest on any
debt incurred for the construction of such treatment works or for the creation
of a Sinking Fund for the payment of such debt. (Ord. 1013 §1, 2006)
13.04.130: TERMINATION OF SERVICE:
A utility billing account for sewer shall be considered delinquent upon the
failure of any customer or user to pay the full amount owed, including any
service fees, interest, penalties, and/or required deposits, after thirty (30)
days from the date on which the bill is stated to be due. In addition to the
penalties provided for within this chapter, delinquent utility billing accounts
for sewer shall be processed in the following manner:
A.   Disconnection Of Sewer: After an account has become thirty (30) days
delinquent the City may, in addition to all other remedies available to the
City for collection on open accounts, initiate termination procedures to
terminate sewer service to the described premises by entering the described
premises, pursuant to the right of ingress and egress granted by the customer
to the City in the utility service agreement, with all personnel and equipment
necessary to accomplish the disconnection of the sewer service line to the main
sewer line belonging to the City. In addition to the notice provisions
contained herein, the City may serve notice to any appropriate State agency of
its intent to terminate utility services to the described property.
B.   Termination Procedures And Stay Of Termination Proceedings: Delinquent
accounts shall be subject to termination through the process established in
title 3,
chapter 3.07 of this Code. Because billing is made for a period of one month in
arrears, any account subject to termination proceedings shall be accelerated
such that, before termination proceedings are discontinued, the portion (pro-
rated by the number of days in the month as of the date the payment is received
divided by the number of total days in the month) of the current month's bill
(the month during which a payment is received) shall be due and owing before
the account is removed from termination proceedings (i.e., the customer, owners
or any resident must pay the back due amounts, any amounts due on the last
issued bill which may not have yet become delinquent, and the pro-rated amount
due for the month during which payment is made as of the date of the payment).
C.   Reconnection Of Sewer: All disconnections shall be conducted during normal
business hours. When a disconnection of the sewer service line is accomplished
by the City, the line shall not be reconnected except at the expense of the
customer or user. In addition, the customer or user shall reimburse the City of
the expense incurred by the City in disconnecting and reconnecting the service
line prior to reconnection. Similarly, any new customer shall bear the expense
of reconnecting the service line as a condition of establishing service.
D.   Collection Of Delinquent Payment: If a user or customer's sewer service is
terminated for nonpayment or delinquent payment, the City may attempt to
collect the balance due through collection services or legal processes. All
rights and remedies available to the City pursuant to State law, this chapter,
and the utility service agreement shall be cumulative, and election by the City
to terminate the account by disconnection shall not prevent the City from
exercising all other rights and remedies it may have regarding the collection
of charges and amounts due for past services. (Ord. 1180, 2018)
13.04.140: SEWER SERVICE TO LEASED PROPERTY:
No person or entity, being the owner or other person in charge or having
control of real property, shall knowingly cause or permit such real property to
be leased, rented or otherwise occupied for human habitation purposes without
first providing water and sewer service to such premises or property. Violation
of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof,
such person or entity shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred
dollars ($200.00), plus court cost and fees. (Ord. 1013 §1, 2006)
13.04.150: APPLICABILITY:
From and after the effective date hereof, any accounts existing on the
effective date hereof which become delinquent two (2) times, terminated one
time, new accounts for sewer service, including existing accounts being
transferred to a different person or entity or to a different location, or any
other action resulting in a change in an account, shall require execution of a
utility service agreement and be subject to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1171, 2016)
CHAPTER 13.06
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES
SECTION:
13.06.010: Legislative Findings
13.06.020: Monthly Emergency Service Utility Service Charge
13.06.010: LEGISLATIVE FINDINGS:
The city council of the city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, makes the following
findings in consideration and adoption of this chapter:
A.   The city of Warr Acres is financially unable to provide ambulance and
emergency medical services for its citizens, and as a result has contracted
with the emergency management services agency (EMSA) to provide such services
to the citizens of Warr Acres, Oklahoma.
B.   The contract for such services has a monetary cost to the city of Warr
Acres to make these services available to its citizens which meets the need of
prompt, efficient, and professional emergency medical treatment and transport
as required by Warr Acres citizens. The provision of such service is a matter
affecting the public health and safety of the citizens of the city of Warr
Acres, and is hereby declared to be a public utility subject to a recurring
availability use charge.
C.   A monthly public safety and health utility service charge should be paid
by each utility unit customer in the city of Warr Acres to defray the cost of
making this vital service available. (Ord. 1032 §2, 2006)
13.06.020: MONTHLY EMERGENCY SERVICE UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE:
A.   A monthly utility service charge or fee is levied on each utility unit
within the corporate limits of the city of Warr Acres, Oklahoma, for providing
ambulance service for the citizens of the city, payable in advance. The amount
of this fee may be amended from time to time by resolution adopted by the city
council of the city of Warr Acres.
B.   The monthly public safety utility service fee shall be charged on the same
classification as water and sewer services. The service charge or fee shall be
as follows:
   1.   Single-family residential shall be two dollars twenty five cents
($2.25) per month per occupancy.
   2.   Multi-family residential shall be two dollars twenty five cents ($2.25)
per month per unit.
   3.   Nursing homes and assisted living centers shall be two dollars twenty
five cents ($2.25) per month per bed.
   4.   Businesses shall be one dollar fifty cents ($1.50) per occupancy. (No
total care coverage.)
C.   All proceeds from the monthly emergency ambulance fee established shall be
deposited in a fund maintained exclusively to apply to charges made to or
incurred by the city in providing emergency medical services to the residents
of the city. (Ord. 1074 §1, 2009)
CHAPTER 13.08
WASTES PROHIBITED IN SEWERS
SECTION:
13.08.010: Prohibited Waters And Wastes
13.08.020: Harmful Wastes
13.08.025: Restrictions On Wastewater Strength
13.08.030: Handling Of Prohibited Or Harmful Wastes
13.08.040: Industrial Wastes Connections; Permit
13.08.050: Industrial Wastes Connections; User's Responsibilities
13.08.060: Nonconforming Sewer Connections
13.08.070: Grease, Oil And Sand Interceptors
13.08.080: Control Manholes For Industrial Wastes Sewers
13.08.090: Waste Measurement, Tests And Analyses, Standards
13.08.100: Acceptance Of Extra Strength Industrial Wastes By Special Agreement
13.08.110: Injury To Sewers Or Sewage Works
13.08.120: Right Of Entry For Inspection
13.08.121: Private Meters And Adjustments For Water And Sewer Waste Disposal
13.08.130: Notice Of Violation
13.08.140: Penalty
13.08.150: Enforcement
13.08.010: PROHIBITED WATERS AND WASTES:
A.   It is unlawful and an offense for any person to connect or cause to be
connected the downspout or conduits draining storm water or rainwater from the
roofs, premises or other places or buildings, or uncontaminated cooling water
or unpolluted industrial process waters with any of the lateral or main
sanitary sewers of the city, or to in any manner conduct or cause to be
conducted any uncontaminated cooling or unpolluted industrial process water,
storm water, surface or subsurface water or rainwater whatsoever into such
sanitary sewers.
B.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following
described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
   1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid or gas;
   2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or
gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, to constitute
a hazard to humans or animals, to create a public nuisance, or to create any
hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including, but
not limited to, cyanides in excess of two milligrams per liter (2 mg/l) as
cyanogen in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer;
   3.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 6.0 or greater than 10.5 or
having any other chemical or corrosive property which are hazardous or capable
of causing damage to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works;
   4.   Solids or viscous substances in quantities or of sizes (will no pass
through a 1/4 inch screen) capable of causing obstruction to flow in sewers or
other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works, storm sewers
or natural outlets, such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud,
straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, rubber,
unground garbage, animal grease or oil, whole blood, paunch manure, hair, meat
fleshings, entrails, bones, hooves, toenails, bristles, horns, chicken feet or
heads, yeast, spent grain, hops, whey, whole or separated milk, paper dishes,
cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. (Ord.
414 §1, 1976)
13.08.020: HARMFUL WASTES:
A.   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely, in the opinion of
the city engineer, that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage
treatment process or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream,
or can otherwise endanger life, limb, or public property, or constitute a
nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the
city engineer will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of
subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of
construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of
the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of
treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent
factors.
B.   The prohibited substances are:
   1.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty
degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) or sixty five degrees centigrade (65°C);
   2.   Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether
emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred milligrams per liter (100 mg/l), or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between thirty two (32) and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F) (0 and
65 degrees centigrade);
   3.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and
operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths (3/4)
horsepower or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the city
engineer;
   4.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or
concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not;
   5.   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, and
similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive
chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the
composite sewage as measured at the points of discharge of the city sewers into
the outfall lines transporting sewage to the sewage treatment plant exceeds the
limits established by the city engineer for such materials;
   6.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste producing or
odor producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be
established by the city engineer as necessary, after treatment of composite
sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal, or other public
agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters;
   7.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half life or concentration
as may exceed the limits established by the city engineer in compliance with
applicable state or federal regulations;
   8.   Materials which exert or cause:
      a.   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not
limited to, fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved
solids (such as, but lot limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate),
      b.   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and
vegetable tanning solutions),
      c.   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements (such
as, but not limited to, whey, whole or separated milk, yeast, whole blood,
etc.) in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage
treatment works,
      d.   Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting
"slugs";
   9.   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are
amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction
over discharge to the receiving waters. (Ord. 414 §2, 1976)
13.08.025: RESTRICTIONS ON WASTEWATER STRENGTH:
No person or user shall discharge wastewater, which exceeds the following set
of standards (table A, "Local Discharge Restrictions", of this section) unless
an exception is permitted as provided in this chapter. Dilution of any
wastewater discharge for the purpose of satisfying these requirements shall be
considered in violation of this section.
 
Table A
Local Discharge Restrictions
Pollutant Daily Maximum Milligrams Per Liter
Arsenic (total)       0.424
Cadmium (total)       0.208
Chromium (total)      2.494
Copper (total)        0.472
Cyanide (total)       0.304
Lead (total)          0.319
Mercury (total)       0.039
Molybdenum (total)    0.223
Nickel (total)        3.157
Phenols (total)       60.980
Selenium (total)      0.580

Thallium (total)      0.168
Zinc (total)          1.060
 
(Ord. 914 §1, 2000)
13.08.030: HANDLING OF PROHIBITED OR HARMFUL WASTES:
A.   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to
the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the
characteristics enumerated in sections
13.08.010 and
13.08.020 of this chapter, and which in the judgment of the city engineer may
have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or
receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a
public nuisance, the city engineer may:
   1.   Reject the wastes;
   2.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to public
sewers;
   3.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
   4.   Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the
wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges.
B.   If the city engineer permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste
flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject
to his review and approval, and subject to the requirements of all applicable
codes, ordinances and laws. (Ord. 414 §3, 1976)
13.08.040: INDUSTRIAL WASTES CONNECTIONS; PERMIT:
Any person applying to the city engineer for a permit to make any connection
for industrial wastes shall furnish the following information:
A.   A plat of the property showing accurately all existing sewers and storm
drains;
B.   Plans and specifications covering any work proposed to be performed under
the permit;
C.   A complete schedule of all process waters and industrial wastes produced
or expected to be produced at the property, including a description of the
character of each waste, the daily volume and maximum rates of discharge, and
representative analyses;
D.   The name and address of the firm who will perform the work covered by the
permit. (Ord. 414 §4, 1976)
13.08.050: INDUSTRIAL WASTES CONNECTIONS; USER'S RESPONSIBILITIES:
The grantees of industrial waste connections shall cooperate at all times with
the city engineer in the inspecting, sampling and study of the industrial
wastes and any facilities provided for pretreatment. The user shall also
furnish any additional information relating to the installation or use of the
industrial sewer as may be requested by the city engineer and shall operate and
maintain any waste pretreatment facilities as may be required as a condition of
the acceptance into the public sewer of the industrial wastes involved, in an
efficient manner at all times and at no expense to the city. The user shall
notify the city engineer immediately in the event of any accident or other
occurrence that occasions discharge to the public sewers of any wastes or
process waters not covered by agreement and permit. (Ord. 414 §5, 1976)
13.08.060: NONCONFORMING SEWER CONNECTIONS:
The city engineer shall cause to be served on the owner and/or occupant of any
buildings or establishments with any sewer connections which do not conform to
the provisions of this chapter at the time of the passage of the ordinance
codified in this chapter, a notice in writing stating that the sewer
connections must be made as required, giving thirty (30) days' time in which to
make the proper connection. If, after thirty (30) days from the day of the
service of the notice, the proper connection has not been made, it is unlawful
and an offense for any person, firm, association or corporation to maintain or
use any said sewer connection not conforming to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 414 §6, 1976)
13.08.070: GREASE, OIL AND SAND INTERCEPTORS:
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the
city engineer, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes
containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other
harmful ingredients, except that such interceptors shall not be required for
private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type
and capacity approved by the city engineer and shall be located so as to be
readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Such interceptors
shall be constructed under the supervision of the city inspector and shall be
maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at
all times. (Ord. 414 §7, 1976)
13.08.080: CONTROL MANHOLES FOR INDUSTRIAL WASTES SEWERS:
Where required by the city engineer, the owner of any property serviced by a
building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control
manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located,
and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city
engineer. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall
be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. (Ord. 414
§8, 1976)
13.08.090: WASTE MEASUREMENT, TESTS AND ANALYSES, STANDARDS:
All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and
wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods For The Examination Of
Water And Waste Water", published by the American Public Health Association,
and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon suitable
samples taken at the control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has
been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest
downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer
is connected. (Ord. 414 §9, 1976)
13.08.100: ACCEPTANCE OF EXTRA STRENGTH INDUSTRIAL WASTES BY SPECIAL AGREEMENT:
No statement contained in this chapter shall be construed as preventing any
special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern
whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by
the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern.
(Ord. 414 §10, 1976)
13.08.110: INJURY TO SEWERS OR SEWAGE WORKS:
No person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy,
uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which
is a part of the sewers or sewage works. (Ord. 414 §11, 1976)
13.08.120: RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION:
The city engineer and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing
proper credentials, shall be permitted to enter all properties at reasonable
times for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and
testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 414 §12, 1976)
13.08.121: PRIVATE METERS AND ADJUSTMENTS FOR WATER AND SEWER WASTE DISPOSAL:
A.   The city is hereby authorized to permit customers to connect sanitary
sewer meters to their water system for the purpose of measuring sewage and/or
flow of potable water. The city shall prescribe the manner, type and location
of such meters. A fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be established for
reading such additional or private meters and administrating these customer
accounts.
B.   When the public water supply is used exclusively, the water consumption
during the previous month, as determined from the meter records received by the
city, shall be the valid basis for computing a sewage flow, with reference to
industrial users, unless actual sewage flow is measured by a recording meter of
a type to be approved by the city. The owner shall maintain such devices in
proper condition to accurately measure such flow. Upon failure to do so, the
water consumption shall be the basis for charges.
C.   In cases where all or part of the water consumed is obtained from private
supplies, well, etc., such person shall provide and maintain at all times
suitable metering devices approved by the city, in connection with all sources
of private water unless the control manhole provided for in the preceding
section shall be equipped with an approved volume measuring device. The volume
of private water consumed during the previous month, together with the
consumption of public water as determined from the records of the city, shall
be the basis for computing the sewage volume, or the owner may install, at his
expense, an approved metering device to accurately measure sewage flow as
before mentioned.
D.   When water is contained in a product, or is evaporated, or is discharged
as unpolluted waste in an uncontaminated condition to surface drainage, an
application may be made for a reduction in the volume of waste discharge to the
public sewer, provided, that supporting data satisfactory to the city are
furnished. This data shall include a flow diagram, destination of the water
supply or waste and shall be supported by submetering data of a type
satisfactory to the city installed on such process piping at the expense of the
private owner. (Ord. 953 §1, 2001)
13.08.130: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter shall be subject
to being served with a citation for the offense by the city and to appear on
the matter in the municipal court, whereupon being found guilty of said
offense, said person shall be subject to fine and penalty as prescribed in
section
13.08.140 of this chapter. Any person who is served by the city with written
notice stating the nature of the violation must immediately, or within the
earliest reasonable practicable time after notice thereof, as deemed in the
sole discretion of the city, and permanently cease all violations or be subject
to being charged with and prosecuted for said violations by the city in the
municipal court, with each day for which any such violation continues being
deemed a separate offense and being subject, upon conviction thereof, to
penalty as such. (Ord. 657 §9, 1987)
13.08.140: PENALTY:
Any person who commits any of the violations specified in this chapter shall,
upon conviction thereof in the municipal court, be guilty of an offense and
shall be subject to paying a fine of not less than thirty five dollars ($35.00)
nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus court costs, for each offense
said person is convicted of. (Ord. 657 §9, 1987)
13.08.150: ENFORCEMENT:
The city engineer, his duly authorized representatives, and the director of the
city-county health department are vested with full authority to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 414 §15, 1976)
CHAPTER 13.10
NONFRANCHISED PUBLIC UTILITIES
SECTION:
13.10.010: Purpose
13.10.020: Definitions
13.10.030: Application Of Provisions
13.10.040: Repair, Maintenance And Quality
13.10.050: Delinquent Utilities; Permit For Temporary Access And Use
13.10.060: Construction
13.10.010: PURPOSE:
It is the obligation of the city to assure the public, and in particular the
inhabitants of the city, that public utility services supplied within the city
are supplied on a consistent and equal basis, and that such utilities shall
have such access as shall be necessary to protect public health, safety,
welfare and property. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
13.10.020: DEFINITIONS:
As used in the ordinance codified in this chapter, the following terms are
defined:
PUBLIC UTILITY: Any entity, whether person, firm, corporation, partnership,
trust, public trust, municipality, or any other entity, furnishing power, cable
television, telephone, sewer services, light, heat, gas, electricity or water
for residential or commercial use within the city of Warr Acres, and which
uses, in whole or part, the streets, alleys, easements, public grounds or other
rights of way within this city.
PUBLIC UTILITY COMMISSIONER: The mayor of Warr Acres.
SERVICES: The furnishing of power, cable television, telephone, sewer services,
light, heat, gas, electricity or water. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
13.10.030: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all utilities within the city
which are operating without a franchise agreement granted by voters of the city
pursuant to the constitution and the statutes of the state, and pursuant to the
ordinances of this city. Those operating with a franchise agreement shall be
governed by the terms of such agreement, which shall control over any conflict
with the terms of this chapter. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
13.10.040: REPAIR, MAINTENANCE AND QUALITY:
Any and all utilities regulated by this chapter shall provide reasonable and
prompt repair and maintenance to and upon the equipment lines, installations
and other plant equipment and facilities which it uses, directly or indirectly,
to provide utility services. It shall have and maintain such equipment and
lines in good repair at all times, in full compliance with the laws, rules and
regulations of any regulating body of competent jurisdiction, whether federal,
state or local. It shall maintain a quality of services at all times, in full
compliance with the laws, rules and regulations of any regulating body of
competent jurisdiction, whether federal, state or local. Such utility shall, at
all times, use every reasonable precaution to ensure the safety, welfare and
convenience of all inhabitants within the city. The utility shall protect all
property within the city, real and personal, public and private, from any
damage due to defects or deficiencies in its lines, installations, plant,
equipment or other facilities. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
13.10.050: DELINQUENT UTILITIES; PERMIT FOR TEMPORARY ACCESS AND USE:
A.   No utility operating in Warr Acres may enter (or cause any person to
enter) onto any public easement, right of way, or property of this city, for
any purpose, unless that utility is current in all its payments to Warr Acres
of all amounts of tax due under sections
3.08.010 through
3.08.080, inclusive, of this code. If a utility has not provided all reports
and documents necessary for a determination of all amounts of tax due, or if it
has not allowed an inspection and audit of its books for a determination of all
amounts of tax due, the utility shall be considered as not current in its
payment of tax.
B.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, and notwithstanding any other portion of
this code, the mayor, as public utility commissioner, upon request of any
utility, request of any interested person, or on his own initiative, may issue
a permit as herein described, which may permit such entry and access, under the
terms and conditions of that permit:
   1.   The permit may authorize a specified utility to enter onto public
easements, rights of way, and city property to the extent necessary:
      a.   To make connection or reconnection of services within Warr Acres;
      b.   To conduct maintenance of their facilities within Warr Acres; and/or
      c.   To repair their facilities within Warr Acres.
   2.   The mayor may issue such a permit should he deem it necessary for the
public health, safety and welfare of persons within Warr Acres, and/or for the
protection of property within Warr Acres. However, a permit shall not be issued
solely to protect the property of the delinquent utility itself.
   3.   Such a permit must be in writing, and must specifically describe the
particular place or places included in the permit. No single permit may be for
a period of longer than sixty (60) days, although a permit may be renewed. The
permit must state its beginning and ending dates. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
13.10.060: CONSTRUCTION:
Nothing in this chapter, nor any act or proceeding hereunder, nor any permit
granted hereunder, shall be construed to constitute the granting of a franchise
to any public utility. Only if and when a franchise shall be duly authorized by
the voters of Warr Acres, as provided by the constitution and the laws of the
state, and by the charter and ordinances of Warr Acres, shall any utility be
deemed to have a franchise within Warr Acres. (Ord. 587 §1, 1984)
CHAPTER 13.12
REMOVAL OF PUBLIC UTILITY PROPERTY
SECTION:
13.12.010: Generally
13.12.020: Notice To Owner Or Company
13.12.030: City Removal; Generally
13.12.040: Failure To Pay Costs And Expenses
13.12.050: Costs Constitute Lien
13.12.010: GENERALLY:
In case it is necessary to change or move any property of any public utility in
the performance of or carrying on any public work by the city, its agents or
servants, or any person, firm or corporation contracting with the city to
perform any public work, such public utility owner or company will, upon proper
application by the city engineer or public utility commissioner, change or move
such property within the specified time as is provided in this chapter. The
city, its agents or servants, or persons, firms or corporations contracting
with the city shall not interfere with such property until ordered to do so by
the engineer or utility commissioner. (Prior code §15-16)
13.12.020: NOTICE TO OWNER OR COMPANY:
When necessary to move or change the property of any owner or company of any
public utility, the city, its agents or servants, or any firm, person or
corporation contracting with the city shall give written notice to the engineer
or public utility commissioner, who shall immediately notify the public utility
owner or company of such notice to move or change the property of the utility
owner or company, and the utility owner or company shall move or make such
change necessary within ten (10) days thereafter. (Prior code §15-17)
13.12.030: CITY REMOVAL; GENERALLY:
Should the public utility owner or company fail or refuse to remove or change
the property within the time specified by the request and/or notice provided
for by section
13.12.020 of this chapter, the city, its agents or servants, and/or any person,
firm or corporation contracting with the city shall remove or change or cause
the property to be removed or changed without further notice to the public
utility owner or company, and all cost or expense incurred or expended in the
moving or changing of the utility property, and all damages caused or incurred
by said failure or refusal shall be charged against the utility owner or
company, and the utility owner or company shall be liable for such costs or
damages thus incurred, and the utility owner or company shall be liable to the
city, its agents or servants, and/or persons, firms or corporations contracting
with the city for all costs, expenses and/or damages incurred or suffered by
them. (Prior code §15-18)
13.12.040: FAILURE TO PAY COSTS AND EXPENSES:
Failure or refusal to pay the cost or expense incurred and/or the damages
suffered resulting from the failure, refusal or delay in removing or changing
of the public utility property when requested as provided in this chapter and
within the specified time shall be regarded as a trespass and the public
utility owner or company may be ousted from the city, and, in addition thereto,
an action may be maintained against such utility owner or company for the
amount of the cost or expense incurred or expended and/or the damages suffered
that may result from such failure, refusal or delay in removing or changing
such public utility property when requested as provided in this chapter and in
the time specified, including all expense of collection, together with
reasonable attorney fees. (Prior code §15-19)
13.12.050: COSTS CONSTITUTE LIEN:
The cost, expense or damage incurred or resulting from the failure, refusal or
delay in moving or changing such utility property shall constitute a first and
prior lien on all of the assets located within the city limits of any public
utility owner or company. (Prior code §15-20)
CHAPTER 13.20
FRANCHISES AND LEASES
SECTION:
13.20.010: Utility Franchise; Generally
13.20.020: Oklahoma County Utility Services Authority Lease
13.20.040: Oklahoma Gas And Electric Company Franchise
13.20.050: Multimedia Cablevision Franchise
13.20.010: UTILITY FRANCHISE; GENERALLY:
Ordinance 135, passed and approved by the mayor and councilmen on January 5,
1960, grants, subject to approval of the qualified electors of the city voting
at an election to be held for such purpose, to the trustees of the Oklahoma
County utility services authority, their successors and assigns, for a period
of twenty five (25) years from and after the date of acceptance thereof by said
trustees, in the manner and time specified therein, a franchise for the use of
the streets, alleys and other public grounds and ways within the city for the
furnishing of such utility services, in accordance with the constitution and
statutes of the state, and also directs the calling of a special election for
the purpose of submitting to the qualified electors residing within the city
for their approval or disapproval. (Prior code §20-1)
13.20.020: OKLAHOMA COUNTY UTILITY SERVICES AUTHORITY LEASE:
A.   There has been presented to the city council an instrument of lease,
providing for the ratification of a certain lease and amendment to lease, both
dated May 1, 1961, between the city and the trustees of the Oklahoma County
utility services authority, and further providing for the substitution of the
terms of the new instrument for those of the aforesaid instruments effective
from the date of passage of the ordinance codified in this section to be
amended regarding ownership; and it is deemed for the best interest of the city
that the new instrument of lease be executed and delivered.
B.   All of the terms and provisions of the aforesaid instrument of lease
between the city and the trustees of the Oklahoma County utility services
authority, dated on the date of the passage of the ordinances codified in this
section, are approved; and the mayor is authorized and directed to execute said
instrument of lease and to deliver the same to the trustees of the Oklahoma
County utility services authority, all for and on behalf of the city. A fully
executed duplicate of said instrument is directed to be filed with the city
clerk. (Prior code §20-2; prior code appx. III)
13.20.040: OKLAHOMA GAS AND ELECTRIC COMPANY FRANCHISE:
Ordinance 34, which grants a franchise to the Oklahoma Gas and Electric
Company, was passed and approved on January 15, 1952, and filed with the city
clerk. (Prior code appx. II)
13.20.050: MULTIMEDIA CABLEVISION FRANCHISE:
Ordinance 762, which grants a franchise to Multimedia Cablevision, was passed
and approved on March 7, 1995, and filed with the city clerk. (Ord. 762, 1995)
CHAPTER 13.24
